summary: Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend after Townsend was substituted on late in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Previously, Merson had criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but Townsend responded by scoring a notable equalizer against Italy, prompting Merson to admit his mistake. Despite seemingly resolving their differences, Merson again mocked Townsend on Twitter for his brief appearance against Burnley.

Chelsea have made an official offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer is completed, Muto will initially join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Ogane denies any connection between Chelsea's interest and their recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and has earned 11 international caps for Japan. Although honoured by Chelsea's interest, Muto has not yet decided whether to accept the offer.

A large-scale Finnish study found that babies given antibiotics within their first six months of life are more likely to become overweight or obese as toddlers. Researchers analyzed data from over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and found that antibiotic exposure early in life, especially repeated prescriptions, was associated with increased body mass, particularly in boys. Although the study did not conclusively prove antibiotics cause weight gain, researchers suggest antibiotics may alter gut bacteria, affecting appetite and nutrient absorption. The findings highlight concerns about antibiotic overuse potentially contributing to the global childhood obesity epidemic, alongside other known risks such as eczema, digestive issues, and antibiotic resistance.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident, captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell, showed the guard losing his footing, dropping his rifle, and quickly scrambling back up, visibly embarrassed. The slip was likely caused by metal protectors on his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E Networks announced plans to remake the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally drew over 100 million viewers. Scheduled to air in 2016, the new version will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History channels, and will closely follow Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." LeVar Burton, who starred as Kunta Kinte in the original, will serve as co-executive producer. Producers will consult historical scholars to ensure authenticity. The remake aims to introduce the powerful story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery, to a new generation of viewers who have experienced significant historical and cultural developments, including Barack Obama's presidency, the Oscar-winning film "12 Years a Slave," and ongoing racial tensions in the U.S.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, alleges that in January 1978, on his first day working at Clarence House, palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy. Lawler claims he was pinned down, groped, and threatened, prompting him to leave the job immediately. Although he reported the incident at the time, his complaint was ignored. Prompted by recent investigations into historical VIP child abuse cover-ups, Lawler contacted palace officials again last year, but was initially rebuffed. Eventually, his complaint was passed to Scotland Yard, and police are now investigating. The Palace has stated it will cooperate fully with the investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video parodying the theme song from the '90s sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." Their video, which has gained over 1.7 million views on YouTube, humorously describes their journey toward parenthood and ends with a sonogram image of their unborn child. The couple created the video primarily to inform distant family and friends, and its viral success was unexpected. Jesse Meek is notably the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Another couple from Pennsylvania previously made a similar pregnancy announcement video using the same sitcom theme.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray but faded over time, was featured in key scenes of the film. It was part of a collection of over 150 items from the movie, owned by James Tumblin, who acquired the dress for $20 in the 1960s and amassed over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia. Other notable auction sales included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Clark Gable's suit ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary recently, and actress Hattie McDaniel became the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role in it.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after reportedly being dangled over the railing by his parents. The child dropped approximately 10-12 feet, sustaining minor injuries and bruises, but was not attacked by the cheetahs. His parents rescued him before emergency responders arrived, and he was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition. Zoo officials plan to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was temporarily closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, originally installed to enforce a 30mph limit, has been inactive for over two years after all fixed cameras in the West Midlands were turned off in March 2013 due to outdated technology. Recently, this camera was mysteriously repositioned to point directly at a residential home's front door. Birmingham City Council is aware of the issue and plans to send an engineer to inspect and possibly remove the camera. The council also confirmed that this particular camera will not be included in an upcoming pilot program using new digital technology. The homeowners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as confirmed by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, expressed excitement about participating, stating he is fit and ready. He highlighted Jamaica's strong relay tradition and his commitment to making his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed delight at Bolt's participation, anticipating impressive performances. The full Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Barcelona footballers Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their support for the club by attending a basketball El Clasico match, accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella. Barcelona narrowly defeated Real Madrid 85-80 in the Euro League basketball contest, although Real Madrid remains ahead in their division on points difference. Neymar recently captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile in a physical match at Emirates Stadium. Barcelona currently leads La Liga by four points and continues to compete for a treble, resuming league action against Celta Vigo on Sunday.

Italy is currently facing a significant increase in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received distress calls from 20 boats on Monday alone. Save the Children reported fears that 400 migrants may be missing after survivors claimed their boat carrying 550 people capsized near Libya. However, the Italian coast guard has not yet confirmed this incident, finding no evidence of the reported capsizing. According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM), over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, mostly from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year crossing the Mediterranean, often due to overcrowded vessels, bad weather, or abandonment by smugglers.

Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool after leaving Barcelona, although Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger admits he does not know exactly why Sanchez made this decision. Wenger is pleased Sanchez joined Arsenal, highlighting the player's immediate impact, scoring 19 goals so far this season, and praising his qualities, efficiency, and fighting spirit. Wenger acknowledged Liverpool's interest in Sanchez, suggesting it could have been linked to negotiations involving Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Wenger also downplayed speculation linking Arsenal with Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, instead praising Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for successfully adapting his team after Suarez's departure and injuries.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who recently ended his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, aims to set a lasting mark and inspire others. Tickets for the event, which will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, go on sale from April 19. Wiggins is also targeting an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams struggled to defeat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, eventually winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, but described the match as an "eye-opener," acknowledging she was not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought. Despite her singles victory, Williams and Alison Riske lost the doubles match to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in a 3-2 defeat for the US and relegation to World Group II. Williams, who recently won her 19th Grand Slam singles title at the Australian Open, admitted she needs to adjust her game for clay. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for the team to work harder to return to the elite World Group.

River Plate are interested in re-signing striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them before leaving for Porto in 2009. Vice president Matias Patanian confirmed the club's interest, stating they "dream of Falcao" and "the doors are open," but acknowledged the complexity of the deal. Falcao, currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco, has struggled this season, scoring only four Premier League goals. However, he recently matched Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. During his earlier stint at River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from the 2012 series of The X Factor, has become the official face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a vibrant city background, and includes a TV advertisement featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about the partnership, noting she regularly uses the product. The collaboration was arranged by the MILES agency, and her management highlighted the natural synergy between the artist and the brand.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, after reportedly arming himself with a weapon during a confrontation following a vehicle and foot pursuit. Torres, who is currently on leave pending investigation, was featured on a billboard erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association thanking the community for support. Siler's family and friends have expressed shock and distress, calling the billboard disrespectful and requesting its removal. The police association stated the billboard was not intended to offend but rather to acknowledge community support. Torres had previously shot another individual, Terry Knight, ten days earlier, an incident later deemed justified. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, according to Iranian state media. Three militants were also killed during the fighting in the southeastern town of Negur. Iranian officials stated the attackers crossed from Pakistan and requested Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving militants. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal, known for targeting Shiites and opposing Iranian influence, claimed responsibility. Iran has previously criticized Pakistan for not controlling militants who flee back into Pakistan after attacks. Pakistan condemned the incident, calling it terrorism, and promised cooperation in investigating and apprehending the attackers if they entered Pakistani territory.

In Japan, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani recently clarified in parliament that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. His statement came in response to a question from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler turned politician known for his colorful career, including wrestling Muhammad Ali, promoting wrestling events in North Korea, and converting to Islam while practicing Buddhism. Inoki, who claims to have personally seen a UFO, asked if Japan had ever scrambled jets against alien threats or conducted research into extraterrestrial visitors. Nakatani confirmed that while jets have been scrambled for unidentified objects, these have always turned out to be birds or other earthly phenomena. This is not the first time Japanese politicians have discussed extraterrestrial scenarios; in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal implications of defending against alien invasions under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on broke at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in eastern China's Anhui Province. Jin had stood on the toilet rim to avoid contact with the seat, fearing it was unclean, but the toilet collapsed and shattered, injuring him severely enough to require dozens of stitches. Initially admitting to friends he had been squatting, he later told police he was sitting normally, possibly to avoid compensation charges. Authorities considered the incident accidental but reminded the public that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. Investigators traced the camera back to Rebbie, who admitted to filming the girl and other juveniles over several years. The victim reported that Rebbie had sexually abused her from ages nine to thirteen, molesting her while she slept. Authorities found 41 videos, including explicit footage of minors, on Rebbie's computer. He faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Rebbie is currently held on $500,000 bail, with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a unique photo series titled "Daughter and Salary Man," featuring fathers dressed in sharp suits energetically leaping into the air next to their teenage daughters, who remain standing and smiling at the camera. The images aim to showcase the playful, expressive side of fathers who typically maintain a serious demeanor. The photographs, set against various Japanese landmarks, have gained significant online attention due to their unusual and humorous nature.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has opened the possibility for Kevin Pietersen's return to international cricket. Pietersen, who was controversially dropped by Downton after England's disastrous Ashes tour in Australia, has rejoined Surrey ahead of the county championship season, aiming to regain his place in the England Test team. During Surrey's team photo session at the KIA Oval, Pietersen appeared thoughtful yet jovial, joking with teammates and photographers, as he prepares for the upcoming season and a potential international comeback.

Romanian football club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, facing relegation, has fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria twice within one week. Initially dismissed due to poor results, Ze Maria was briefly reinstated by club owner Angelo Massone, but was fired again after a subsequent 2-0 defeat to FC Botosani. Ceahlaul currently sits 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international who joined the club in January as their third coach this season, will now be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao regrets his unsuccessful loan move to Manchester United, despite previously being unhappy in Monaco. Falcao struggled at United, scoring only four goals and failing to regain his pre-injury form. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played regularly and participated in the Champions League, although he acknowledges Falcao was not comfortable there.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a very tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt. The robbery occurred around 12:30 pm on Saturday at Union St dairy in east Christchurch, where the masked offender demanded cash from the owner's daughter, took the till drawer containing approximately $1,500, and fled. No weapons were reported, but the robber remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with two 15-year-old students. Initially arrested on March 19 for allowing a student to touch her breasts and kissing him, she was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. Shortly afterward, another student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district confirmed she remains on administrative leave and is prohibited from contact with students or school property.

In Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, a large crocodile was filmed swimming through a public marina carrying a dead pet dog in its jaws. The dog, wearing a red collar, belonged to a local bike shop owner and was attacked after approaching the crocodile at the water's edge. Tourist Tim Weston from New Zealand witnessed and photographed the incident, noting the crocodile held onto the dog for hours. The video has been viewed over 500,000 times online, prompting shocked reactions from social media users. Crocodiles are common in the area, living in nearby mangroves and a sanctuary, and are increasingly encountering humans due to urbanization.

Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident his team can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton leaving them just two points clear of the drop zone. Initially targeting 10 wins for survival, Bruce now hopes eight or nine might suffice, with Hull currently having only six victories. He attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players such as Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Hull face challenging upcoming fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United, but Bruce believes positivity and determination will help them secure the necessary results. Meanwhile, Southampton moved up to fifth place, but manager Ronald Koeman faced internal issues after Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty ahead of designated taker James Ward-Prowse, prompting Koeman to reinforce team discipline.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, has been banned from teaching for at least two years after allowing pupils to alter their SATs exam answers and personally changing some answers himself. This misconduct led to the annulment of the entire school's SATs results for the year. Although Guffick claimed he only asked pupils to make answers more legible, an investigation found he had breached exam rules. The disciplinary panel concluded his actions were dishonest but not fraudulent, noting he acted deliberately without duress, yet acknowledged his remorse and cooperation during the investigation. Guffick has 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish goalkeeper at Manchester United, has struggled to secure regular playing time since joining the club in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons. Currently third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes, Lindegaard was recently linked with a move away from United. Off the pitch, however, he enjoys a happy personal life, having married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius. The couple, who have a son together, have been dating since 2012. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, is active on Instagram, regularly sharing modeling photos with her followers.

The iconic blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, $260,000, came from a Sotheby's employee attempting to initiate bidding. The letters, originally installed in 1976 and removed in 2008, are currently owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who bought them after the stadium's closure. Jackson had hoped a new generation would enjoy the letters, even promising to visit the buyer if located in the U.S. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s significantly exceeded expectations, selling for $112,500 despite a lower estimate of $20,000 to $30,000.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after both were pictured using shisha pipes, with Sterling also inhaling nitrous oxide. Rodgers has not disciplined the players but emphasized the importance of understanding their roles as elite athletes. Ahead of Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, Rodgers has captain Steven Gerrard available after suspension but has not confirmed if Gerrard will start. Rodgers highlighted the importance of learning from past disappointments, stating that setbacks are part of the journey toward success.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after international duty, where he helped Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He shared a photo relaxing at home with his dog, captioned "Home Sweet Home." Ozil, who joined Arsenal from Real Madrid in 2013 for £42.5 million, missed Arsenal's previous match against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to play against Liverpool. Despite rumors of him being spotted in a Berlin nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger dismissed these claims. Ozil has been in strong form since returning from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January. He stated he is now fully adjusted to English football and enjoys the demanding schedule.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has dismissed speculation about replacing manager Luis Enrique, stating the club is "very happy" with his performance. Enrique, who joined last summer on a two-year contract, has impressed by positioning Barcelona close to winning three trophies this season. Bartomeu emphasized Enrique's dedication and confirmed the club has no immediate plans to discuss his contract, which runs until 2016. Recently, Enrique's team defeated Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay until 2020 on improved terms worth around £100,000 per week. Henderson, who joined Liverpool from Sunderland in 2011, has significantly improved under manager Brendan Rodgers, contributing seven goals and 13 assists this season. He is considered a potential successor to Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Henderson is the third key player, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, to recently agree a contract extension. Meanwhile, contract talks with Raheem Sterling, who previously rejected a new deal, are expected to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis has stated his intention to remain at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite interest from his former club Atletico Madrid. Luis, who joined Chelsea on a three-year deal last July, has struggled to secure a regular starting position. He recently played for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, but is now focused on Chelsea's Premier League title challenge. Manager Jose Mourinho continues to emphasize the importance of concentration and winning every remaining match, as the team faces nine difficult games ahead.

Nathan Hughes, initially banned for three matches after accidentally knocking out George North during a rugby match, had his suspension overturned following an appeal and widespread criticism of the original decision. Hughes' knee collided unintentionally with North's head as North scored a try, leaving North unconscious and requiring a month off due to concussion symptoms. Although Hughes was initially deemed reckless and received a red card, the appeal panel later concluded the incident was accidental and rescinded the ban. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon during his suspension but is now cleared to return to play.

A fiery red sunset appeared in Washington, particularly noticeable in Seattle, due to smoke from wildfires in Siberia. The fires began when farmers burned grass, but strong winds caused them to spread uncontrollably, destroying villages. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific Ocean, affecting air quality and creating intense red and orange sunsets in Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelengths of sunlight, allowing only red and orange colors to penetrate, especially visible during sunrise and sunset. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig from St. Louis, Missouri, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway shortly after purchasing it. Police later recovered the vehicle after receiving a tip from a man named Mick Sexton, who recognized the car. Upon its return, Schoenig discovered the thieves had spray-painted the rims red, added red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Rather than becoming upset, she humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her car. However, she noted the car had a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, prompting her to have it professionally cleaned. Schoenig, who owns a restaurant called The Hot Pot, is honoring Sexton by creating a smoothie named "The Sexton on Wheels."

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club uses incentivised contracts for key players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure to comply with financial fair play rules, meaning a failure to reach Europe's top competition would cost the squad around £12 million collectively. After losing to Manchester United, City sit in fourth place, just four points ahead of Liverpool, putting their Champions League qualification at risk. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team has significantly declined since starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea, suffering seven defeats and early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. Their uncertain European status could also affect their ability to attract top players like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who is also targeted by rivals Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in the 'mini-derby', thanks to a skillful free-kick from Callum Gribbin. The match, played at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium, featured predominantly local English talent, with 10 Mancunians among the starting players. United coach Paul McGuinness aimed to replicate senior-level conditions, employing a formation similar to the first team. Marcus Rashford missed two good chances for United, while City's Marcus Wood nearly scored with a chip. Gribbin, known for his impressive skills, earned and converted the decisive free-kick. United nearly doubled their lead through Cameron Borthwick-Jackson, while City narrowly missed equalizing late on. The result leaves United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury-hit City have lost both their playoff matches. The match highlighted promising young talent on both sides, suggesting potential future first-team opportunities.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th international cap during a 1-1 draw between England and Italy. Hart, who himself reached a milestone of 50 caps, described Buffon as an inspiration and someone he personally looks up to. Hart expressed pride in his own achievement but emphasized his desire to continue improving and accumulating more caps for club and country.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to enter the $70 billion food delivery market, offering delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. Customers will pay a nine percent service charge plus delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Previously hesitant to collaborate with third-party delivery services, Chipotle has now approved Postmates, which uses independent contractors similar to Uber. Other major chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or implementing delivery services. Additionally, presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton have recently been spotted dining at Chipotle locations.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly urged the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as a sentencing option for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In an emotional opinion piece, Bill and Denise Richard described the profound suffering their family endured, including the death of their 8-year-old son and severe injuries to their daughter. They argue that pursuing the death penalty would lead to prolonged appeals, forcing their family to repeatedly relive the trauma. Instead, they advocate for a sentence of life imprisonment without parole or appeal, emphasizing the need to move forward and heal.

A Boeing 747 jumbo jet has been converted into a luxurious private home for an unnamed billionaire, costing approximately £400 million and taking three years to customize. Originally designed to carry up to 600 passengers, this jet now accommodates just one owner and several dozen guests. It features multiple lounges, a master bedroom, guest sleeping areas, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a conference room, and spaces for relaxation and work. The interior resembles a high-end hotel, far surpassing typical first-class airline accommodations.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station (ISS). While the Dragon successfully headed toward the ISS, SpaceX's attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge failed, as it landed too hard and tipped over. This was SpaceX's second unsuccessful attempt at landing a rocket stage at sea, part of their broader goal to reuse rockets and significantly reduce space travel costs. The Dragon spacecraft carried over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker, to the ISS. After about five weeks, Dragon will return to Earth carrying over 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS and the second launch attempt for this particular mission, after weather delayed the initial attempt.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding held at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. She collaborated with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win an "ultimate wedding," including a free reception, hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. The chapel, located at the Westgate Hotel—formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed extensively—is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Presley emphasized the chapel's seriousness, explicitly stating no Elvis impersonators would be involved. Contestants must submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve the prize, with the winning couple announced next Monday and married on April 23.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League standings after regaining winning form with a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet each made their 47th appearance of the season, equalling the highest number of appearances in Europe's top five leagues. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring early, and Joe Allen secured the win with his first Anfield goal. Allen acknowledged Newcastle had a strong penalty claim denied. Liverpool now sit four points behind Manchester City, who recently lost to Manchester United, and Henderson remains optimistic about their chances of overtaking City by season's end.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli 1-0 in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the decisive goal in the 25th minute following a swift counter-attack, while goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves to preserve the victory. Roma, who were without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, moved four points clear of city rivals Lazio in second place. Napoli's winless run extended to five matches, leaving them fifth in the standings. Security was heightened due to previous fan violence, but no incidents were reported.

Doncaster Rovers experienced a disappointing and uneventful League One season, stuck in mid-table mediocrity. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town ended in a dull 0-0 draw, offering minimal highlights. The club's media team humorously produced a brief 27-second highlight video, containing only 14 seconds of actual match footage, featuring just the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

The passage describes a unique interaction between a man named Roland Giroux and his pet blood parrot cichlid. Unlike typical marine pets, this fish enjoys physical interaction, allowing Giroux to stroke and massage it by hand. The fish repeatedly returns to Giroux's hand, appearing relaxed and enjoying the touch. Giroux began interacting closely with the fish after removing two other fish that were bullying it, and he now spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with and massaging it. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid species first bred in Taiwan around 1986, has become notably sociable and attached to its owner.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery temperament, has returned to the England cricket team after a challenging year, including an incident where he broke his wrist punching a locker. His aggressive character, highlighted by clashes such as the one with Marlon Samuels, is seen positively as long as it remains controlled and productive. England coach Peter Moores has guided Stokes on managing his aggression effectively. England values Stokes' natural exuberance and wants him to develop fully, balancing his fiery nature with consistent performance in runs and wickets. The team aims to regularly include Stokes and teammate Chris Jordan, viewing their growth as exciting prospects for the future.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out its 33,000 tickets. Both teams currently lead Group B with 11 points each, though Belgium holds first place due to superior goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has significantly boosted their chances of qualifying for their first major tournament since the 1958 World Cup, generating high fan interest. Despite speculation about moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules and player preference for the smaller Cardiff City Stadium prevented this change.

England coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. As defending champions, England qualified with a perfect record and will face Italy, Holland, and the Republic of Ireland in Group D, starting against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from Premier League clubs such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (both receiving their first call-ups), and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who return after missing previous qualifiers.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the club's top youth talents. Patoulidis previously rejected a move to Barcelona at age 12 to focus on his studies, but has continued to attract attention from clubs including Arsenal and Barcelona. Manchester City have already held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock regarding a compensation package, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to build for the future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort originally from Mexico, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, southwest London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man has been arrested and bailed in connection with her death, pending further questioning. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death. Santillan, who worked internationally as an escort, had recently expressed her affection for London online. Authorities have not confirmed whether her profession is central to the investigation but have pledged to thoroughly investigate the case.

Dawn, a woman who suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show accusing her friend and housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, of stealing £207 she had saved towards a £500 gravestone for her deceased baby, Daniel James. After initially denying the theft, Jamie was exposed by a lie detector test and a Facebook message confession, causing Dawn to become deeply distressed and betrayed. Dawn expressed her devastation, emphasizing the emotional significance of the gravestone as a final gesture of love for her child.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women, children, elderly, and ill individuals, who had been captured during the group's takeover of northern Iraqi towns the previous summer. Kurdish officials reported differing numbers (217-228) and indicated that Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, though the exact motivation remains unclear. Yazidis, a minority religious group of Kurdish descent, have faced severe persecution from ISIS, including mass killings, displacement, rape, and enslavement. The ISIS attack on Sinjar triggered a humanitarian crisis, prompting international aid, rescue operations, and coalition airstrikes. Yazidis number around 500,000 in northern Iraq, less than 1% of the country's population.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker who has had a remarkable season breaking into both his club's first team and England's national side, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animated video by Copa90 highlights Kane's best goals and celebrations, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a header against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The animation, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher has expressed support for Brendan Rodgers to continue as Liverpool manager despite a disappointing season without trophies and likely missing Champions League qualification. Carragher believes Rodgers should not be judged solely on recent results, highlighting difficulties integrating new players and emphasizing the importance of making the right signings for future improvement. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work through his 23 Foundation, also spoke about his commitment to helping disadvantaged youth in Merseyside, inspired by his own upbringing in Bootle.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport, who deemed it a security risk. The boy was frisked and his toy, which fires sponge darts, was taken after being detected by X-ray. His father criticized the security measures as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous." The airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their actions, citing government regulations prohibiting items resembling real weapons. After returning from their holiday in Lanzarote, James received a replacement toy gun.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He lists detailed requirements for his ideal partner, including being fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good at cooking, handy around the house, and great in bed. He prefers a non-smoker and non-drinker, though he acknowledges this may be unrealistic. Rich describes himself as athletic, tattooed, financially successful, independent, and someone who enjoys outdoor activities. He promises various benefits to the successful candidate, including accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, gym membership, and financial generosity. He explicitly states that former partners should not apply. Attempts by Daily Mail Australia to contact him were unsuccessful.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is proposing significant changes to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in Premier League club squads from eight to twelve, and redefine 'home-grown' as players trained in England for three years before age 18 rather than 21. Despite opposition from the Premier League, Dyke's proposals have received strong backing from five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—who warn that rejecting these changes could further harm English football and reduce chances of international success. They highlight the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level, noting only 36.8% of recent Premier League starters were eligible for England. While acknowledging promising young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, the former managers stress that these talents need more opportunities to succeed.

In the latest episode of "Poldark," Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, quickly transitions from barely showing pregnancy to giving birth to a daughter, causing viewers to question the show's accelerated timeline. Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, clearly expresses affection for Demelza, despite initially marrying her out of duty. Fans humorously noted the unrealistic speed of pregnancies depicted in the series, referencing a similar rapid pregnancy involving another character, Elizabeth.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to remain calm and focused on their own performances rather than worrying about their relegation rivals. Despite recent back-to-back wins, including a crucial 3-2 victory against West Bromwich Albion, Leicester remain bottom of the Premier League table, three points from safety. Pearson emphasized that their survival is in their own hands and warned against becoming overly optimistic or distracted by other teams' results.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration ever documented, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific Ocean to Baja, Mexico. This surpasses the previous record held by a humpback whale. Scientists from Oregon State University, who tracked Varvara, noted her journey included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may actually belong to the eastern rather than the endangered western gray whale population. This finding could indicate that the already small population of western gray whales, estimated at around 150, might be even smaller, prompting scientists to reconsider genetic distinctions between the two groups.

Overnight, a stretch of seabed measuring approximately 1,000-1,640 feet long, 100 feet wide, and rising 30-50 feet above sea level emerged unexpectedly along the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, on Japan's Hokkaido Island. Geologists attribute this sudden appearance to a nearby landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, causing underwater land to pivot upward. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds indicating the event, and authorities do not expect further expansion. The event is not believed to be related to recent earthquakes elsewhere. Marine organisms remain attached to the newly exposed landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain, despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match. Van der Wiel emphasized his happiness at PSG, expressing love for the club, city, and teammates, and stated his desire to sign a new contract. However, with PSG linked to Barcelona's Dani Alves, Van der Wiel's future at the club remains uncertain.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus this summer, despite his contract running until 2016, to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Boca Juniors' president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to finalizing the deal but emphasized Tevez must first terminate his Juventus contract. Juventus, although reluctant to lose their top scorer, have accepted Tevez's decision and begun seeking replacements. Argentina's national team manager Tata Martino stated that Tevez's potential move would not affect his international career, emphasizing that both Juventus and Boca Juniors are great clubs.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 in a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, overturning a previous 3-1 deficit to advance to the semi-finals. Goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. During the excitement of the match, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola accidentally ripped his trousers, exposing his underwear. Guardiola humorously remarked afterward that he would need new trousers for the next match.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a three-vehicle collision on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, Brisbane. Four individuals, including two children, were airlifted to hospitals with injuries ranging from chest and shoulder injuries to abdominal pain. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or assessment. Emergency crews used hydraulic equipment to free one trapped person. The highway was temporarily closed with diversions in place.

This weekend, second-placed Arsenal will host Premier League leaders Chelsea in a crucial match. Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil expressed excitement ahead of the game, showcasing his new Apple Watch on Instagram and comparing it to Michael Knight's gadget from the TV show Knight Rider. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to start the match. Arsenal currently trail Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining. Meanwhile, Arsenal have been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who recently returned from a five-month injury absence. Club legend Ray Parlour praised Wilshere's talent and potential, but highlighted concerns over his injury record as the main obstacle to fulfilling his potential.

Referee Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. Clattenburg has previously sent off three players from these teams this season, including City's captain Vincent Kompany during an international match and two United players, Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw, in Premier League games. Despite past accusations of favouring United, both of his Premier League red cards this season have been against United players. Clattenburg, considered one of the Premier League's top referees, will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official. The upcoming derby is crucial, as United recently moved ahead of City in the league standings, with United in strong form and City struggling since the start of the year.

MP Bob Katter has sparked controversy by accusing the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string," after Gordon was accused of domestic violence and admitted to withholding his criminal past. Gordon recently resigned from the Queensland Labor Party but remains in parliament as an independent, causing political instability. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, defended his controversial statement, citing personal experiences with racism and claiming he deliberately used provocative language to highlight racial attitudes. His comments have drawn criticism on social media for their racial terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois born with cerebral palsy, is challenging stereotypes and negative perceptions about disabilities through dancing videos. Despite facing bullying and judgment, Dayna emphasizes that she is just like everyone else, capable of doing everyday activities such as driving, attending college, and dancing. Her videos aim to inspire others, encourage positivity, and prompt people to reconsider their assumptions about disabilities. Additionally, Dayna has begun motivational speaking at local schools to further spread her message.

Orlando City, an MLS club coached by Adrian Heath, have expressed interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez would appeal commercially to Orlando's large Latin-American fanbase, joining captain Kaka, but faces competition from eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United are willing to sell Hernandez for around £8 million. Meanwhile, United have offered a revised contract to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who previously rejected their initial offer and has attracted interest from PSG, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

At least three suspects set a car on fire at a gas station in South Los Angeles early Saturday morning after an argument and attempted carjacking. The driver was pumping gas when the suspects approached, demanded his car at gunpoint, and then sprayed gasoline on his white Dodge Charger, igniting it while two passengers were still inside. No one was injured, but the vehicle was severely damaged. Authorities are investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance footage is being reviewed as part of the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his state license after admitting to charges of accepting sex as payment for chiropractic services and performing exorcisms on patients. He agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must demonstrate that the circumstances leading to revocation no longer exist before resuming practice. Despite these serious charges, Manuel received excellent patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, earning a perfect five-star rating from three patient reviews. His listed practice address appears to be a residential home, and individuals contacted at his home and former practice declined to comment.

A Russian fighter jet intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an incident described by the U.S. as "unsafe and unprofessional." The Pentagon stated the Russian SU-27 performed aggressive maneuvers close to the U.S. RC-135U aircraft in international airspace north of Poland. Russia claimed the U.S. plane approached its border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denied. The U.S. plans to file a diplomatic complaint with Russia. Similar incidents have occurred previously, including a dangerous encounter a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his vehicle parked at a Marriott Springhill Suites hotel in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama's scheduled visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a locked case attached to the vehicle, was forcibly removed by breaking the car's window and using another vehicle to pull it free. Additional items including gear, clothing, and tools were also stolen, though some were later recovered nearby. The rifle remains missing, and authorities have entered its serial number into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was informed of the theft prior to Obama's visit, but it is unclear if security measures were increased as a result. The hotel lacked surveillance cameras, and police have not determined if the theft specifically targeted the agent's vehicle.

In July 2012, Luigi Costa, aged 71, allegedly murdered his elderly neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra. Costa, who reportedly suffered from dementia and alcohol abuse, is accused of violently attacking Freebody by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa's mental state was significantly compromised by dementia and alcohol, causing confusion and fluctuating moods during the incident. Prosecutors questioned whether Costa was feigning memory loss, but Professor Mullen rejected this suggestion, asserting Costa likely had dementia for an extended period before the attack. Costa's mental condition is crucial to the case, as the jury could find him not guilty if his unstable mindset at the time is proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty, despite Barkley missing the spot-kick in Everton's 1-0 victory over Burnley. Barkley took the penalty instead of regular taker Leighton Baines, who has an excellent penalty record. Martinez supported Barkley's choice, stating he encourages multiple players to step up depending on their confidence at the moment. Although Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, Everton still secured the win through a goal from Kevin Mirallas. The incident recalled a previous penalty controversy involving Kevin Mirallas and Baines earlier in the season.

Two passengers were found dead aboard the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide, according to Holland America Line. The bodies were discovered in their stateroom by cleaning staff, and authorities, including the FBI, are investigating the incident. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at the time of discovery.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert successfully began his tenure as coach of Curacao by guiding the Caribbean island team into the second round of CONCACAF qualifying for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced after drawing 2-2 against Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Substitute Charlton Vicento scored a decisive late goal in the second leg. Curacao will now face Cuba in the next qualifying round. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, previously reached World Cup semi-finals as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated footballer who previously won major European trophies with Inter Milan and Real Madrid, considers helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League as significant as winning another trophy. Leicester, currently bottom of the league and seven points from safety with eight games left, face a challenging task. Cambiasso remains optimistic, believing the team can still survive. Having joined Leicester on a one-year deal after a successful decade at Inter Milan, Cambiasso has become a key player and is open to staying longer, expressing satisfaction with his life in the East Midlands.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two young children, risks being banned from seeing her children by her own mother, Debbie, who currently cares for them. Gemma handed both children over to Debbie at four months old and continues to prioritize drinking, partying, and drug use over motherhood. Debbie stepped in after social services threatened to remove the children, and now suspects Gemma of stealing, including an iPad belonging to one of the children. Gemma denies stealing the iPad but admits to previous thefts from her mother. Debbie, frustrated and upset, is considering banning Gemma from her home and from seeing the children, as she believes Gemma is irresponsible, untrustworthy, and unwilling to change her lifestyle.

Chelsea forward Eden Hazard scored the opening goal against Manchester United after a controversial incident involving Chelsea captain John Terry. Terry's strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao caused Falcao to lose the ball, which was then picked up by Cesc Fabregas, leading directly to Hazard's goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness unanimously agreed during their analysis that Terry's tackle was a foul and play should have been stopped. Souness described it as a "forearm smash," Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao, and Redknapp acknowledged that although Falcao could have been stronger, the challenge was still a foul.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway after a rear tire blew out, but everyone onboard—including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and driver—was safely evacuated. The fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except Scott's Bible. Band members Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus. The incident occurred shortly before the band's scheduled performance at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing space-based lasers designed to convert sunlight into energy, potentially providing power to homes by directing laser beams onto solar panels. These lasers, unlike those depicted in science fiction, would not be powerful enough to cause harm. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and further testing is planned in Portugal. Separately, researchers in Tokyo have proposed using lasers on the International Space Station to clear small pieces of space debris. Although neither laser system is intended as a weapon, Dr Quarterman acknowledges concerns about who controls such technology.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a known obsession with young girls, has escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after being convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl and admitting to possessing indecent images of children. Munden, who suffers from autism and mild learning difficulties, was last seen leaving the hospital and may have shaved off his beard to alter his appearance. Police have launched an urgent manhunt and appealed for public assistance in locating him.

Donald Sterling, former owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, lost his NBA team after racist remarks surfaced in an audio recording involving his companion, V. Stiviano. Subsequently, Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, sued Stiviano to recover over $2.6 million in gifts—including luxury cars and property—claiming Stiviano targeted wealthy older men. A Los Angeles judge ruled in Shelly Sterling's favor, ordering Stiviano to repay the money. The decision was hailed as a victory for the Sterling family and set a legal precedent allowing spouses to reclaim gifts given to extramarital partners.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer activity, stating they must sign four key players—a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker—to have a realistic chance of winning the Premier League. Henry specifically questioned Olivier Giroud's ability to lead Arsenal to the title, despite acknowledging Giroud's good performances and 14 league goals. He cited Chelsea's successful signings of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as examples Arsenal should follow to strengthen their squad and compete effectively.

Maurice Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman and Bega Cheese boss, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. One of his victims, a young woman, described to Sydney's District Court the severe and lasting impact of his abuse, including depression, self-harm, attempted suicide, and fear for her future relationships. She kept silent for years, unaware as a child that the abuse was wrong, and only spoke out after learning Van Ryn had been caught. The hearing is ongoing.

Arsenal midfielder Serge Gnabry, aged 19, is nearing a return to first-team action after being sidelined for over a year due to a serious knee injury sustained in March 2014. Gnabry recently completed his second full 90-minute match for Arsenal's Under-21 team against Reading, and stated he is feeling increasingly better and has overcome his injury concerns.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling down a 70-foot cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while running away from a taxi driver to avoid paying the fare. Phillips and two friends had taken a taxi home after a night out but lacked sufficient money, prompting them to flee without paying. Phillips became disoriented in the dark, jumped over a fence, and unknowingly fell off the cliff. His body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker. The coroner ruled the death accidental, noting Phillips likely had no awareness of the danger due to darkness and disorientation.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay crisis have received little or no compensation, despite the Passport Office making a £42 million profit during the period. Managers at the agency received bonuses of up to £3,500, while ministers rejected calls for blanket refunds, arguing it would set a precedent. Although more than half a million passports were delayed, only 2,191 compensation claims were approved, averaging just £92.68 per claim. Many travelers who paid extra fees or missed trips received nothing, and the Passport Office admitted it could not track how many claims were rejected due to a system failure.

A semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, untouched since the 1930s, is up for auction with a guide price between £200,000 and £250,000. The property retains original features such as stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hallway, original kitchen cupboards, and vintage food tins. Although externally unimposing, the interior is considered a collector's paradise. Despite some modern upgrades like double glazing, auctioneers suggest renovation costs might deter developers, but the home could appeal to antique enthusiasts or families. The auction is scheduled for April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup quarterback for Alex Smith on the 49ers, becoming the starter mid-2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent her early life there before relocating to Texas and later San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) in Secaucus to NY 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal's division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn grew up in Leytonstone, East London, and near Colchester, Essex. He attended Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur, whose debut album "Leisure" (1991) received mixed reviews. Blur's self-titled album in 2001 achieved worldwide success, drawing from genres such as alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop. Albarn released his first solo album, "Everyday Robots," in 2014, co-produced by Richard Russell and featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia, hosting many significant national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut EP, "Broken," released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter nominated for a BAFTA award.

The 2007 film "Shooter" features Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger (Mark Wahlberg), who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The TV series "Shooter" stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action upon discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama television series that aired on Fox for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for orchestrating the killings of seven people, notably actress Sharon Tate, carried out by his followers. He also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After being charged, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were commercially released.

Sean Justin Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career on television in 1974 and made his film debut in 1981 with "Taps." Penn gained critical attention in the 1980s and early 1990s through films such as "Fast Times at Ridgemont High," "At Close Range," "State of Grace," and "Carlito's Way." He became a prominent leading actor with "Dead Man Walking" (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination. Penn later received Oscar nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and "I Am Sam" (2001), and won Academy Awards for Best Actor for "Mystic River" (2003) and "Milk" (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman ever. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held prominent leadership roles in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a division of Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He began his career with the band Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 alongside Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, Wilk plays in the band Prophets of Rage, which includes Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. The passage also mentions a separate German heavy metal band named Rage, formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

"The Millers" was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, producing 34 episodes across two seasons. CBS announced its cancellation on November 14, 2014, after airing four episodes of the second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was an American politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national prominence as Texas state treasurer after delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards, known for her outspoken feminism and sharp wit, was the second female governor of Texas and lost her re-election bid in 1994 to George W. Bush. The passage also briefly mentions another Ann Richards (1935–1982), an American jazz singer married to pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released an EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film directed by Stephen Verona and co-written by Verona and Leigh Chapman. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader instrumental in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent nations free from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean, known for mysterious disappearances of aircraft and ships.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers but became the starter mid-2012 after Alex Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In 2013, his first full season as starter, he guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
*Marnie* is a 1964 American psychological thriller directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual marketing communication that uses openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, advertising targets a general audience rather than specific individuals. It is delivered through mass media channels, including traditional media like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as newer media such as search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward, and also a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice. He studied at Plato's Academy in Athens from around age seventeen or eighteen until age thirty-seven. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and became the tutor of Alexander the Great in 343 BC, at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer who later became a musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and currently serves as CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning five NBA championships and earning the NBA Finals MVP award in his rookie season. Initially drafted first overall in 1979, he briefly retired due to player protests but returned in 1996 before retiring permanently. Beyond basketball, Johnson became a successful businessman, recognized by Ebony magazine in 2009 as one of America's most influential black businessmen, and was also a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). The band gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I (1566–1625), also known as James Stuart, ruled Scotland as James VI from 1567 and became King of England and Ireland as James I in 1603, uniting the crowns in personal union until his death. Although he strongly advocated for a single parliament for both kingdoms, he succeeded mostly in Scotland but encountered significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality TV show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born on 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist, best known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since its start in 2000. Bentley previously provided continuity announcements for Channel 4 until July 2011, after which he continued narrating Big Brother on Channel 5. His distinctive Geordie accent has made him one of Britain's most recognised voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering the German states of Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, and Bavaria, as well as Poland and the Czech Republic. It is Germany's tenth largest state by area (18,413 km²) and sixth most populous, with around 4 million inhabitants. Saxony has a history spanning over a thousand years and is known as one of Germany's northernmost wine-producing regions, alongside Saale-Unstrut, both located in former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park situated in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood. "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with supporting roles by Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar. Sophia Anna Bush, born July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist, known for her roles in films such as "John Tucker Must Die" (2006), "The Hitcher" (2007), and "The Narrows" (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. His younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch, is an Australian, British, and American businessman who serves as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc. Rupert Murdoch previously had full control as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, which split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013, and is now the world's second-largest media conglomerate.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was ranked as Israel's second highest earning actress/model, behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with most of her income derived from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, also known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually identified through radiographic examination, commonly known as an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield, known in Welsh as Maes glo De Cymru, is a large coal-rich region in south Wales, particularly notable in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football club competition organized by CONCACAF for leading clubs from North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was initially called the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when first established in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 after her husband George's death, when her eldest son Edward ascended the throne but soon abdicated to marry Wallis Simpson. She supported her second son, Albert (George VI), until his death in 1952, and died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
Poseidon is a film that earned $181,674,817 globally against a production budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton share the record for most wins, each having won three times.

Human trafficking involves trading humans primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), forced labor alone generates approximately $150 billion annually as of 2014. Among trafficking victims, 68% (14.2 million) were exploited for labor, 22% (4.5 million) for sexual exploitation, and 10% (2.2 million) in state-imposed forced labor.
The film "Rio" (2011) had a sequel titled "Rio 2," released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I refers to two historical figures. The first, Francis I (Franz Stefan, François Étienne, 1708–1765), was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though real power was effectively exercised by his wife. The second, Francis I (François Ier, 1494–1547), was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death. Known as François au Grand Nez ("Francis of the Large Nose"), Grand Colas, and Roi-Chevalier ("Knight-King"), he notably engaged in wars against his rival, Holy Roman Emperor Charles V. After unsuccessful military efforts, he controversially allied with the Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian war of 1536–1538 was a conflict between Francis I of France and Charles V.

Peking University (PKU), also known as Beida, is a prominent Chinese research university located in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Imperial Academy (Taixue or Guozijian) and initially served as China's highest educational administration. It is consistently ranked as the top university in mainland China.
Lemmy was recognized for his distinctive appearance, including friendly mutton chops, his gravelly voice, and unique bass playing style.
Global warming poses significant threats to humans, including reduced food security from declining crop yields and displacement of populations caused by rising sea levels.
Australia is a 2008 epic historical romantic drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann, starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. It is an Australian-American-British production.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, mainly for the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.
Canadian folklore encompasses various oral traditions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and traditional practices like food-making and craft-making.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films known for being both informative and entertaining, and also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones, the author, won the 1952 National Book Award for his first novel "From Here to Eternity," which was adapted into a film and later a television series.
