James Jones, the basketball player, averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He won three NBA championships—two with the Miami Heat and one with the Cleveland Cavaliers—and reached the NBA Finals seven consecutive times alongside teammate LeBron James. He finished third in NBA three-point percentage in the 2007–08 season and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, Humphrey Bogart was ranked by the American Film Institute as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation involves generating animated images. An example is "Trollhunters," an American computer-animated fantasy TV series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, effective January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for portraying the fourth incarnation of the Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, holding the longest tenure of any actor in the role. He also narrated the comedy series Little Britain and has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

Hanford Site hosts a cleanup project, a commercial nuclear power plant called the Columbia Generating Station, and scientific research facilities including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the executive branch, particularly representing the President, senior executives, and policies. Appointed directly by the President without Senate approval, the Press Secretary regularly briefs the media, making this role a prominent non-Cabinet position.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State" due to the bluegrass in its fertile pastures, features the central Bluegrass Region, home to major cities Louisville and Lexington. The state is famous for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film featuring actors Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also appeared in the films The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, previously stylized as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, electronic and urban versions of "Despacito" were released, produced respectively by American trio Major Lazer with Colombian DJ MOSKA, and by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view. It was organized by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). In 1987, Starrcade became the first NWA event broadcast on pay-per-view, after WWF scheduled their own pay-per-view event, Survivor Series, demanding exclusivity from cable providers. In 2014, WWE Network included all previous Starrcade events, rating them TV-MA due to violent content, notably the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. Starrcade (1997) marked the fifteenth annual event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer, as well as a film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series created specifically for a particular service and the first Star Trek series released since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played football professionally as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also competed in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

"Excuse My French" refers to two distinct works: the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana, and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on his personal experiences. Additionally, Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop artist, actor, film director, and producer.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or disk, is a storage medium consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic disk enclosed in a rectangular plastic casing lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

From the mid to late 19th century, Guatemala faced chronic instability and civil unrest. Between 1960 and 1996, the country experienced a violent civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military committed genocidal massacres against the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used to grasp and hold objects. In non-medical contexts, they are commonly called tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The series "The Closer" began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after concluding its sixth season as cable's highest rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the protagonist of the ABC television drama series "Lost," which aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes. The show's first season averaged approximately 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey, born November 4, 1969, is an American actor who, since 2011, has favored dramatic roles. Notable films include "The Lincoln Lawyer," "Bernie," "Killer Joe," "The Paperboy," "Mud," "Magic Mike," "The Wolf of Wall Street," "Dallas Buyers Club," "Interstellar," "The Sea of Trees," and "Free State of Jones." The 2012 film "Mud" starred McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was known primarily as a writer, recognized for his books such as "Deep Blues," his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine, his production work on blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film "Deep Blues," and his clarinet playing with the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912 – January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer, best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, who originally designed and led the project from 1927 until his death in 1941.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, and features voice acting by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The TV series "The 100" follows a group of teenagers—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first people sent from a space habitat called "The Ark" back to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also centers on adult characters from the Ark, including Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke's mother), Marcus Kane (a council member), and Thelonious Jaha (the Ark's Chancellor and Wells' father).

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite facing financial issues due to its pioneering nature, is recognized as a successful and influential humanitarian aid project. It raised awareness, generated significant funds, and provided valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent initiatives, notably Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized by media as one of India's influential filmmakers, credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and significantly impacting Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of seven Lincoln-Douglas debates held on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. These debates featured Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate, and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas, and attracted large crowds, especially in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, due to the national significance of the slavery issue.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone alongside actors Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her professional writing career with the publication of "Interview with the Vampire" in 1976 and wrote sequels starting in the 1980s. Initially receiving mixed reactions, her popularity grew significantly during the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death in 2002.

Camden is a city located in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 U.S. Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. In the early 20th century, Camden's population was primarily composed of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the critically derided 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film "The Canyons," directed by Paul Schrader.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, also called The Great Debates of 1858, consisted of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas, held across seven towns in Illinois.

Homer is the name given by ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems central to ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle was a U.S. Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band consisting of Soundgarden's Chris Cornell (lead singer/rhythm guitarist) and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). Brad Wilk previously played drums for Greta in 1990, co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 with Morello and Zack de la Rocha, and later joined Audioslave (2001–2007). As of 2016, Wilk was playing with Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, included Zack de la Rocha (vocals), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), Tom Morello (guitar), and Brad Wilk (drums).

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, "The ArchAndroid," a concept album sequel to her first EP, through Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin, published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town located in northeastern Louisiana and serves as the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. The University of Mississippi has approximately 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent of its total student body from Mississippi, with minorities comprising 23 percent and international students representing 90 nations.
In July 2016, the series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served twice in the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), was appointed New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), served as a U.S. senator from New York (1791–1797), and reached the peak of his political career as vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, initially conducting 8 unmanned test flights followed by 19 manned launches. The Soyuz spacecraft, designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s, succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally intended for Soviet manned lunar missions. It remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

In 2000, tensions within Rage Against the Machine led vocalist de la Rocha to leave, causing the band's breakup. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. Their fourth studio album, "Renegades," was released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 financially strong companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors, listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, is one of the constituents of the SENSEX index and is also listed on India's National Stock Exchange and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially known as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is located on the easternmost part of the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It has approximately 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country. Vietnam borders China, Laos, Cambodia, and is near Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced rapid economic growth, ranking highly among global economies. It remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is an American sports drama film from 2005, written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.
Bhagat Singh was an Indian socialist revolutionary whose two dramatic acts of violence against British rule and execution at age 23 made him a celebrated folk hero in India's independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan.

James VI and I (James Stuart, 1566–1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 1567 and became King of England and Ireland as James I in 1603, uniting the crowns in personal union until his death. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with individual parliaments and laws, James strongly advocated for a single parliament. His reign in England was marked by significant difficulties with Parliament.

Danielle Cormack, born on 26 December 1970, is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in stage and screen productions. She was part of the original cast of the soap opera Shortland Street and is recognized for roles such as Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her other notable works include the film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and portraying Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Her most prominent recent role was as Bea Smith in the prison drama Wentworth, which she starred in for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, primarily recognized for his extensive collaboration with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred or co-starred in films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, released in 2015, is an American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and co-written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but achieved commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies. It was Lady Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the US, eventually selling 757,000 copies domestically and becoming the ninth best-selling album of 2013 globally with 2.3 million copies sold.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, titled "Stadium Arcadium." This album was also the band's last to feature Frusciante, who confirmed his departure in 2009.
Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, introduced policies known as Thatcherism. Although controversial and still debated, she is praised as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Besides his musical career, he has also written weekly columns on diverse topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, besides acting roles, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants. It also has Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
"Make It or Break It" concluded with its third and final season, as announced on April 26, 2012, and aired its series finale on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methods and technologies enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It integrates knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice dialing, call routing, home appliance control, search functions, data entry, structured document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft voice input. Recent advancements are marked by increased academic research and widespread industry adoption of deep learning techniques, with major companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC publicly acknowledging deep learning as the core technology behind their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 – January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman starting in 1970. Originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, the event was founded in 1970 by Alf along with Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and later became known as the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
"Fist of Legend" is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," which originally starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl share the lead at 16 under par, closely followed by Rory McIlroy and Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat at 15 under. McIlroy, who shot his third consecutive 67, recovered from early setbacks with an eagle on the 12th hole. He is aiming for his first title since May and believes he can achieve a lower round. McIlroy previously missed tournaments due to an ankle injury sustained in July but returned in August. He currently leads Danny Willett in the Race to Dubai standings, with three events remaining. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland, previously tied for second, are now fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the need for meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, urging the government to offer concrete solutions and involve representatives who can speak for the royal family. He highlighted divisions within the ruling family, contrasting reformists like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who favors dialogue and accommodation with the Shia majority, with hardliners led by Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, who oppose concessions. Sheikh Salman recalled a previous agreement with the crown prince on a seven-point reform plan that was disrupted by the arrival of Gulf Cooperation Council troops in 2011. He expressed hope that the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, would take a stronger stance on human rights and democracy than his predecessor, Hillary Clinton, and criticized the UK's private diplomatic approach, urging public pressure instead. Sheikh Salman reaffirmed al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations despite government bans, and called for the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and activists, stressing their importance to the success of any dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it globally for around 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, notably the first complete Mozart symphonies cycle on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London. He also served as artistic director for festivals and societies, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. Colleagues praised his generosity, intellect, and significant legacy in historically informed music performance.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest annual figure since 1976. Sharp instruments, particularly knives, remained the most common method, accounting for 51% of cases. Alcohol or drugs were involved in at least 31% of cases. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the decline but emphasized the need for continued efforts in education, enforcement, and community support to further reduce violence. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker urged caution, noting previous revisions of homicide figures upwards and highlighting increases in sexual crimes and violent offenses such as attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first team defeated by Sunderland in the Premier League this season. Despite Dan Gosling giving Bournemouth an early lead—ending a three-game goal drought—the team failed to capitalize on numerous scoring opportunities, even after Sunderland went down to 10 men following Steven Pienaar's dismissal. Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration at the missed chances, emphasizing the importance of moving forward positively.

Australia's former Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended his country's controversial policy of detaining migrants arriving by boat and resettling them offshore, arguing it prevents deaths at sea. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and possibly illegal, urging European leaders not to adopt similar measures. Abbott also sparked controversy by comparing Islamic State (IS) militants to Nazis, suggesting IS was worse because they openly boast about their atrocities. Australian Jewish groups strongly criticized this comparison, emphasizing the fundamental difference between IS terrorism and the systematic genocide committed by the Nazis. Abbott later stood by his comments but clarified he was not attempting to rank evil.

The passage describes escalating tensions between the US and Russia over the conflict in Syria, particularly regarding intensified attacks on civilians in Aleppo. The US blamed Russia and the Syrian government for increased bombings, including strikes on hospitals and humanitarian aid convoys, and suspended bilateral talks with Russia aimed at maintaining a ceasefire. Russia denied responsibility, accused the US of failing to fulfill its commitments, and criticized Washington for shifting blame. Despite suspending cooperation on ceasefire arrangements, both sides agreed to continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations to avoid unintended clashes.

The passage discusses a proposal by the think tank Policy Exchange, supported by Downing Street, to sell high-value social housing when it becomes vacant. This policy could raise approximately £4.5 billion annually, funding the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes per year and potentially reducing the social housing waiting list by around 500,000 people. Policy Exchange argues this would be the largest social housing programme since the 1970s and would boost the economy. However, critics, including Labour and the National Housing Federation, argue that this approach would drive lower-income families out of affluent areas, creating segregated communities. Labour suggests alternative funding methods, such as a bank bonus tax, to build affordable homes. The government emphasizes councils already have the power to sell high-value properties and encourages efficient use of housing stock, while highlighting its own affordable housing initiatives.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, aged 25, died recently at his home in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 reported cases. Although laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, it remains unclear if measles was the primary cause of his death, and further tests are pending. Colfer-Williams had recently been hospitalized for asthma and developed a rash shortly after discharge. His family is uncertain how he contracted measles, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the disease. An inquest will be opened and adjourned to allow additional investigations.

Vincent Hudson, aged 54, from Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16, reportedly occurring in 2001. He is scheduled to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in their National League match. Guiseley took an early lead through Jake Lawlor's goal in the 15th minute. Gateshead equalized in the second half with a goal from Wes York in the 62nd minute. Gateshead extended their unbeaten run to nine matches, while Guiseley remained unbeaten in five.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase stadium capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has faced delays. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the redevelopment, approved by Bristol City Council, will proceed if no judicial review occurs by March, with construction starting in May.

Cuadrilla Resources has suspended shale gas drilling ("fracking") operations in Lancashire after a second earthquake occurred, measuring magnitude 1.5. The British Geological Survey (BGS) confirmed the tremor was similar in location and mechanism to an earlier 2.3 magnitude quake in April. Cuadrilla will analyze BGS data and consult with authorities before deciding whether to resume operations. Fracking, which involves fracturing underground shale rocks to release gas, has been controversial due to environmental concerns, particularly in the US. However, UK authorities suggest that strict regulation could mitigate these risks. The BGS noted that injecting pressurized fluids underground can trigger earthquakes, and it continues to monitor the situation closely.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud after performing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015. Carpenter, who had previously piped for the charity, claimed he was simply busking and intended the banner as a tribute, not to deceive. Although he had permission to display the banner, he was explicitly told not to use it for fundraising. He was cleared of two other fraud charges and will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers (QPR) 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. QPR goalkeeper Alex Smithies' error led directly to Varney's goal, and Ipswich could have scored more, missing several good chances. QPR struggled offensively, with their best chance being Sandro's header hitting the post. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance and highlighted Smithies' mistake as pivotal, while QPR manager Ian Holloway criticized his team's mental toughness and defensive errors. The result moved Ipswich up to 14th place, dropping QPR to 15th.

Wells, aged 23, performed notably in the previous T20 Blast season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's positive direction and praised the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive victory by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher praised the front row and front five players, particularly Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, for their strong defensive effort. Although satisfied with the team's emotional resilience, Churcher emphasized the need for further improvement and consistency, especially given their upcoming schedule against mostly lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians.

Police arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, accused of raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat, India. Nazrul, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was apprehended at a Kolkata railway station after returning from Bangladesh. The incident sparked widespread outrage and protests across India. Police have identified eight suspects, arresting six so far, with two still at large. Previously arrested suspects named Nazrul as the rapist. The attack involved theft and vandalism at a convent school, culminating in the rape of the nun.

The passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of London's Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, who explains key reasons behind changes in consumer purchasing habits in the UK. Factors such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports influenced consumer preferences and available products. Additionally, the video includes interactive elements examining shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands. Alternative non-interactive resources are provided for browsers unable to support the interactive content.

Two separate incidents occurred involving scammers claiming to be from BT technical support. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was deceived on 15 September. Seven days later, another woman in Stranraer lost money after a caller gained remote access to her computer under the pretense of fixing internet issues. PC Siobhan Pellett warned the public to be cautious of cold calls, emphasizing that legitimate businesses never request banking details or account numbers over the phone.

Duffy, aged 37, has signed a one-year contract as head coach with Featherstone, currently third in the Championship, after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league match against Toulouse and into the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's previous coaching performance at Swinton. Duffy, who previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been replaced at Swinton by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

A rider was found unconscious with head injuries and suffering from cold exposure on Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve. A Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic, and a coastguard helicopter responded at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. After initial treatment, she was airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a radio frequency for satellite-based global flight tracking, addressing weaknesses exposed by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in 2014. The current radar-based system leaves 70% of global airspace uncovered. The new system will use satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, enabling real-time tracking worldwide. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, requiring aircraft to report their positions at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently during emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found at age 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez was arrested and charged with tampering with records and is being held on a $250,000 bail in Ohio. Authorities confirmed Julian's identity after receiving a tip related to issues he encountered applying for college. Julian's mother has been informed of his recovery. Bobby Hernandez was suspected of abducting Julian in 2002 after claiming he was taking him to preschool but instead fleeing.

Firefighters spent several days responding to a fire at a site on Duncan Street on 2 March, causing reduced train services and travel delays. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and decided to revoke its environmental permit effective from 7 August, pending any appeal. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had previously raised concerns about potential impacts of a fire at the site, prompting joint visits with the EA. Although the site's operators, Asset and Land Group, were described as "broadly compliant" with fire safety legislation, the EA still chose to take enforcement action. The cause of the fire remains unknown, and the company must remove all waste from the site.

The passage describes two legislative bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party "A Just Russia," directly linked to the crisis in Ukraine, particularly in Crimea, where pro-Russian sentiment is strong. The first bill would simplify the process for territories to join Russia without requiring a treaty with the neighboring state, provided the territory's population expresses a clear desire to join Russia. The second bill would expedite the issuance of Russian passports to Ukrainians, removing requirements such as previous residence in Russia, financial self-sufficiency, and renunciation of Ukrainian citizenship. This bill explicitly aims to support Russian-speaking Ukrainians, described as vulnerable to a "brown threat," referencing fascism. Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea, highlighting Russia's active involvement in the region.

McLaren, historically one of Formula 1's most successful teams with 182 race wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a significant decline. Their struggles began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and have continued due to problems with their Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team is now aiming merely for decent points rather than victories. McLaren previously enjoyed dominant periods, notably with Honda engines in the late 1980s and Mercedes engines in the late 1990s. However, controversies such as the 2007 Ferrari espionage scandal and the 2009 "lie-gate" incident have marred their reputation. Ron Dennis, who previously led the team to success, returned after the poor 2013 season but has yet to reverse the decline. Dennis remains optimistic, believing McLaren will soon return to championship-winning form, a belief shared by Alonso, who rejoined the team in 2015 hoping for renewed success. Currently, however, optimism and belief are all the team has to rely on.

Thomas Baker, aged 44 from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest on 27 January outside Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool after leaving Phoenix Gym. Three men from Liverpool, two aged 29 and one aged 32, have been arrested and remain in custody. Police believe the attackers waited outside the gym for about an hour and are currently searching for a silver VW Polo seen speeding away from the scene. Detectives have appealed for witnesses captured on CCTV near the market to come forward, as they may hold crucial information.

The passage describes various innovative ways people are using online platforms and digital media to celebrate Christmas spiritually. It highlights Everyday Church Online, which offers virtual church services and sermons themed around Star Wars to convey messages of hope. The fantasy game Guardians of Ancora, developed by Scripture Union, engages children aged 8-11 in Bible-themed quests, including special Christmas content. Viral videos such as "The Digital Story of Nativity" and "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" creatively retell the nativity story through social media formats and modern settings. Additionally, Next Manga has adapted biblical stories into Manga form, distributing millions of copies globally, including to refugees, to spread messages of hope and peace. Finally, the passage notes that churches increasingly use social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook to subtly encourage spiritual reflection during the festive season.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to take over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land for development, with supporters offering around 320 hectares (800 acres) as replacement. Experts disagree on the environmental impact: Natural Resources Wales expressed uncertainty about the replacement land's value but did not oppose the project, while developers claim biodiversity would improve due to habitat enhancements, a point contested by the Gwent wildlife trust. After the inquiry, the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will issue a recommendation, with the final decision resting with Welsh government ministers.

The passage describes a controversy sparked by a report from the Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta, which revealed that over 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of homosexuality, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, stating detainees were tortured. Chechen Muslim clerics condemned the report as an insult to their faith and dignity, warning of "retribution" against those responsible. Novaya Gazeta interpreted this as a threat against journalists and urged Russian authorities to protect them. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming there were no gay people in Chechnya. Novaya Gazeta vowed to continue investigating human rights abuses despite past murders of its journalists linked to Chechnya. The LGBT Network plans to seek international justice if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency founded by Samir Patel, has profited significantly by housing single homeless men over 35, receiving substantial housing benefit payments by placing multiple tenants in single properties. Patel also founded the charity Fresh Start Housing, which refers homeless clients to Investing Solutions and private landlords. Both entities operate from the same building, though Patel insists the charity is independent. While not illegal, this arrangement has drawn criticism from homeless advocacy groups, calling it "a new low." Tenants have reported poor living conditions, including lack of heating, dampness, and infestations. In one example, Investing Solutions received £2,114 monthly in housing benefit for a property, paying only £1,150 to the landlord, generating significant profit. Wandsworth Council alone has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1 million in two years. The council and government emphasize their responsibility to safeguard taxpayer funds and ensure housing standards.

Great Britain lost their final warm-up basketball match against the Netherlands despite leading for most of the first three quarters. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. However, the Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, took control early in the fourth quarter and held on for the win. GB coach Joe Prunty emphasized the importance of consistent effort ahead of their upcoming Eurobasket qualifying campaign, starting with a game in Hungary. Prunty praised Gordon's performance, highlighting his strong third-quarter contribution.

Former five-weight world champion Floyd Mayweather and UFC champion Conor McGregor have requested permission from the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use lighter 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves for their upcoming boxing match at 154 lbs. The NAC will publicly debate this request, emphasizing fighter safety as their primary concern. McGregor, who typically uses 4oz gloves in UFC, welcomed the lighter gloves, while Mayweather initially announced his intention but had not formally submitted the waiver at that time. NAC executive director Bob Bennett justified sanctioning the fight, citing McGregor's boxing ability demonstrated against Nate Diaz, his physical advantages, and Mayweather's age and recent lack of knockouts. Bennett also recommended McGregor's camp hire boxing referee Joe Cortez to familiarize McGregor with boxing rules. The fight has drawn criticism from boxing figures but is expected to be highly lucrative.

Fleet Street, historically the heart of British journalism, has seen its final two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith of the Dundee-based Sunday Post, leave as the paper closes its London office. Fleet Street was once the epicenter of UK newspapers, beginning with the Daily Courant in 1702, and at its peak housed nearly all major national papers. Known for its vibrant, alcohol-fueled journalistic culture, it was also infamous for its pubs and social scene. The street's decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his newspapers to Wapping, prompting other papers to follow suit, adopting cheaper, computerized printing methods. Today, Fleet Street's former newspaper offices have been replaced by businesses like supermarkets and restaurants. Sherriff, who worked there for 32 years, plans to write memoirs, while Smith, after 25 years, will freelance. Both journalists reflect nostalgically on Fleet Street's rich history and their roles as its last representatives.

Author J.K. Rowling faced abusive comments and criticism on Twitter due to her political views, particularly after donating £1m against Scottish independence and previously to the Labour party. She stated her personal boundaries had been crossed and emphasized the importance of standing up to bullies. Rowling revealed she had blocked abusive users, some of whom she believed were SNP supporters, but also noted positive interactions with other SNP supporters. Despite hostility, she humorously responded to threats of book burning. The SNP secured 56 of Scotland's 59 seats, becoming the UK's third largest party.

The study conducted by University of Edinburgh researchers found that poverty significantly increases the likelihood of young people becoming involved in crime and violence. Children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action compared to wealthier peers committing the same crimes, and poorer youths were five times more likely to be placed under statutory supervision. Poverty was identified as a key factor increasing both victimization and perpetration of crime, even after accounting for other risk factors. Gender was also influential, with boys three times more likely than girls to commit violent acts, and poorer girls twice as likely as affluent girls to engage in violence. The research highlighted a destructive cycle where poverty increases violence risk, and contact with juvenile justice systems further exacerbates these risks. Despite overall crime rates in Scotland falling, the most deprived communities continue to experience disproportionately high crime rates, chronic health issues, and unemployment. Researchers emphasized the need to address inequality more effectively, while the Scottish government maintains that Scotland is becoming safer and highlights ongoing initiatives aimed at reducing poverty and inequality.

Mr Haugh, aged 25, was fatally stabbed during a fight in the Marian estate early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until his next court appearance on 14 August. Two other men arrested were released without charge, pending further investigation. Police allege Walsh and two others entered the estate looking for Mr Haugh, leading to a violent altercation involving weapons. Knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene, and Mr Haugh died later in hospital from a stab wound to his back.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted allegations against Tom Elliott, suggesting Elliott had harassed and shot people during his time in the UDR. Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992 and is now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, has a clear MoD record. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and has since apologized, acknowledging the claims were false and without foundation. Elliott expressed satisfaction at being vindicated but disappointment at the lengthy legal process. Compensation is yet to be determined, and Flanagan's insurance provider has refused to cover the costs, prompting a separate legal challenge.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has significantly increased sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 per week due to strong demand. This growth is driven by successful sales of its newly launched own-brand range and continued expansion of its established private-label business. The company, acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November, serves markets across Europe, North America, and Japan. Hartop attributes the firm's positive outlook to increased orders and the dedication of its workforce.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, who failed to stop at a red traffic light, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn, who had been helping pedestrians cross the road, is now receiving residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse in court, stating he had turned Mrs Blackburn's "world upside down." The trial is ongoing.

NATO is conducting an anti-submarine warfare exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," in response to increased Russian submarine activity near European waters. The exercise involves ten NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, helicopters, underwater drones, and a French maritime patrol aircraft, all attempting to detect a German submarine, U33, simulating an enemy threat. Russia has significantly expanded its submarine capabilities, now possessing around 60 advanced submarines, described as the quietest and most challenging adversaries globally. The exercise highlights a critical vulnerability in Britain's defences, specifically its lack of maritime patrol aircraft, forcing reliance on NATO allies for surveillance. Experts warn this gap leaves the UK exposed, particularly to Russian submarines potentially tracking Britain's nuclear deterrent. Addressing this deficiency is expected to be a priority in Britain's upcoming defence review.

South Sudan, the world's youngest country, is facing severe ethnic violence that UN officials warn could escalate into genocide or ethnic cleansing. Since July, violence has spread from Juba to the previously peaceful Equatoria states, causing 340,000 people to flee to Uganda—more than from any other country this year, including Syria. Refugees report widespread killings, rapes, and targeted attacks along ethnic lines, primarily involving the Dinka, Nuer, and Equatorian groups. Uganda, despite its generous refugee policies, is struggling to cope with nearly a million refugees, half of whom are children. Refugees receive land and basic supplies quickly, but resources like water remain challenging. The international community is urged to intervene and pressure South Sudanese leaders to end the violence.

Leon McKenzie, aged 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. A former footballer for Norwich and Peterborough, McKenzie turned professional boxer in 2013, two years after retiring from football, and currently holds a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage describes plans for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital, funded as part of the coalition's £330m investment in NHS facilities across England. The new hospital, costing £33m, will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The existing hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and requires extensive maintenance. Staff emphasize the positive impact a modern facility will have on patient recovery and care quality. Somerset has recently replaced three of its 13 community hospitals, and construction has begun on another facility at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton. The new Bridgwater hospital, planned for completion by autumn 2014, awaits planning permission for a site at Bowers Lane.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre. He was found by police around 13:35 GMT with a gunshot wound to the chest and later died in hospital. Witnesses reported he was near or inside a black Mercedes car he had been driving. Local residents indicated the victim belonged to a family living nearby, who were gathered for a celebration at the time of the shooting. Recent weeks have seen multiple shootings in Sheffield, though previous incidents occurred in other areas of the city, including Shiregreen, Southey Green, and High Green.

The passage describes cyber warfare activities related to the Ukraine-Russia conflict, highlighting three prominent hacker groups: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conduct cyber-attacks such as DDoS attacks, hacking CCTV systems, disrupting rebel funding, and hijacking network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. They have also provided hacked data to Ukrainian security services, though officials deny using it for military targeting. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group supporting pro-Russian positions, hacks Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and election systems, and claims to have obtained sensitive documents related to U.S. military assistance to Ukraine. Anonymous International, also known as Shaltay Boltay, leaks documents primarily from within Russia, including communications involving separatist commanders in Ukraine. The passage emphasizes the significant role cyber warfare plays in the ongoing conflict, with each group claiming independence from official government sponsorship.

The passage describes emotional farewells in the Scottish Parliament as several veteran MSPs, including former First Minister Alex Salmond, Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, and Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie, stepped down ahead of the May 5 election. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during these farewells. Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity rather than division, praised the parliament's growing responsibilities, but criticized the Scotland Bill for not fully meeting referendum pledges. He humorously acknowledged competing events and concluded by highlighting the honor of serving Scotland. McNeil urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny, while Goldie humorously noted she would miss interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, their families, and friends to inform recommendations aimed at care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of highlighting both good practices and the negative impacts of poor care, noting significant variations in care quality across Wales. Her review will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. However, Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, expressed disappointment that the advisory panel lacks representation from individuals with direct experience of managing or working in care homes, viewing this as a missed opportunity for partnership and full sector engagement.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported an increase in pre-tax profit to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million. The company, headquartered in Turriff, manufactures and supplies animal feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors, and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, serving farming and rural communities. International sales grew, particularly in Europe and new markets. Although the agricultural industry faces uncertainty and challenges, particularly due to Brexit, Harbro remains confident in its ability to adapt and succeed.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and another man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are treating the death as murder and urgently seek to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), advising the public not to approach him. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with greying, collar-length hair, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked short-sleeved shirt. Police have increased patrols in the area and are appealing for information from the public.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, warned of weakening global economic conditions, highlighting a "delicate juncture" following disappointing trade data from China, where exports fell sharply by 25% year-on-year. The IMF is expected to lower its current global growth forecast of 3.4% in its upcoming April report, signaling ongoing challenges for businesses reliant on China's economic growth.

The passage describes issues surrounding a newly launched chain ferry at Cowes. Since its delayed launch on 14 May, the ferry has experienced multiple problems, including breakdowns, grounding incidents, suspension due to training issues, and damage to vehicles. In response, the council has made the crossing free until 2 July, ordered an audit review, and authorized ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage. Local businesses have suffered financially, prompting discussions about possible compensation. Council representatives acknowledge the difficulties but consider them initial "teething problems" rather than a disaster.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred around 07:30 GMT on Thursday on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by careless driving. The road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based international temp agency, has faced criticism for job advertisements specifying physical attributes such as appearance, hair color, and cup size. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners condemned these practices as unlawful, discriminatory, and outdated. Employment lawyer James Lynas confirmed such adverts violate the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on age, gender, disability, race, and other protected characteristics. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the approach, claiming appearance is important to their clients. However, EHRC chief executive Rebecca Hilsenrath urged Matching Models to modernize their hiring practices and abandon sexist criteria.

A shooting incident occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, India. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, shot and killed an 18-year-old student named Gautami and severely injured another student, Sirisha, who is now believed to be out of danger. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. Gun crimes at educational institutions are rare in India, which has strict gun control laws, although firearms are sometimes used to settle disputes. A similar incident occurred in 2007 near Delhi, where a student was shot dead by fellow students.

Between June 2016 and May 2017, advocacy group Glaad analyzed scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series, identifying 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, Glaad expressed concern over the deaths of more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters, including notable examples from "Orange is the New Black" and "Wentworth." Additionally, the report highlighted a record-high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like "Empire," "Luke Cage," and "How to Get Away with Murder." Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would not seek re-election amid controversy over a missing £10.25 million loan from the borough council to Northampton Town Football Club, approved during his tenure as council leader. The loan, intended for stadium redevelopment, is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. Mackintosh denies wrongdoing but faced opposition from his local party, which planned to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fired a rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Oliver was responding to reports of underage drinking and mistakenly believed he heard gunshots. Initially, police claimed the car reversed aggressively toward Oliver, but footage disproved this, showing the vehicle driving away. Oliver was fired shortly after for policy violations and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault related to other teenagers in the car. He faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted, and would be the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. Oliver is currently free on bail, and no trial date has been set.

Melania Trump and her son Barron did not immediately move into the White House after Donald Trump's inauguration, citing Barron's schooling as the reason. This decision sparked criticism on social media, with some viewing it as inappropriate given the symbolic importance of the First Family residing in the White House. However, historians note that delaying a child's move for educational reasons is not unprecedented. Melania has consistently emphasized Barron as her priority, suggesting she may not fully embrace the traditional, active public role of First Lady. Historically, the First Lady's role has been ceremonial but increasingly involves advocacy and public initiatives. Melania has indicated interest in addressing cyber-bullying. The passage also highlights past examples of First Families balancing public duties with private family life, noting that previous presidential families have successfully maintained a sense of normalcy despite the public nature of their roles.

A 72-year-old man died at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland stated they are cooperating fully and await the investigation's findings. A report will be submitted to COPFS upon completion.

A yellow wind warning has been issued, with gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) expected, especially west of the mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction could worsen impacts, causing likely travel disruptions on roads and at sea. Affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts have already caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain shut for most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants defeated the Panthers 4-3, with goals from Derrick Walser, Mike Forney, Mike Radja, and James Desmarais. Nottingham's scorers were Jeff Dimmen, Andy Bohmback, and David Ling. The teams will play again on Saturday. Nottingham currently leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

World champion Lewis Hamilton endured a difficult Chinese Grand Prix, starting from the back, suffering a broken front wing on lap one, and making five pit stops. He now faces a 36-point deficit behind teammate Nico Rosberg, who won the race comfortably after early leader Daniel Ricciardo suffered a puncture. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first-lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth behind Red Bull drivers Daniil Kvyat and Ricciardo. Vettel blamed Kvyat's aggressive move for causing the collision, leading to a heated post-race exchange. Hamilton's car sustained significant aerodynamic and suspension damage, limiting his recovery and leaving him with a challenging task to catch Rosberg, who has won the first three races—a feat historically associated with winning the championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality to encourage discussion about a topic often ignored in German football. His announcement received widespread praise from former teammates, football administrators, and public figures, who described it as courageous and important. Prominent individuals such as Lukas Podolski, Arne Friedrich, Theo Zwanziger, Reinhard Rauball, Gary Lineker, Joseph Barton, John Amaechi, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert expressed support. The announcement is considered a significant step in addressing homophobia in football, with hopes it will encourage greater openness and acceptance in the sport.

Sidwell, aged 34, has played a key role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League, making 32 Championship appearances this season. His current contract expires soon, and he hopes to secure a new deal to remain with the club next season. Sidwell previously played in the Premier League with several clubs and believes he deserves another chance at the top level, noting that he has exceeded expectations this season. Brighton recently confirmed their promotion and are now aiming to secure the league title.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt after 12 minutes, but Colchester equalised shortly after when Kurtis Guthrie scored from close range following a corner. Both teams had chances to win, with Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making key saves, and Guthrie hitting the bar for Colchester. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a good chance late on. Colchester ended the match with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle in injury time.

The 29-year-old player Reid, who previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season, during which they were relegated from League One. Reid could debut for the U's in their upcoming EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss at Accrington.

Following the murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March, there has been increased emphasis on creating a permanent memorial to honour fallen police officers. The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising funds for a £4 million memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire, with the government contributing £1 million. The memorial will commemorate over 1,400 officers and staff who have died in service over the past 250 years. It will feature a brass screen with leaf-shaped cut-outs bearing the names of fallen officers, which will be given to their families as personal memorials. Completion is expected by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League after a 1-0 victory against Sunderland, marking their 25th win in 30 matches. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized focusing on upcoming games rather than past results, highlighting the team's strong recent form (50 points from the last 54 available). United have eight matches left to surpass Chelsea's record of 95 points set in 2005. Ferguson confirmed injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea, and indicated he will make changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea, with players like Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez, and possibly Wayne Rooney returning. Ferguson praised Sunderland's effort and credited United's determined defending and courage for the victory.

Google chairman Mr Schmidt defended the company's UK tax payments, stating they paid what was legally required (£10m between 2006 and 2011) and that any changes to tax obligations should be decided by the UK government. He emphasized that taxes are not optional and that Google would comply with any changes in tax laws. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed establishing a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, potentially allowing confidential hearings. Google has faced criticism for routing UK sales through Ireland to minimize taxes. EU leaders recently agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchanges. Schmidt has previously argued that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs, not where products are consumed, and called for international tax reform discussions to clarify and simplify the system.

NHS Improvement, the regulator, is pushing for further reductions in NHS spending on agency staff after last year's £3.6bn expenditure. Aiming for a £1bn reduction by the end of this financial year, a cap introduced in October has already saved £600m. The cap restricts hospitals, mental health trusts, and ambulance services from paying more than 55% above normal shift rates, excluding senior managers. Despite promising progress, NHS trusts remain 10% behind their targeted savings. The regulator plans to publish league tables ranking trusts' agency spending and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff, amid concerns that some agencies still charge excessive rates. NHS Improvement emphasizes the need for further action, highlighting examples of hospitals being quoted double the capped rates for doctors.

The passage describes the economic situation in Longford, Ireland, highlighting the abandoned Longford Town Centre as a symbol of the country's economic crash. Local businesses, such as Matt O'Brien's clothing shop, have struggled but are beginning to see improvement through diversification. The opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the government for neglecting the region, particularly regarding broadband investment and attracting foreign direct investment. The government counters this criticism by pointing to the planned Center Parcs tourism development, expected to create around 1,000 jobs, although it still awaits planning permission. Local traders suggest additional measures, such as removing parking charges, to further stimulate economic recovery. Overall, while signs of recovery are emerging, residents and businesses believe more targeted efforts are needed.

The competition concludes on 29 May at the same stadium. Eight teams participate, playing each other twice, with the top four teams advancing to the play-offs. Leading run-scorers include Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249). Warner and De Villiers have hit the most sixes (12 each), while De Kock holds the highest individual innings score (108). McClenaghan leads wicket-taking with 9 wickets. Four current or former England players—Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants)—are participating. BBC Sport provides updates on scores, fixtures, and results.

Since 2013, plastic carrier bag usage has increased by 200 million, causing significant environmental issues as many bags cannot be recycled and end up in dumps and rivers. To address this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October, aiming to encourage reuse. Similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have successfully reduced bag usage, and campaigners hope for similar environmental benefits in England.

Strong winds caused significant disruption across Wales, damaging a school roof in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, and leaving hundreds of homes without power. Transportation was heavily impacted, with train delays, speed restrictions, and lane closures on major bridges. Irish Ferries cancelled several sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, and the National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle due to safety concerns. Winds peaked Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey, easing by evening, allowing bridge restrictions to be lifted. However, the poor weather forecast led to postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip event to 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about reuniting with director Ryan Coogler for the film "Black Panther," though he did not specify his role. He also looks forward to working alongside Lupita Nyong'o, an Oscar-winning actress, and Chadwick Boseman, who portrays Black Panther. Jordan previously starred in the unsuccessful "Fantastic Four" reboot, while Nyong'o appeared as Maz Kanata in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." "Black Panther" is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The passage describes the restoration project of Alexandra Palace's east wing, particularly focusing on its theatre and BBC studios. Founded in 1875, the theatre, unused for decades but retaining original decor and machinery, is planned to reopen in 2018 for theatrical performances, cinema, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be refurbished. The project aims to transform Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination, including converting the glazed east court into a public exhibition space. The total refurbishment cost is £26.6m, with £18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8m from Haringey Council, and the remaining £1m to be raised by Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust by summer 2017.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 senior caps for England after debuting in 2009, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only briefly at Euro 2016. He retired from international football, wishing success to the team under Sam Allardyce. Milner holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46) and scored his only senior international goal against Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family narrowly escaped a devastating house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her young son David, who noticed the flames while awake on FaceTime with his father. Although the family survived, their home was destroyed and their pets perished. The fire, caused by rubbish burned in a wood stove, spread rapidly without triggering the fire alarm. The community has since provided support and donations to help the family recover. Mrs. Smith credits David's quick actions for saving their lives and expresses deep pride and gratitude toward him.

Energy drinks giant was reportedly considering a £200m offer for Premier League club West Ham. Current owners Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in 2010, valuing the club at £105m, and now own over 85%. Since moving to London Stadium, West Ham has attracted takeover interest from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan previously indicated a minority stake might be sold to clear debts, but stated their intention for ownership to pass to their children.

At the MTV Movie Awards ceremony in Los Angeles, "The Fault in Our Stars" emerged as the night's big winner, securing best movie, best female performance (Shailene Woodley), best kiss, and the Trailblazer Award. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for "American Sniper," dedicating his award to Chris Kyle. Other notable winners included Channing Tatum (best comedic performance), Meryl Streep (best villain), Zac Efron (best shirtless performance), and Kevin Hart (comedic genius award). Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers co-stars. The event also served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters.

Aberdeen loaned 21-year-old player Smith to Dundee United in July, where he has scored five goals this season. Smith, who has represented Scotland at Under-21 level, debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and scored four goals in 89 appearances. St Mirren manager Jack Ross described Smith as a "brilliant acquisition," highlighting his maturity and attacking capabilities. St Mirren, currently bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council stated that warmer weather now allows its Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, aiming to fill approximately 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working for EnQuest on the Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes claimed the workers were not provided proper protective equipment initially, and expressed concerns about potential cancer risks and ongoing health tests. He accused EnQuest of failing in its duty of care and stated he has struggled to find work since raising concerns. EnQuest confirmed the exposure but stated it was below reportable levels, and said additional precautionary measures have since been implemented. Wood Group emphasized employee safety as their priority, conducted medical assessments, and supported a joint investigation. Unite union criticized the treatment of workers and called for transparency, while the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) noted the incident was not reportable under current regulations and thus did not investigate further.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from New York dealer Art of the Past for $650,000 in 2007. It later emerged that the dealer's manager admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this sculpture, which is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The allegations surfaced during a 2012 court case against the dealer. Following discussions with India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which officially requested the sculpture's return, ACM decided to return the artwork. Although there is no conclusive proof of theft, ACM acknowledged the dealer's confession of trafficking stolen items. ACM plans legal action to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck northern Italy, 35km north of Lucca, at a depth of 15.5km. The quake, centered in Garfagnana, was felt widely, including in Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. Although no immediate injuries or damage were reported, phone lines and power were disrupted, and schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy frequently experiences earthquakes, notably the deadly 2009 quake in L'Aquila, which killed nearly 300 people. Last May, two earthquakes in the same region caused over 20 deaths. Following the L'Aquila disaster, six scientists and an official were convicted in 2012 for providing misleading reassurances about earthquake risks, leading to fatalities.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, initially doubted South Yorkshire's climate suitability but has finally seen fruit growing, although it is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat. He expressed great excitement at this success.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their open-world adventure game from 27 January to 24 March, citing the need for additional testing and polish. They emphasized that the decision was made in the best interests of the game and fans. Meanwhile, online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC release. Rockstar has also released screenshots of the PC version, promising enhanced detail, 1080p at 60fps visuals, 4K resolution, and triple monitor support. Minimum PC specifications have been published. GTA V previously became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days of its initial release in September 2013.

76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery for his painting Squint (19), after previously being shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times. The painting depicts a "leper squint," holes in medieval churches allowing outsiders to view services. Judge Ansel Krut praised the work as "extraordinary" and technically subtle, noting its emotional depth despite being challenging to view. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art materials. Established in 1957, the biennial John Moores Painting Prize is among Britain's oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Masked assailants simultaneously attacked the offices of two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, early on Thursday. The attackers set fire to the Yeni Safak building, but firefighters quickly extinguished the blaze. Gunfire shattered windows at both locations, and bullet casings were found at the scenes. No casualties were reported, and police are currently searching for the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. Previously, pro-government protesters had attacked another newspaper, Hurriyet, accusing it of misquoting President Erdogan.

The 24-year-old former Burton player, previously contracted with the Stags and loaned to Crawley (scoring three goals in 23 appearances), will join Marcus Bignot's Mariners on a free transfer starting 1 January, becoming Bignot's first signing.

Gareth Southgate, who replaced Sam Allardyce as England manager in September, is currently in charge temporarily and has overseen mixed results. Arsene Wenger, whose Arsenal contract expires in the summer, has been linked with the England job but insists he is focused on his current role. Wenger praised Southgate's experience and competence, suggesting he deserves a chance to prove himself. Wenger also confirmed Arsenal's intention to offer defender Hector Bellerin a new contract amid interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, emphasizing that Bellerin's long-term future is at Arsenal. Additionally, Wenger noted midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation, with the company fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving the Northern Isles. Previously, the RMT union had highlighted that some workers earned less than £4 per hour. The vessels Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under contract from Serco Northlink, will now return directly to Serco Northlink's operation.
