Seatruck had argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to their non-UK resident crew, and had declined Serco Northlink's offers to bridge and backdate the pay gap. Under the new arrangement, all crew members will receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, which operates three ferries and two cargo boats under a heavily subsidised £243m contract awarded in 2012, will implement the changes early next month pending final financial and regulatory details.

Ken Dickie, aged 64, died in hospital on 14 May following an incident at Rockley Park in Poole involving Jamie Mitchell, aged 35. Mitchell intervened in an argument between Dickie and Mitchell's mother, Samantha, who had been in a relationship with Dickie. After drinking alcohol, Mitchell confronted Dickie, resulting in a physical altercation. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault, and both he and his mother admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about the incident. Mitchell later described the event as a "tragic accident." Sentencing for both individuals is scheduled for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter known for hits like Michael Jackson's "Thriller," "Off The Wall," and "Rock With You," died in London at age 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile, Temperton began his career with disco group Heatwave, writing hits such as "Boogie Nights." His songwriting caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, leading to collaborations on Jackson's breakthrough albums "Off The Wall" and "Thriller," the latter becoming the best-selling album in US history. Temperton also wrote songs recorded by artists including Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. He won a Grammy in 1990 and received two Oscar nominations in 1986. Tributes poured in from musicians like Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, and Gilles Peterson, highlighting his significant influence and legacy in music.

Researchers, including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, have discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. These earthworks, known as geoglyphs, were hidden beneath bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation revealed over 450 large geometric structures. Their purpose remains unclear, but due to the lack of artefacts and defensive features, researchers suggest they were likely used sporadically as ritual gathering places. Unlike other ritual sites such as Maya pyramids or Stonehenge, these geoglyphs were constructed within taller vegetation and were probably not visible above the forest canopy. Analysis of soil samples, phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes indicates that humans significantly influenced the Amazonian environment, selectively cultivating economically valuable trees rather than extensively burning forests. This challenges previous assumptions of pristine pre-European Amazonian ecosystems, suggesting instead a long history of human-managed biodiversity, possibly still influencing the region's forests today.

Australian tennis player Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open, admitted feeling tired and bored during the match, attributing his fatigue to travel and poor sleep. Last year at the same tournament, Kyrgios was fined for a foul-mouthed outburst, calling the event a "circus."

Scientists and charities are urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination programme to boys, highlighting its effectiveness in preventing head and neck cancers, which are increasing in incidence. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the HPV vaccine to protect against cervical cancer, with 85% coverage in Wales since its introduction in 2008. Experts note a demographic shift in head and neck cancer patients, who are increasingly younger, predominantly male, non-smokers, with an average age of 55. Charities and medical professionals argue that vaccinating boys would significantly reduce cancer rates and urge the Welsh government to act proactively, while the government states it is awaiting recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student from West Calder High School, passed away after battling a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Diagnosed in August, Jak documented his journey and treatment on social media, gaining widespread support and over 28,000 followers. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude, sharing personal experiences including meetings with football stars, playing his tuba, and attending special events. Shortly before his death, he briefly attended a prom held in his honour, where his family accepted awards recognizing his courage. After doctors informed him that his cancer had spread and treatment would cease, Jak continued to enjoy meaningful experiences and encouraged fundraising for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. His story inspired significant community support, including a charity football match planned in his memory.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a closely contested match, with Abdallah El Said scoring the decisive goal in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had an earlier goal correctly disallowed for offside. The result eliminates Uganda from their first tournament since 1978, while Egypt will face Ghana next, with the top spot in Group D still undecided. Ghana had already qualified for the quarter-finals after beating Mali 1-0 earlier.

Lancashire County Council has selected land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College sites for a new railway station in Skelmersdale. This decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail, considering these sites and another near the Concourse shopping centre. Skelmersdale's original station closed in 1956, and currently it is one of the largest towns in northwest England without a railway station. Under the new plans, developed in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, Skelmersdale could receive two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The chosen site offers good highway access, connectivity, and potential for future expansion. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land.
Police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, arresting a man in his late 40s at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old woman was seriously injured after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from nearby Bad Muender later surrendered to authorities. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. Authorities have not yet determined the motive and are appealing for witnesses.

A study conducted by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin examined pay rise requests among 4,600 workers, finding that women ask for pay rises as frequently as men but are less likely to receive them. Contrary to the "reticent female" theory, the research showed no evidence that women avoid asking for salary increases due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from stereotypes. When comparing like-for-like workers, men were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise upon request. The study controlled for factors such as employment type (full-time or part-time), employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. Based on data from Australia's 2013-14 workplace relations survey, the findings surprised researchers, who suggested the results indicate some level of discrimination against women. However, younger workers under 40 showed no gender difference in requesting or receiving pay rises, suggesting changing negotiation behaviors among younger generations.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, but despite spending money on ground investigations, no suitable location has been found. The two existing cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to reach full capacity by 2018 and 2021 respectively. Potential sites have been rejected due to issues such as size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. Once current cemeteries are full, only reopening family plots, reserved plots, and interment of ashes will remain possible. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will introduce an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online content such as videos, band interviews, and festival information through signs and posters. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan stated that this new feature will enhance visitor experience and enable global audiences to engage with the festival remotely, providing updated content and ticket purchasing options.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died shortly after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Veterinary staff confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur even in horses without underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, including overheating and wobbling, he displayed no such symptoms on the day of his death. The horse had previously won notable races, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described Many Clouds as the "horse of a lifetime." Authorities emphasized the rarity of such incidents and expressed commitment to further understanding and prevention.

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl was raped by a person named David Ayrton, now known as Davina, who was 34 at the time of trial. Ayrton denied the charge but was found guilty and will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded Ayrton into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester, citing concerns about self-harm and failure to attend court. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide previously, changed her name in 2012 but has not undergone physical or medical gender transition. The victim clearly recalled the attack, which occurred in a Portsmouth garage while two friends slept nearby. Ayrton later disclosed the incident to a care home worker in 2014.

Serbian tennis player Novak Djokovic and his partner lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilian doubles players Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a day after Djokovic was eliminated from singles competition by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Earlier in July, Djokovic, the world number one and 12-time Grand Slam winner, experienced a surprising third-round defeat at Wimbledon against American Sam Querrey, but later rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

Over 20 competitors will participate in Saturday's chainsaw carving event in Carrbridge, located in the Cairngorms. Participants from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US regularly compete, using only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, who has been sidelined since sustaining a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up match against Italy in September, is nearing a return and expects to be fit in time for Wales' Six Nations opener against Ireland on February 7. The 27-year-old scrum-half, capped 16 times by Wales, recently renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, rejecting offers from other clubs to remain with his home region, where he debuted in 2007. Webb expressed satisfaction with his recovery progress and his decision to stay, emphasizing his commitment to representing his country.

US border agents near Sumas, Washington, intercepted two men attempting to smuggle 58 pounds (26 kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One suspect, Nathan Hall, fired at agents and fled but was later arrested in Canada. The other suspect, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately detained. Authorities also arrested two accomplices, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, who planned to transport the drugs to San Francisco. Lambert was to be paid $11,000 for the delivery. All three suspects in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is known as a common smuggling route.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported counselling over 4,500 children for online abuse in the past year, nearly double the number from 2011-12. The actual number affected is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven described severe distress, humiliation, and fear caused by online bullying, which often extends beyond school into their homes. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized the urgent need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, as bullying typically worsens if left unaddressed. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with schools, parents, and organizations to tackle the issue.

Following a controversial UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements, tensions rose between Israel and the US. The US abstained from vetoing the resolution, angering Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu, who accused the US of secretly supporting it—an allegation the US denied. The resolution declared Israeli settlements illegal under international law and an obstacle to peace. In response, Netanyahu summoned ambassadors, recalled envoys, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled diplomatic visits. A planned vote on new settlement homes in East Jerusalem was postponed at Netanyahu's request to avoid further tensions ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech outlining his vision for Israeli-Palestinian peace. Palestinian President Abbas welcomed the resolution, hoping it would lead to concrete steps toward ending the occupation.

The passage describes events and celebrations marking Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday. Prince William praised the Queen as a guiding example of a good monarch, highlighting her dedication, tolerance, and commitment. Celebrations included the release of commemorative stamps featuring four generations of the royal family, visits to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office marking the postal service's 500th anniversary, and the opening of a new bandstand. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron, acknowledged the Queen's dignity and service. Prince William addressed recent criticisms of his own royal duties, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but believes in gradually developing into his role. He emphasized his desire to maintain a normal life for himself and his family as long as possible. The Queen's birthday events also included unveiling a commemorative walkway and lighting beacons across the UK and globally. The republican group Republic criticized the extensive media coverage as disproportionate and celebratory rather than balanced reporting.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup match. After Cheltenham's promising start, West Ham took control with two quick first-half goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Cheltenham had chances through Harry Pell and Jordon Forster but failed to score. West Ham, who made seven changes from their recent Premier League losses, could have extended their lead further, but Cheltenham goalkeeper Jonathan Flatt and captain Kyle Storer prevented additional goals. Cheltenham's defeat ended League Two's representation in the competition.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, aged 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after motorist Andreas Werner, 46, failed to notice him while turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not seek imprisonment, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse, and Werner expressed remorse without being able to explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, west London, traveled to Syria to join the extremist group Rayat al Tawheed, affiliated with Islamic State. He became known for posting propaganda videos and images online, often masked, depicting his involvement in violent activities, including posing with a severed head. Khawaja attempted to secretly return to the UK by faking his own death online and was assisted by his cousin, Tahir Bhatti. Upon arrival at Dover, both were arrested. Khawaja, described by police as highly dangerous, admitted to four terrorism-related offences and faces a potential life sentence. Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Jackson, a 22-year-old player who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, has joined Barnsley as their third signing ahead of their League One play-off final. Barnsley's caretaker manager Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and attacking style, noting he fits their playing approach. Jackson declined a contract renewal offer from Wrexham.

Bottles of detergent have washed ashore at several coves in Cornwall, including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The bottles, believed to have come from a container lost overboard from a ship during stormy weather near Land's End in May, pose a risk to wildlife and marine life. Although the Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of Vanish detergent, it stated there is currently only circumstantial evidence linking this incident to the bottles found. National Trust volunteers have been clearing the bottles, some of which have leaked, and authorities advise the public to avoid contact with them. Cornwall Council and other agencies are monitoring the situation closely.

The incident took place around 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, resulting in minor injuries to several people. The road was closed, with traffic diverted via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton after helping the team secure promotion to the Championship by finishing second in League One. Dervite, who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, made 14 appearances last season and has played 83 matches overall for the club. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his contribution, especially towards the end of the campaign. Dervite joins teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in renewing contracts following the club's promotion.

Labour and the Liberal Democrats previously cooperated in the Lords to defeat the government on Brexit-related issues, such as EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval of a Brexit deal. However, after MPs rejected these amendments, the two parties clashed. The Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding too easily and aligning with the Conservatives, while Labour accused the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" and giving people false hope. Despite past cooperation on various issues, tensions remain, although both parties acknowledge they may still collaborate pragmatically in the future.

In this passage, the author highlights that defence is a low priority in the current UK election, overshadowed by issues like the economy, NHS, and immigration. Public fatigue from past military interventions and political reticence have contributed to this neglect. Despite growing global instability, the UK has significantly reduced its military capabilities, including cuts to army personnel, naval ships, and air force squadrons, creating capability gaps such as the absence of Maritime Patrol Aircraft. Defence spending has fallen from fourth to sixth globally, and the UK is projected to soon drop below NATO's symbolic 2% GDP spending target. Major parties have avoided detailed defence commitments, with only smaller parties explicitly supporting the 2% target. Further defence budget cuts appear likely, given fiscal pressures and lack of political protection for defence spending. The Conservatives have limited their options by promising to maintain army size, increase equipment budgets, and renew the Trident nuclear deterrent, while Labour and Liberal Democrats propose more cautious approaches to nuclear deterrence. The upcoming Strategic Defence Review may reconsider nuclear spending, especially given US concerns about the UK's declining conventional capabilities. Additionally, the UK's new aircraft carriers face staffing and equipment shortages, raising concerns about a "hollow force" unable to match political rhetoric of global military influence.

Barcelona is under investigation regarding Neymar's transfer from Santos, initially reported at £48.6m, but alleged to be significantly higher when considering additional contracts. The club has denied wrongdoing but made an extra tax payment of approximately 13.5 million euros to address potential discrepancies and protect its reputation. Former club president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds, which he denies. Neymar's total cost to Barcelona, including fees, wages, and taxes, is estimated at £106.8m. The investigation continues, and no confirmation has been given on whether the case will be dropped following the additional tax payment.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, died when the van he was travelling in was struck by a car driven the wrong way on the motorway by elderly driver Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw's family called for regular driving tests for retired drivers, arguing that older drivers' slower reactions pose risks. Currently, UK drivers over 70 only complete a self-assessment form every three years without mandatory medical or practical tests. The DVLA stated there is no evidence older drivers cause more serious accidents and has no plans to impose age-based restrictions. Age UK emphasized the importance of driving for older people's independence, advocating support for safe driving as long as possible.

The passage describes controversy surrounding the safety and review process of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse. Many women have experienced severe complications, prompting criticism of an independent review report. Two patient representatives resigned from the review group, alleging the final report was watered down and incomplete. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will now examine the review process and identify lessons for the future. The report recommended against routinely offering mesh procedures, advocated for informed patient choice, and called for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite campaigners' demands for a complete ban, the Scottish government stated it lacks authority to ban the implants, as this power lies with the UK regulatory body. The review's chairwoman, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to achieve consensus among panel members, acknowledging significant internal disagreements and public criticism. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh implants in the past two decades, with more than 400 currently pursuing legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5K record by 14 seconds, finishing in 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at Glasgow's Emirates Arena. McColgan initially questioned whether the race met official criteria, as Muir was the only competitor running the full 5K distance, but British Athletics confirmed the record was expected to be ratified. McColgan praised Muir's potential, suggesting she could run even faster and compete for world medals. She also noted similarities between Muir's race and her own record-setting run 25 years earlier. Muir previously broke the British 1500m record and competed in the 1500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won gold riding Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou after an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton earned bronze. Britain's William Fox-Pitt, competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall, finished 12th. Fox-Pitt initially led after dressage but dropped to 21st due to time penalties in cross-country, despite a faultless final show-jumping round. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes, securing his place in the last 16 at Wimbledon for the 11th time. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set, but Murray rallied from 5-2 down in the fourth set, winning five consecutive games to clinch victory. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the next round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week for the first time. Murray described the match as tense and inconsistent, noting concerns about fading light and potential roof closure. Despite not feeling at his best physically, Murray expressed satisfaction at progressing and having time to recover before his next match.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found evidence alcohol had been served until 04:49 BST, well beyond permitted hours. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, faced two charges of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours and was fined £3,000. James Thomas faced one similar charge and was fined £1,000. The judge criticized O'Neill's record as "appalling," noting the severity of the case and regretting the lack of authority to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched his party's manifesto titled "Real Partnership," emphasizing partnership over domination. He faced controversy after suggesting voters could transfer votes to the nationalist SDLP, a stance publicly distanced by senior colleague Danny Kennedy. Nesbitt stood by his comments, clarifying he preferred working with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin after the election. He argued the election should focus on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and criticized the DUP and Sinn Féin's governance as incompetent and corrupt. The manifesto includes commitments to address healthcare waiting lists, increase police numbers, prioritize infrastructure projects, support the LGBT community, and protect groups from negative Brexit impacts.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed plans to introduce a motion to the Northern Ireland assembly to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This move aligns Northern Ireland with recent proposals in England and Wales, known as 'Turing's Law', named after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing. The pardons will apply both posthumously and to living gay and bisexual men who can apply for them. Sugden emphasized the importance of equal treatment and correcting past injustices, stating the motion would allow quicker resolution than an assembly bill. The motion will now proceed for assembly consideration.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old athlete from Kinross, set a new Scottish mile record of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds, surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 record. This performance places her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m record, expressed satisfaction with her achievement, especially as it was her first race of the season at this distance. She finished second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon and aims to secure a place on Great Britain's Olympic team at the upcoming British trials. Muir balances her athletics career with veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year.
The passage mentions pictures from 26 beaches ranked as Scotland's "most excellent" for water quality.

In 2006, Alexander Litvinenko was fatally poisoned in London with radioactive polonium-210 after meeting two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. UK officials believe the Russian state likely sponsored the murder, although direct involvement by President Putin is not confirmed. Litvinenko, who defected to the UK in 2000 and publicly criticized Russian authorities, was poisoned twice before his death. The suspects deny wrongdoing, but evidence strongly implicates them, and attempts to extradite them from Russia have failed. The poisoning posed unknown risks to the London public due to radiation exposure.

Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed Australia's cricket captain, succeeding Michael Clarke, who retired after Australia's Ashes defeat to England. Smith, who already leads the one-day side, will also captain the Twenty20 team due to Aaron Finch's injury. David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues, with selectors confident in his maturity and leadership potential. Smith previously captained Australia in three Tests against India and has an impressive Test batting record. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and suitability for the role. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Mr Farron repeatedly avoided directly answering whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating that "we are all sinners." However, he emphasized his strong support for LGBT-plus rights, pledging to prioritize defending equal marriage and extending marital rights for transgender individuals. When questioned about his past vote against the Equality Bill in 2007, Farron explained it was due to concerns about protecting individual liberties, but reaffirmed his commitment to equality and equal legal access for all, regardless of sexuality.

In 2015, French-based Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare is now taking over the facility for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi employees. This investment is expected to positively impact the local economy, strengthening Newcastle's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving the council at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, views these departures as evidence of the council's difficulty retaining senior staff and anticipates more exits soon. Ellis served as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Monaghan was head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland led human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

English rider Guy Martin experienced a difficult racing season, crashing at this year's TT and facing ongoing mechanical issues with his Honda Fireblade bike. Although initially reported as quitting road racing, Martin clarified he has not entirely given up racing but has no plans to continue road racing with Honda this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix, as the team withdrew him due to the bike's lack of competitiveness. Martin expressed dissatisfaction with his TT experience and stated his intention to focus instead on racing classics and unconventional events.

In Nigeria's recent elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory, winning 19 out of 28 governorship positions, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. This follows the PDP's first-ever presidential election loss last month, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated as president on May 29. The PDP lost key northern states, including Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa, but retained control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and mostly southeastern states. Elections were inconclusive in Imo state, and results from Taraba remain outstanding, while seven states did not hold elections. The APC's gains have reduced the PDP to a regional party, strong mainly in the southeast and Niger Delta. However, the APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, raising concerns about potential disruptions to oil production and revenue. Although violence marred elections in some areas, overall the elections were more peaceful than previous ones, suggesting a maturing democracy. The PDP's defeat was attributed to voter desire for change, corruption allegations, defections to the APC, and perceived failures in addressing the Boko Haram insurgency.

A report by the environmental group Mighty accuses agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore's state-owned investment firm Temasek, of indirectly supporting unsustainable palm oil practices linked to slash-and-burn agriculture causing severe haze in Southeast Asia. Both Olam and Temasek deny these allegations. Olam, which sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, insists it maintains strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policies, although it only recently disclosed its suppliers' identities. Temasek emphasizes it does not direct Olam's operations but supports no-burn policies. Mighty also criticizes Olam's operations in Gabon, alleging rainforest destruction for palm oil plantations, a claim Olam counters by asserting its practices there are responsible, transparent, and aligned with Gabon's sovereign rights. The palm oil industry, projected to reach $88 billion by 2022, faces ongoing criticism for environmental damage, deforestation, and labor abuses, with activists urging stronger governmental oversight despite economic benefits to rural communities.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started offering puppy platters following the introduction of a new law permitting dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they dine outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury, having only appeared as a substitute in recent matches. Derby County's David Nugent may return after a groin injury, while midfielder Jacob Butterfield seeks a starting role after scoring as a substitute in the previous game.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube, originally imposed in 2012 due to controversial content, after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) confirmed that internet providers were instructed to restore access. Google's new arrangement allows the PTA to directly request the blocking of offending material, although YouTube clarified that content removal requests from governments are not automatically granted and must undergo review. Activists have called for greater transparency regarding the terms of the agreement between Google and the Pakistani government.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces controversy due to sharing Swiss-Italian nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Liberian FA boss Musa Bility argues this constitutes a conflict of interest under FIFA's electoral regulations and demands Scala's withdrawal, threatening to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down. Previously, Scala voluntarily withdrew from the 2015 elections to avoid perceived conflicts, as he shared nationality with incumbent candidate Sepp Blatter. However, Scala's spokesman insists nationality alone does not constitute a conflict of interest, emphasizing that Scala's earlier withdrawal was voluntary and precautionary due to Blatter's incumbency. Bility, previously disqualified from running himself, stresses the importance of fairness and integrity in the upcoming election, which features five candidates and will be decided by FIFA's 209 members in Zurich.

Two workers, Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56), died following a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. The incident occurred in a paint-spraying area, likely due to a build-up of toxic fumes ignited by an unknown source, causing a fire-ball effect. Forensic investigations and witness statements have made significant progress, and the Health and Safety Executive is conducting further inquiries.

Tunisia and Morocco both faced challenges regarding their participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia risked expulsion after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea. They later apologized, clarifying they never accused Caf or the referee of corruption, and resolved the issue after discussions with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Morocco was initially banned after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban and significantly reduced their fine. Both nations are now cleared to participate in the 2017 qualifiers, with Tunisia aiming for a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1 at Etihad Stadium in a match marred by a mass altercation in the 95th minute. City's Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct after a dangerous challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz, marking his second dismissal this season. City's Fernandinho was also sent off and received a three-match ban following a clash with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas, who faces no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charges.

Mae gan Gymru rai o'r cyfraddau gwaethaf yn y byd datblygedig o ran goroesi canser, yn rhannol oherwydd oedi wrth ddiagnosio cleifion heb symptomau amlwg. Yn dilyn ymweliad â Denmarc, lle mae canolfannau diagnostig wedi gwella cyfraddau goroesi, mae cynllun peilot newydd wedi'i lansio yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd. Bydd meddygon teulu sy'n amau bod gan gleifion ganser, ond heb symptomau clir, yn gallu eu cyfeirio'n uniongyrchol at ganolfan ddiagnostig yn Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg o fewn saith diwrnod. Bydd tua chwe chlaf yr wythnos yn cael profion cyflym, gyda'r nod o sicrhau diagnosis cynnar. Mae cynllun tebyg hefyd yn cael ei sefydlu yn Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot. Os bydd y cynllun peilot chwe mis yn llwyddiannus, bydd yn cael ei ymestyn i fyrddau iechyd eraill yn yr ardal.

England defeated Pakistan decisively at Old Trafford, leveling the Test series with a day to spare. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, achieving their second-largest victory over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match after scoring 254 and an unbeaten 71, taking four catches, and claiming a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's innings as extraordinary, while Root himself described it as his most controlled performance. Pakistan struggled, dismissed for 198 and 234, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq surpassing 50 in the first two Tests. Misbah acknowledged poor shot selection and low confidence, promising improvement. Former players Vaughan and Boycott praised England's performance but differed on predictions for the series' competitiveness. The third Test begins on 3 August at Edgbaston.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, appointing interim coach Rob Howley to his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales during the summer tour, a role he previously held in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) plans to appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde, with announcements expected soon. WRU officials believe the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour will benefit Welsh rugby by providing valuable experience and inspiration.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1, ending their six-game losing streak in the league. Southampton initially led through Charlie Austin's early penalty, but Hull turned the match around in two second-half minutes, with substitute Robert Snodgrass scoring and then assisting Michael Dawson's header. Hull overcame early injuries to strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, with Snodgrass' introduction significantly improving their performance. Southampton pushed hard for an equaliser, but Hull goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas produced a vital goal-line clearance late on. Despite the win, Hull remain in the bottom three. Southampton manager Claude Puel cited a lack of concentration following their recent Europa League victory as a factor in the defeat.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist was a local resident, but no further details have been released. The tractor driver was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses, and the B1191 was temporarily closed between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

Macedonia has been in political turmoil since 2015, when opposition leader Zoran Zaev began releasing covert recordings allegedly showing government ministers involved in vote-rigging, corruption, illegal wiretapping, and cover-ups of serious crimes. President Ivanov recently cancelled an investigation into these abuse-of-power allegations, claiming he wanted to end the country's "agony" ahead of early elections. His decision was strongly criticized by the opposition and EU officials, who warned it undermined the rule of law and jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership ambitions. The government denies wrongdoing and accuses Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country, a claim Zaev rejects.

After Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with former Derby boss Paul Clement as their preferred candidate. Curtis emphasizes the importance of selecting someone capable of avoiding relegation, warning that returning from the Championship would be challenging. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after nearly facing bankruptcy and relegation from the Football League in 2003, previously built a reputation for attractive, possession-based football. Curtis believes the club has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements. Despite this, he feels the current squad is capable of staying up and stresses the importance of players understanding the club's history and significance to the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two to the National League after losing to Leyton Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. Orient initially led 2-0 through Jay Simpson, and Armand Gnanduillet scored the decisive goal to secure Orient's victory and maintain their play-off hopes. Dagenham, who first reached the Football League in 2007 and League One in 2010, struggled defensively and offensively this season, conceding significantly more goals and scoring fewer, notably with Cureton's goal tally dropping from 20 last season to nine this season. Manager John Still, who previously guided the club to League One, returned in December and expressed commitment to achieving promotion next season. Leyton Orient, now two points from the play-offs, recently removed player-manager Kevin Nolan, and interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized professionalism and dedication to the fans despite managerial instability.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, aged 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp praised Gerrard's appointment, noting Gerrard's ambition to become a manager and highlighting his potential due to his playing experience and willingness to learn. Gerrard retired in November after a 19-year playing career, having previously turned down a managerial opportunity at MK Dons, stating it was "too soon." He is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching licence, necessary for managing in the Premier League.

Morton secured a comfortable victory over Alloa, with McManus scoring twice, Forbes adding a deflected goal, and Johnstone netting late. Alloa briefly responded through McAusland before half-time, but Morton maintained control to win the match.

Ofsted has uncovered illegal schools operating in poor and unsafe conditions in Birmingham, leading to the closure of three establishments. These schools, primarily within Muslim communities, were found to be unregistered and posed risks of abuse and radicalisation. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw expressed concern that these cases represent only the "tip of the iceberg." The government is now consulting on stricter regulations for educational settings teaching more than 6 to 8 hours weekly, and has funded a dedicated team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools. Education Secretary approval is required for prosecution, and she has instructed Ofsted to prepare cases against identified illegal schools. Sir Michael emphasized that enforcement will apply equally to all religious groups.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders region in nearly 200 years. It operates on a small scale, housed entirely within a cowshed, and emphasizes local sourcing by using botanicals from the Teviot valley. The distillery aims to reflect the area's unique terroir and flavor profile. Its name honors Lilliard, a legendary female figure from the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, symbolizing both the local landscape and the distillery's strong female-led production team.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died after being struck by a tractor driven by Gary Green at Swithens Farm near Leeds. Green was found to be more than twice the legal alcohol limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer the night before. Due to the incident occurring on private land, Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law, and was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in prison after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed deep grief, emphasizing the lasting impact on their family and the importance of remembering Harry beyond the tragic event. The Health and Safety Executive described Green's actions as reckless and the case as extremely tragic.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker, had his appeal partially upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), allowing him to resume training and participate in friendly matches with his new club Barcelona, although his four-month ban from competitive matches remains. Suarez was originally banned by FIFA from all football-related activities for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. Cas deemed the total ban excessive, allowing Suarez to train, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities, but upheld the nine-match international suspension. Suarez's competitive debut for Barcelona is expected to be against Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez previously faced disciplinary actions for similar incidents, including biting and racial abuse.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a competitive race against Lithuanian couple Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene. The event involved a challenging 380-metre course with obstacles such as haystacks, steep slopes, and water pistols. Participants included various combinations of men and women, and marriage was not required. Rich and Anna trained intensively and will now advance to the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage describes the UK government's decision to replace the paper car tax disc system with an electronic system in October 2014, allowing monthly direct debit payments. Concerns were raised about potential job losses among the 5,000 DVLA employees in Swansea. Minister Stephen Hammond reassured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that although job roles might change and fewer staff might be needed for certain tasks, any reductions would be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies. Mr Hedges welcomed these assurances, acknowledging the benefits of the new system and expressing comfort that employees' jobs would be protected through redeployment.

Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, faces strong EU criticism over three controversial laws: strict controls on asylum seekers, a higher education law potentially forcing the closure of the prestigious Central European University (CEU), and proposed legislation targeting NGOs as "foreign-backed." Hungary insists these issues are domestic matters and refuses to backtrack, with Poland pledging to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws, and the EU has warned of possible action if Hungary does not change course.

The passage describes casting details and production information for the 2017 film adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson will star as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and an unnamed star as Mrs Potts, a role originally voiced by Angela Lansbury. Directed by Bill Condon, filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios, with the film scheduled for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a prominent journalist and columnist for the Sunday Times since 1993, has died after battling an extensive form of cancer, which he humorously described as the "full English." Known for his fearless, witty, and controversial writing style, Gill overcame dyslexia to become a celebrated author and critic. His death has prompted widespread tributes from colleagues and peers, who praised his unique talent, intelligence, and compassion. Gill's career included notable controversies due to provocative comments about various groups and places. He was married twice, including to current Home Secretary Amber Rudd, and had four children. His illness led him to become engaged to his long-term partner, Nicola Formby.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator. Reports indicate he was struck on the head with a bottle and kicked repeatedly, resulting in serious brain injuries and a coma lasting about 10 days. The incident reportedly occurred after he appeared on stage wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol historically used in Mongolia long before its association with Nazi Germany. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but claims local media reports are distorted. The suspect, identified as a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested, with Mongolian police stating this was due to the injuries not being considered serious, rather than diplomatic immunity. The rapper's representatives deny allegations that he shouted Nazi slogans during the performance.

Campaigners from the group Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion plans by staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. They have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted aerodrome area, and will appear in court on 19 August. Police stated that airport security will be reviewed.

Glamorgan's innings was highlighted by Nick Selman's mature 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, after a recent run of poor form. Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles regularly took wickets in cloudy conditions, restricting Glamorgan to 220. Aneurin Donald contributed a quick 36, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten secured a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire also struggled batting in difficult evening conditions, leaving the match evenly balanced. Glamorgan were captained by Michael Hogan due to Jacques Rudolph's neck injury. Selman expressed relief at returning to form, while Taylor acknowledged helpful bowling conditions and anticipated a challenging batting effort for Gloucestershire.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police after making online threats to ambush and shoot police officers by falsely reporting a crime. Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and awaits sentencing. The threats occurred while he was intoxicated and were reported by the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, a confidential support service he had contacted. Hughes had a previous firearm conviction from 2009 and was on bail awaiting trial for separate firearms charges, of which he was later cleared. His legal team argued he had no intention of carrying out the threats.

Surrey recovered from a poor start of 8-2 to post 255-7, driven by a crucial 130-run partnership between Davies and Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase faltered after Stuart Meaker took three quick wickets, including key batsmen Bairstow and Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire fell short, all out for 236. Yorkshire missed opportunities, notably dropping Davies on 43, who went on to score significantly. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised Davies and Foakes' partnership, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment, noting their batting failed at crucial moments.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler experienced flooding 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack and radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. The onboard pump was insufficient, prompting the RNLI lifeboat crew to provide an additional pump and tow the vessel to Holyhead.

Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir will miss next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine exams scheduled for May. The 24-year-old athlete, who recently placed fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, expressed disappointment at missing the event but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. She plans to return to university next week for her final year. Despite this, Muir is considering competing at the World Indoor Championships in March. She recently set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m and believes she has potential for at least two or three more Olympic appearances.

Liverpool are struggling to replicate last season's title challenge due to several key issues, according to Robbie Savage. The departure of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge have significantly reduced their goal-scoring threat, and new signings like Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini have not adequately replaced them. Liverpool's intensity, pressing, and effectiveness from set-pieces have also declined sharply. Defensively, despite heavy investment, they remain disorganized and lack leadership, with goalkeeper Simon Mignolet failing to command his area effectively. Savage suggests Brendan Rodgers should drop expensive signing Dejan Lovren and instead play Kolo Toure against Chelsea. He also emphasizes the importance of full-backs contributing offensively while maintaining defensive balance. Savage believes Chelsea are currently far superior and expects them to win at Anfield. Regarding Steven Gerrard, Savage argues that despite his costly slip against Chelsea last season, Gerrard remains crucial to Liverpool's future. At 34, Gerrard faces both physical and mental challenges to maintain his performance level, but Savage insists he still has much to offer and should remain at Liverpool beyond this season.

A new £45 million educational facility is planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council intends to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock and was passionate about education. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," was an influential novelist, poet, journalist, and broadcaster, famous for works such as the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man. He passed away at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated after a sea mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered in the river. Residents within 500 meters were advised to stay indoors, and an exclusion zone was established both on land and at sea, affecting local ferry services. Authorities emphasized the evacuation was precautionary, as the mine's condition made it unclear how much explosive material remained. The Royal Navy decided to move the mine to a safer location before disposal. Local officials thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport has announced funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports ahead of Tokyo 2020, allocating £345m across 31 sports—£2m less than for Rio 2016. Cycling funding was reduced by over £4m, while badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby lost all funding. Badminton England strongly criticized the decision, highlighting their recent Olympic bronze medal and calling the funding removal "catastrophic." UK Sport defended the cuts as necessary prioritization to protect medal potential, aiming for 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Basketball, volleyball, and handball, previously defunded, criticized UK Sport for neglecting team sports despite a recent review recommending investment in performance pathways. Funding decisions for newly added Olympic and Paralympic sports, including baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton, remain pending, with £9m still unallocated.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff area will be demolished to make way for a new development consisting of a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine-storey and seven-storey), totaling 122 apartments. Despite strong objections from English Heritage and some residents who argued the buildings contributed to the area's historic character, councillors approved the project by a vote of seven to three, citing benefits to tourism and improved living conditions for older residents. The council received 246 letters supporting the plans, while 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society opposed the demolition.

Private Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was killed in Brecon after being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely during an off-duty night out. Vallely, who had been drinking heavily and boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon," attacked Boyd outside a bar, leaving him unconscious and later dragging his body away before fleeing. Vallely was convicted and awaits sentencing, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of involvement. Boyd's family described him as loving, caring, and full of life, and expressed deep grief over their loss. The community of Brecon was deeply shocked by the incident and showed strong support for Boyd's family.

Andrew Travers has left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council by mutual agreement following significant electoral errors, where voters were initially turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on the poll lists. Travers, who served for three and a half years, stated he enjoyed his tenure and believed the borough would continue to thrive. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily assume Travers' role. The council has launched an independent investigation into the incident, which will conclude by the end of May and examine arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum. Barnet Council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes, but voters questioned the fairness of the election results.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1, with Josh Gillies scoring first from a free-kick before Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham, also from a set-piece. Ryan Bowman secured Gateshead's victory with a headed goal from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half improvement and the quality of their winning goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment at his team's weaker second-half performance and missed opportunities.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of people aged over 60 across 96 countries, ranking Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb, in partnership with Airbus, is developing a large satellite constellation initially comprising 600 satellites, potentially expanding beyond 2,000, to provide global broadband connectivity, particularly targeting schools. To achieve this, Airbus is shifting from traditional, costly satellite manufacturing to high-volume, low-cost production methods similar to automotive assembly lines, aiming to produce satellites at under a million dollars each. Assembly lines have been established in Toulouse, France, with additional facilities planned in Florida. The ambitious launch schedule involves over 20 Soyuz rockets deploying clusters of satellites, aiming for around 300 satellites by early 2021, over 600 shortly thereafter, and more than 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb has already raised $1.7 billion in equity and is pursuing further financing. Registered in the UK's Channel Islands, OneWeb expects significant economic benefits for the UK and aims to set new standards in space debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit satellites within two years and incorporating hardware to facilitate removal of defunct satellites. While this new manufacturing approach could disrupt the satellite industry, specialized missions will still require traditional, high-cost methods.

The passage describes a dispute over public spending between the Scottish government and the UK government. Scottish Finance Minister John Swinney argues that the UK government's recent spending review has placed significant pressure on Scotland's public expenditure, claiming that Scotland's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with over £1bn in cuts still to come. Swinney emphasizes that despite these cuts, the Scottish government will protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and police services. In response, the UK government states that Scotland will have £390m more available next year, rising to £750m if underspending is included, and argues that Scotland benefits from the stability of the UK economy. Labour's Jackie Baillie criticizes Swinney for "anti-austerity posturing" and calls for a long-term budget with clear alternatives to austerity.

Many people with severe disabilities face significant challenges due to the lack of suitable toilet facilities, as standard accessible toilets often do not meet their needs. Changing Places toilets, which are larger and equipped with additional features such as benches and hoists, address these needs but are currently only recommended rather than compulsory in building regulations. Campaigners, including parents like Lorna Fillingham, are advocating for mandatory inclusion of Changing Places toilets in new large public buildings, highlighting the stress, isolation, and psychological impact caused by inadequate facilities. Although logistical and financial barriers exist, successful examples like Arsenal Football Club and the Principality Stadium demonstrate the positive impact of installing these facilities.

Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of imposing excessive rents, high fees, and overly long contracts on franchisees, preventing them from switching to competitors. They argue this practice leads to reduced consumer choice and higher prices at franchise locations compared to company-owned stores. The complaint is supported by unions including the Service Employees International Union (SEIU), which urges the Commission to investigate McDonald's alleged abuse of its dominant market position. McDonald's, which earned $9.27 billion from franchised restaurants globally in 2014, responded by stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees and is committed to supporting them. The European Commission will now review the complaint and may launch an investigation if it finds the allegations credible.

Joshua Martin, a 13-year-old from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve during an operation initially intended for his appendix. Doctors removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. Following his diagnosis, a social media hashtag "#prayforjosh," initiated by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father serves as pastoral staff, quickly went viral, gaining global attention and support. A mystery donor funded a large billboard displaying the hashtag in Holywood. Josh's family and friends have been overwhelmed by the international support and kindness shown through social media and community efforts.

The UK government has announced the closure of Brecon Barracks as part of a wider restructuring of military facilities. Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the decision, highlighting the barracks' historical significance since 1805 and its importance to the local economy and military tourism. Davies is launching a petition against the closure, although the barracks' 85 civilian and 90 military jobs are reportedly not at risk. Nearby facilities such as Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school will remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon stated the reorganisation includes creating a specialist infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, and confirmed closures of Cawdor Barracks in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but expressed concern about the uncertainty it creates for local communities.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit for the UK fishing industry. Fishing communities strongly supported Brexit, hoping to regain control over UK waters and improve their industry, which they felt suffered under the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). However, a House of Lords report highlights potential risks, noting that fishing represents only a small fraction of the UK's GDP and employment, and thus risks being marginalised in Brexit negotiations. The report emphasizes that continued access to EU markets is crucial, as most UK fish exports go to the EU, and warns that this market access may require allowing EU boats continued fishing rights in UK waters. It also stresses the importance of retaining certain CFP elements, such as scientifically-based quotas and international cooperation. Brexit could complicate fisheries management by potentially creating separate regimes for England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic, viewing Brexit as an opportunity for greater control and improved fisheries management. The UK government has expressed commitment to ensuring market access and reviewing fisheries management post-Brexit.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source behind leaks exposing extensive US surveillance programs. Snowden acted due to concerns over privacy, describing the scale of surveillance as "horrifying." The leaked documents showed that the US National Security Agency (NSA) had large-scale access to phone records, chat logs, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The NSA reportedly used a program called Prism, which allegedly provided "backdoor" access to servers of major technology companies like Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Apple, although these companies denied involvement. NSA officials defended the surveillance as necessary for national security, claiming it prevented terrorism, but critics questioned the extent and legality of the access. Privacy advocates expressed alarm, noting that US laws like the Patriot Act and FISA allowed authorities broad access to data stored in the US, affecting users worldwide. The EU expressed concern over the implications for European citizens, while UK officials neither confirmed nor denied involvement. Snowden emphasized his actions were motivated by a desire not to live in a society where all activities are monitored and recorded.

OpenAI is a research venture backed by prominent figures including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aiming to advance artificial intelligence (AI) for positive human impact without financial constraints. While some experts, including Musk and Stephen Hawking, have warned that AI could pose significant threats to humanity, others consider such risks remote. OpenAI emphasizes developing AI safely and beneficially, ensuring it aligns with human interests and is widely accessible. Only a small portion of the pledged $1 billion funding will be spent in the near future.

L/Bdr Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June, supported by an assistant. Despite a brain injury initially affecting his speech, he has recovered enough to speak unaided and retains his personality and humour. Parkinson spends significant time in rehabilitation and fundraising for military charities, notably the Pilgrim Bandits. Following his torch relay, he received overwhelming public support, including thousands of Facebook friend requests exceeding the site's 5,000-friend limit, increased mail, and numerous invitations. Facebook suggested he create a public page or use the subscribe feature due to his popularity.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained steady at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, after three consecutive years of increases. Real median household income declined by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. Meanwhile, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased slightly from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty had previously reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new contract extending his stay until 2019. Known for his short-format skills, Buttler holds England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Lancashire's cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent, his positive influence in the dressing room, and his key role in winning last year's T20 Blast final. Buttler, currently playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL, will return to Lancashire for their upcoming T20 Blast match against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting disposal. Interested bidders had until January 23 to register, with viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a final decision expected in spring. No preservation proposals have been submitted. The UK government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK recycler to assess domestic recycling capabilities. Conservative MP Penny Mordaunt expressed a preference for converting at least one frigate into a reef and diving attraction, highlighting potential tourism benefits. The Ministry of Defence stated it would consider all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers. Type 22 frigates were originally anti-submarine vessels but evolved into versatile surface combatants with advanced anti-surface, anti-submarine, anti-aircraft, and command capabilities. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3 million.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant instability due to racial and political tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. A coup in 1987 overthrew an Indian-dominated government, leading to political turmoil and economic damage, particularly to tourism. Another coup in 2000 involved the hostage-taking of Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister and his cabinet. Continued tensions led to a bloodless military takeover in 2006, Fiji's fourth coup in two decades. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to lack of democratic progress, but reinstated after democratic elections in 2014. The population, primarily on the islands of Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, consists mainly of indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal integration and deep informal segregation. Indo-Fijian numbers have declined due to emigration following political unrest, leaving indigenous Fijians as a slight majority. Fiji's economy relies heavily on sugar and tourism, supplemented by mining, services, and manufacturing, but persistent trade and budget deficits have made it heavily dependent on foreign aid.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is trying its best to meet the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline. He blamed delays on attacks by "terrorist groups" targeting weapon shipments. The US expressed concern over the slow progress, noting only 4% of Syria's declared chemical weapons have been removed so far. Meanwhile, Syria rejected US criticism of its use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, denying targeting civilians and accusing the US of supporting terrorists. Activists reported significant civilian casualties from barrel bomb attacks. Additionally, conflicting reports emerged regarding rebels' seizure of Aleppo's central prison, with activists claiming rebels had freed detainees, while Syrian state media insisted the attack was thwarted. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons acknowledged security concerns have slowed the chemical weapons removal process, but Syria reaffirmed its commitment to fulfilling its obligations.

Mukherjee's novel "The Lives of Others," set in 1960s Calcutta, is the bookmakers' favourite to win the Booker Prize, which for the first time is open to all authors writing in English regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes British authors Howard Jacobson and Ali Smith, Americans Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler, and Australian Richard Flanagan. Fowler's novel is the best-selling among the shortlisted titles. Jacobson, a previous winner, is nominated again but may face reluctance from judges to award him a second prize so soon after Hilary Mantel's double win. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with the ceremony broadcast by the BBC.

A celebrity, identified as PJS, is appealing to the UK Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal decision lifting a ban on media naming him in England and Wales. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish allegations of his extra-marital activities, but PJS argues for his right to privacy. Initially, a High Court judge refused an injunction, but the Court of Appeal later granted one. However, after widespread publication of the allegations abroad and online, the Court of Appeal judges concluded confidentiality was likely lost and lifted the ban. The Supreme Court will now consider whether to grant an appeal, and an interim injunction remains in place until the hearing concludes.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was recently purchased for £345.5 million. The new owners plan to address parking and traffic congestion issues, improve the appearance of retail units, and enhance common areas and facilities. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White supports these improvements, noting the park's importance as a gateway into the city and its current unattractive appearance. Paul Clarke from Crown Estates emphasized their commitment to revitalizing the park's overall quality and visitor experience.

The upcoming Disney film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a brief "gay moment" involving the character LeFou. Although homosexuality is illegal in Malaysia, the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit and gave it a "P13 parental guidance" rating. Disney delayed the film's release for content review, and a new release date has not yet been announced. The controversy drew criticism from netizens and even Malaysia's tourism minister, who called the potential ban "ridiculous." Local cinemas have begun offering refunds to customers who purchased advance tickets.

Landlords renting properties to more than three unrelated tenants must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost around £1,000. Southampton City Council estimates there are approximately 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area, despite potential fines of up to £20,000. Tenants frequently express concerns about eviction fears and poor living conditions, exacerbated by a shortage of affordable housing. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to properties of three storeys or more housing five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, licensing applies specifically to certain designated areas introduced in 2013 and 2015. While most landlords comply, a minority resist licensing, resulting in prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are attempting to avoid a second election by forming a minority government. Fianna Fáil has agreed to facilitate this minority government but refuses to support a formal programme for government. A key disagreement is over water charges, with Fianna Fáil demanding their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their continuation. A commission to examine the future of Irish Water is being considered. The recent election resulted in no party gaining a majority, with Fine Gael securing 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour seven, leaving TDs unable to elect a taoiseach.

The ferry Sorrento caught fire while traveling to Valencia, approximately 27 km from Mallorca. The blaze started on a car deck and quickly intensified, prompting a full evacuation onto lifeboats. Passengers and crew were rescued by another ferry, the Puglia, and taken back to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and transported to hospital by helicopter. Psychologists were dispatched to provide counseling to survivors. Authorities warned the damaged ferry might sink. The cause of the fire remains unclear.

The Electoral Commission reported concerns about duplicate voter registrations and allegations of double voting in the recent UK general election. A record 46.8 million people registered, with a high turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. However, out of 4.9 million voter registration applications submitted, only 1.4 million were new, indicating a significant number of duplicates (estimated between 30% and 70%).
