The Commission highlighted the lack of integration between local electoral registers and the online registration system, causing administrative and financial burdens. It recommended clearer online information and a verification system similar to those used in other countries. Although voting twice in general elections is illegal, some voters, such as students, can legally register in multiple constituencies. Labour cautioned against measures that could discourage young voters, emphasizing the need to avoid making registration harder for students and those with multiple residences.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player who starred at the University of Nebraska, died at age 40 in an apparent suicide while serving a prison sentence of over 30 years. Phillips had a troubled history, including convictions for assaulting teenagers with his car and attacking a former girlfriend. At the time of his death, he was awaiting trial for allegedly killing his former cellmate. His former coach described him as intelligent but troubled by anger and personal issues.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram serving as the official mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for good behaviour during an event marking the regiment's eighth anniversary. He received the honour from Brigadier Andrew Williams. Derby XXX is the 30th mascot ram in a tradition dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th century. He joined the regiment in February 2014, has his own army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season. His duties have included switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial event.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund at Anfield, advancing to the Europa League semi-finals in a match filled with emotion, drama, and excitement. Dortmund initially dominated, quickly scoring two goals, but Liverpool, inspired by manager Jurgen Klopp's passionate leadership and belief, mounted a remarkable comeback. Despite needing three goals in the final 33 minutes, Liverpool achieved this through strikes from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and a decisive injury-time header from Dejan Lovren. Klopp's philosophy of turning "doubters into believers" was evident, as Liverpool overcame adversity through sheer determination and the powerful support of their fans. The match atmosphere was extraordinary, marked by tributes to the Hillsborough disaster and an intense rendition of "You'll Never Walk Alone." While the victory highlighted Liverpool's attacking strengths and Klopp's positive influence, defensive vulnerabilities remain a concern. The result brings Liverpool closer to a potential Europa League title and Champions League qualification, echoing the spirit of their famous 2005 Champions League triumph.

The passage describes a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, involving representatives from the UK government and the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. UK minister Mr Davis emphasized the importance of regular meetings and information sharing to ensure the devolved administrations can voice their views during Brexit negotiations. However, Scottish representative Mr Russell criticized the UK government for lacking transparency and clarity regarding its strategic intentions, particularly concerning single market and customs union membership. He stressed that single market membership is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. Additionally, the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court regarding the triggering of Article 50.

Researchers at the University of Nottingham are closely monitoring a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal born in 1996. The study, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, aims to determine whether cloned animals age normally or experience premature aging due to the cloning process. Dolly herself died at six-and-a-half years old, raising concerns about early-onset age-related diseases like osteoarthritis. To investigate this, the sheep undergo extensive physical examinations, joint X-rays, and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on conditions commonly associated with aging: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Although the final results are pending publication, the cloned sheep, now around nine to ten years old, currently appear healthy.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten favourite Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters despite challenging soft ground conditions. Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori secured their fifth Musidora victory. Shutter Speed will next race at Chantilly in France rather than the Oaks at Epsom, where Gosden already has strong contenders Enable and Coronet. Gosden expressed concern about ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes, and will decide after inspecting the course. Meanwhile, Tasleet, trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, comfortably won the Duke of York Stakes.

The passage describes recent volatility in the British pound due to uncertainty surrounding the upcoming Brexit referendum. Initially, the pound weakened against major currencies like the dollar, euro, and yen, reflecting investor anxiety as polls indicated a tighter race between Leave and Remain campaigns. The volatility index reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis, highlighting heightened market uncertainty. Betting markets showed a reduced probability of a Remain vote, dropping from nearly 80% to 68.5%. Analysts predict further volatility as the referendum approaches, with hedge funds betting on further declines in sterling. Asian stock markets fell significantly, and London's FTSE 100 also ended lower, with Lloyds Banking Group notably affected. Leave campaigners argued that the pound's recent decline merely returned it to March levels and suggested a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters, supported by recent data showing a narrowing trade deficit due to increased exports.

Braintree (The Iron) currently sit sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off positions. Despite losing their third consecutive match against Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games, manager Cowley remains positive. He highlighted the difficulty of conceding an early goal after a long journey, praised his team's efforts, and emphasized the remarkable achievement of their part-time squad, acknowledging the challenge ahead but expressing determination to embrace and enjoy it.

From April 2015, Northern Ireland's local councils will assume responsibility for most planning decisions, shifting authority from the Planning Service to elected politicians. Supporters, such as Michael Corr from PLACE, view this as a positive opportunity for councils to shape local development and community plans. However, critics, including Friends of the Earth, express concerns about potential unfairness, discrimination, and lack of transparency, referencing historical issues from the 1960s. They stress the need for strict codes of conduct and transparency, particularly regarding political donations, to prevent favoritism and ensure fair planning decisions. The debate also touches on concerns about political donations and transparency, with some politicians worried about donor security and others questioning the relevance of current donation declaration limits.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, resulting in severe injuries and the amputation of her left back leg. Teenie's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA, where she is now learning to walk again. The Scottish SPCA described the incident as alarming and called for urgent implementation of air gun licensing by the Scottish government. Previously, a government consultation on licensing air weapons was opposed by 87% of respondents, who considered the proposal overly strict. The Scottish SPCA is appealing for information to identify the person responsible.

Liverpool have signed Belgian striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa on a long-term contract, making him their second most expensive signing after triggering his release clause. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, joins as Liverpool's seventh summer signing following the £49m sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Liverpool struggled for goals last season after selling Luis Suarez and dealing with Daniel Sturridge's injuries, prompting manager Brendan Rodgers to strengthen the attack with Benteke, Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup due to injury but returned strongly last season, expressed excitement about joining Liverpool and working with Rodgers. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge both praised Benteke's abilities and believe he will significantly improve Liverpool's attacking options.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, examined tablet use in 671 state and independent schools, finding no clear evidence that tablets directly improve academic performance. Tablets are increasingly common, used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% providing individual tablets for each pupil. Tablet use is highest in academy schools and is expected to double between 2014 and 2016. Although researchers cannot definitively link tablets to improved academic results, head teachers report positive impacts, including increased pupil motivation, family involvement, and engagement, especially among disadvantaged students. Tablets also reflect students' everyday technology use, with many pupils taking devices to bed for social media. Educators like Simon Mason advocate tablets for their portability, ease of use, and alignment with modern life and future workplaces.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs depicting children's lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. Curated by Kay Jones, the images provide both nostalgic glimpses of childhood play and reminders of harsher realities, such as child labor. The oldest photograph, from 1887, shows the Rollo children dressed for a fancy dress ball. Jones selected the images from hundreds of historical photographs, aiming to represent both positive and negative childhood experiences and illustrate how children's lives have changed over time. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, aged 27, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals, and may face his former club on 18 February. Anderson previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Meanwhile, striker Ruairi Keating, aged 21, joins after being recommended by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams, pending international clearance. Keating previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader-type player despite limited appearances for his age, and Keating as young, raw, and eager to prove himself. The Gulls currently sit four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six matches.

Bolivia has passed a law allowing children as young as 12 to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic realities as one of South America's poorest nations. The law also introduces harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera emphasized the need to balance international standards with local conditions, noting that over 500,000 Bolivian children already work to support their families. While the International Labour Organisation (ILO) generally prohibits child labour under age 15, it allows developing countries a minimum working age of 14. The ILO is currently reviewing Bolivia's new legislation to determine if it violates international child labour regulations.

Actress Rosie O'Donnell experienced a heart attack after feeling chest pain, nausea, and feverish symptoms following an incident helping a woman out of a car. After researching symptoms online, she took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. O'Donnell described her heart attack as a "widow maker" and urged women to recognize symptoms and immediately call emergency services, something she herself did not do.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed following a party in Kenton after a fight involving youths who had earlier been denied entry. The stabbing occurred around 00:30 GMT in an alleyway, and Che died about an hour later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed but remains stable in hospital. Police believe Che was specifically targeted, despite not being involved in the initial altercation. A 21-year-old man and two teenagers aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old was arrested for possession of an offensive weapon. Police are appealing for witnesses.

Denmark reorganised its cancer diagnosis approach after poor survival statistics highlighted delays in diagnosing less obvious cancer cases. A team from Wales visited Aarhus, Denmark, to study this new model. Denmark introduced three diagnostic routes: a fast-track system for clear cancer symptoms with strict time targets, diagnostic centres for unclear symptoms offering rapid tests, and "yes-no" centres for minor symptoms unlikely to be cancer but needing quick checks. These changes reduced delays, improved patient management, prevented unnecessary referrals, and significantly improved cancer survival rates. Wales, with a similar healthcare system, is considering adopting lessons from Denmark's approach, particularly the improved collaboration between GPs and specialists.

Powys council has been selected to replace the UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in overseeing estate agent regulation, receiving £170,000 annually for this role. Powys will have authority to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws. Complaints will still initially go to local trading standards departments, who may prosecute offenders or refer cases to Powys if breaches of the Estate Agents Act are suspected. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, hopes this role will demonstrate Powys' capability to handle additional contracts in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the NHS workforce after a Nuffield Trust review suggested nurses and pharmacists could take on additional tasks traditionally performed by doctors, helping address shortages and changing patient care needs. The report highlighted existing examples of nurses substituting for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs, emphasizing the shift towards managing long-term conditions. However, unions and medical associations cautioned against viewing this as a quick fix, stressing the importance of proper training, adequate funding, and maintaining high-quality doctor training and expertise.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath following a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing significant disruption to commuters and bus services. The road reopened at 14:00 GMT, and investigations into the collision are ongoing. First bus services gradually resumed normal operations, aiming for full restoration by the evening commute. Managing director James Freeman thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts during the incident.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that the Swansea tidal lagoon project would result in annual deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout migrating through local rivers. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the project's developer, strongly disputed these figures, claiming they lacked clear scientific basis and were unrealistic. TLP's own modelling suggested a worst-case scenario of only 2% fish mortality. NRW defended its estimates, stating they were based on extensive evidence, independently reviewed, and that their methodology had been shared with TLP. The £1.3bn Swansea lagoon is considered a test project for larger future lagoons around the Welsh coast. The Welsh Government supports the scheme but seeks clarity from the UK government, which is currently reviewing the project's viability.

Northern Ireland's Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), to strategically coordinate marketing efforts across government and private sectors. The agri-food industry, employing nearly 100,000 people, is considered crucial for Northern Ireland's economy. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the initiative, highlighting the sector's importance for export-led growth, but noted it could affect existing organizations, including her department, and expressed interest in further discussions with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust has invited the public to participate in planting thousands of native trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, as part of a UK-wide initiative commemorating those who died in WW1. The four-year project aims to plant millions of trees across four new woods, with Brackfield Wood specifically receiving 40,000 trees to honor the estimated 40,000 Irish lives lost in the conflict. The charity encourages local involvement, providing saplings and advising suitable footwear. The completed woodland will serve as a lasting tribute, offering a peaceful space for wildlife and reflection.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her thriller "Someone Else's Skin," praised for its powerful storytelling, tight writing, and effective handling of domestic violence and honour crime themes. The award was presented at Harrogate's annual crime writing festival, chaired this year by author Ann Cleeves. Additionally, US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her influential 23-year career creating the strong female detective VI Warshawski, a character described as a "game changer" for female protagonists. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers globally.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, will return to Worcestershire Rapids after previously suffering a broken finger in his second game for the county in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed disappointment at losing Santner last season, noting it significantly impacted their qualification hopes. Santner, who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, will rejoin the team after June's ICC Trophy in England and is eager to make up for lost time. Additionally, Worcestershire have signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, aged 47, was killed in Kiev in 2008 by a speeding car with stolen plates that did not stop. The coroner ruled his death an unlawful killing, noting overwhelming circumstantial evidence. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), who was 19 years younger, had returned to a restaurant for a glove at the time of the incident. Barry's family and a close friend believe he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run to allow Anna to inherit his assets. Anna attempted to claim his estate shortly after his death, sold his possessions, and was found to have been having an affair. Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011; however, the investigation remains open but inactive.

Charlie Fearns, from Merseyside, urgently requires experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital in the US, as the treatment is unavailable in the UK. After a previous transplant failed and no further treatment options remained in the UK, an anonymous donor has stepped forward to fully fund Charlie's treatment. His parents expressed deep gratitude and described feeling overwhelmed and ecstatic at the generosity of the unknown donor. With financial clearance now secured, Charlie's treatment is expected to begin shortly.

Apple has introduced enhanced security measures for its iCloud service following recent celebrity photo leaks, which were reportedly caused by hackers using third-party software to access user data. The new measures involve an optional two-step verification process, requiring users logging in from new devices to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or phone number. Previously, even with two-step verification enabled, attackers could still download complete backups using software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed Apple's new security implementation effectively blocks this method, and users now receive email notifications when backups are downloaded. However, concerns remain about the recovery key, which is difficult to remember and could be lost or stolen. Security experts suggest Apple should make two-factor authentication the default setting rather than optional, a recommendation Apple acknowledges by planning to encourage users more strongly to adopt two-factor authentication and stronger passwords.

Dan Groves indicated that details of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay and possibly become a club director have not yet been finalized. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, recently came under the ownership of multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed willingness to invest £10,000 weekly. The club also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright, known for finishing second in "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011, previously played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds.

Mr Ashley has been asked to provide evidence regarding worker treatment at his company, Sports Direct, following a BBC investigation into warehouse practices. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, invited Mr Ashley to testify publicly at Westminster, but Mr Ashley has not yet agreed to any proposed dates. The committee warned it may escalate the issue, potentially involving the House of Commons, if Mr Ashley does not respond by 21 March. Sports Direct previously promised to review worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight, but has not commented on the current situation.

The passage describes a report titled "Putin. War," originally initiated by murdered Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and later completed by his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin. The report compiles existing evidence from Russian and foreign media to argue that Russian President Vladimir Putin deliberately orchestrated the conflict in eastern Ukraine for personal political gain. It claims Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial to the separatists' victories, contradicting Russia's official stance that any Russian fighters were merely volunteers. The report also highlights the human and economic costs, including Russia's estimated spending of around $1 billion on the conflict and the salaries paid to volunteer soldiers. Despite detailed documentation, including military unit names and weaponry photos, the authors acknowledge difficulties in verification and distribution, as well as limited public interest. Previous reports by Nemtsov similarly failed to spark significant protests against Putin, despite their critical content.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

The passage describes tensions between the UK government and the Welsh administration regarding the drafting and publication of the Article 50 letter initiating Brexit. Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones expressed frustration at not being consulted or shown the letter beforehand, criticizing the UK government for disrespecting devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered this criticism, stating that discussions had occurred previously and that the UK government must act in the interests of the entire UK. Prime Minister Theresa May's letter to Donald Tusk promised consultation on returning powers from the EU to devolved administrations, suggesting increased decision-making powers for Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. However, uncertainty remains about which specific powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them, with Carwyn Jones expressing concern about future financial support.

Two cars were damaged during an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the attacks on PSNI officers and the local community. Police stated they were attacked while performing their duties and urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr Charney, founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was removed from his position due to employee complaints, accusations of misuse of company funds, and allegations of sexual harassment and discriminatory behavior. The company's board stated they do not expect him to return, citing evidence of inappropriate emails and racially derogatory remarks. Charney's lawyer denies these claims, accusing the company of invading his privacy and attempting extortion. Charney has filed a defamation lawsuit against the company, which responded by highlighting his misconduct and the risks he poses. Recently, American Apparel obtained a restraining order preventing Charney from making negative public statements or attempting to remove board members.

Great Britain will face Greece at the Copper Box in their only home game before competing at FIBA EuroBasket 2017. Previously, Greece defeated GB 92-64 in Patras, but Greece will now be missing three key players, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing in Stratford and emphasized the importance of this match as preparation for EuroBasket. After this game, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket begins in Istanbul, Turkey, in early September. Coverage of the game will be available on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app.

The passage describes the author's experience covering the launch of Apple's first iPhone, highlighting initial skepticism and criticism about the media attention it received. Despite initial doubts, the author acknowledges that the iPhone proved revolutionary, transforming mobile technology by making powerful computing accessible to billions, reshaping photography, and changing how people interact with technology. The author reflects that Steve Jobs' innovation was not just in creating a smartphone, but in designing an intuitive user interface that encouraged widespread adoption. The passage concludes by recognizing the iPhone launch as a pivotal moment marking the beginning of the mobile connected era.

Several cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting antifreeze, a toxic substance. The latest victim, a seven-month-old cat named Meereen, died after showing symptoms including shivering and foaming at the mouth. The RSPCA confirmed antifreeze poisoning but stated it was unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. Inspector Andy Bostock urged residents to safely store chemicals and clean up antifreeze spills to prevent further incidents.

The passage describes Greece's economic and political situation under the Syriza government, highlighting the paradox of public calm despite the government's acceptance of austerity measures previously opposed. Tourism remains strong, possibly due to instability elsewhere. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, despite reversing his stance and agreeing to harsh creditor demands—including VAT hikes, pension cuts, privatizations, and market liberalization—remains popular. The shift is attributed to Greece's near-collapse in July, which forced acceptance of creditor terms for an €86 billion bailout. However, Greece faces severe economic hardship, with banks partially closed and businesses unable to secure credit. The author argues that for the bailout to succeed, creditors—particularly Brussels and Berlin—must avoid triumphalism and significantly reduce Greece's unsustainable debt burden.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes featuring Dame Barbara's character, Peggy Mitchell, who will die from cancer. Kemp, who previously played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, agreed to return to reunite the Mitchell family for Peggy's emotional farewell. Peggy recently returned to inform her son Phil that her cancer had returned, and producers confirmed her character's death will air in the spring. Kemp expressed enthusiasm about filming these significant episodes, and the show's executive producer highlighted the reunion of the Mitchell brothers as a special opportunity to showcase actors Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and murdered 24-year-old Alice Ruggles after becoming obsessed with her. Alice's parents described their shock and guilt upon learning of her death, acknowledging they underestimated the seriousness of the stalking despite clear signs. They have since established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers and to honor Alice's vibrant personality. Dhillon was convicted of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

EDF, a French energy firm, approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant in Somerset, UK, with one-third of the investment coming from Chinese investors. However, the UK government unexpectedly delayed its final approval, citing the need for careful consideration. Critics have raised concerns about environmental impacts, escalating costs, and foreign involvement. EDF has faced internal financial concerns, with key executives resigning over the project's risks. Industry representatives urged swift government action, warning delays could threaten energy supply and climate commitments. Environmental groups argued the project offers poor value and advocated for renewable energy investment instead. Hinkley Point C is expected to supply 7% of the UK's electricity.

The passage discusses concerns raised by family lawyers regarding a newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales, which explicitly asks applicants to name the person their spouse committed adultery with. Lawyers argue that naming a third party typically increases conflict and complexity, despite the Ministry of Justice clarifying there is no obligation to do so. Although the form's guidance states naming the third party is "not normally necessary," experts fear applicants will overlook or ignore this advice, potentially causing delays, increased costs, and negative perceptions from judges. Statistics from 2015 show adultery accounted for 12,148 of over 100,000 divorces granted. The Ministry of Justice emphasizes that naming a third party has always been optional, but the new form makes this option more explicit.

The passage discusses tensions between commercial forestry and environmental priorities in Wales. Britain is the world's third-largest importer of wood, and the Welsh timber industry contributes over £450 million annually to the economy. However, since 2001, at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost and need replanting. The Welsh government aims for a balanced approach, promoting native broadleaf species and recreational access, while forestry industry representatives argue that environmental concerns overshadow commercial timber production. Confor, representing forestry businesses, criticizes the current system as overly bureaucratic and insufficient, noting that only 90 hectares were planted last year compared to the 20,000 hectares annually needed to meet government targets.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street around 16:40. Emergency services responded, and he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is reported as serious.

Veterans of the Arctic Convoys, who transported vital supplies from Britain to the Soviet Union during World War II under harsh conditions and constant threat, have been awarded Russia's Ushakov medals. Initially, the British Foreign Office blocked the medals due to rules against accepting foreign awards for actions older than five years. However, after a campaign and the creation of Britain's own Arctic Star medal in 2012, an exception was made, allowing Russia to honor the veterans. The convoys were crucial in supplying the Soviet Union, enabling victory on the Eastern Front, but came at a heavy cost, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. Veterans expressed humility and gratitude, recalling Churchill's description of the convoys as "the worst journey in the world."

HM Inspectorate of Probation identified significant issues with the UK's unpaid work sentencing scheme ("community payback"), including delays in offenders starting their work, poor enforcement when offenders failed to attend, and inadequate organisation. Inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, finding examples such as an offender completing only 16 hours of work in 17 months. Although some offenders viewed their sentences positively and gained useful skills, the report concluded that overall management and delivery were insufficient. The report made 15 recommendations, urging better enforcement, clearer objectives tailored to offenders' circumstances, and improved organisation. The Ministry of Justice accepted all recommendations and stated it was already taking action to address these issues.

The passage discusses accusations of hypocrisy against comedian Russell Brand, who campaigns for economic and political revolution to help poorer people, yet lives in a luxurious home himself. Brand has faced repeated criticism for this apparent contradiction, notably highlighted by a front-page headline in The Sun. When confronted by a reporter about his own expensive accommodation, Brand reacted negatively. He acknowledges the validity of the criticism, admitting his wealth and fame, but argues that personal change alone is insufficient without systemic reform. Brand emphasizes that despite his personal contradictions, economic inequality remains a critical issue that must be addressed.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome through his competitive and controversial approach, drawing criticism from the scientific community for his disregard of traditional conventions. Initially uninterested in academics, his experiences as a medic in Vietnam inspired him to pursue medical research with urgency. He pioneered faster gene sequencing methods by focusing on RNA rather than DNA, leading to breakthroughs such as sequencing the first complete genome of a free-living organism. After founding Celera Genomics, he competed directly with the public human genome project, publishing results simultaneously in 2001. Financially successful, he established the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006, which created the first synthetic life form, "Synthia," aiming to revolutionize industry and environmental sustainability. Additionally, he has conducted extensive marine genetic research, collecting and sequencing oceanic microbes to better understand genetic evolution and function.

Researchers found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home, and half of parents reported their children requested these foods at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. The study, commissioned by England's School Food Trust following a Mumsnet survey, involved about 1,000 parents, 628 of whom had children eating school lunches. School meals, now subject to strict nutritional guidelines, are seen as beneficial in encouraging children to try new foods and eat healthier, partly due to positive peer influence. Currently, around 40% of primary school children in England and about 46% in Scotland eat school lunches.

Morata, aged 23, joined Juventus from Real Madrid in 2014, with Real retaining an option to buy him back for up to 30 million euros. He scored 27 goals in two seasons at Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in consecutive Champions League finals, scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat. Morata, previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, is currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016, where he has scored three goals. He began his career at Real Madrid, debuting at 18 and scoring 10 goals before moving to Italy.

Wilson returned to Championship club Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, making 51 appearances during his second stint before being released in May. The 30-year-old previously spent four seasons at Forest before joining Celtic, and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

British supermarket giant Tesco is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy food chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm. Fresh & Easy, which has consistently lost money since its launch in 2007, operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona. Around 4,000 of its 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while approximately 50 stores are expected to close. Tesco will loan around £80 million to the new business and incur a total cost of £150 million to dispose of the brand, though part of this amount may be repaid. Additionally, Tesco retains an option to buy a stake if the business becomes profitable under Yucaipa's management. This move follows Tesco's first reported annual profit decline in 20 years.
He initially faced racial abuse but overcame it, briefly considered representing France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Between the late 1960s/early 1970s and the late 2000s, glaciers in the French Alps shrank from approximately 375 sq km to about 275 sq km, representing a 26% loss. This research, presented at the American Geophysical Union meeting by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie, utilized historical maps, satellite imagery, aerial photographs, and manual verification to accurately assess glacier coverage. The retreat has accelerated since the mid-1980s and is uneven across the region, with southern sectors experiencing greater losses due to lower elevations and different climatic conditions. The northern Alps, including the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, have seen comparatively smaller reductions. Similar glacier retreats have been observed elsewhere in the Alps, notably in Switzerland.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five of their qualifiers and faces Iceland next, knowing a victory would nearly guarantee their place at the finals in the Netherlands. Forward Lisa Evans emphasizes the emotional importance of qualifying after narrowly missing out on Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making their upcoming matches crucial for deciding the group winner. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, highlights the advantage of having many Scottish players competing abroad, noting that exposure to top leagues like Germany's Bundesliga significantly benefits the national team. She also describes her recent Bundesliga title celebration alongside Bayern Munich's men's team as an extraordinary experience.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in western England following allegations of online harassment made by a woman in south London. The harassment reportedly occurred over two years and involved tweets, which Campbell insists were non-threatening and remain publicly visible. Campbell, who was released on bail pending further inquiries, accused media coverage of encouraging speculation through innuendo. Police confirmed they are investigating the allegations, and Campbell stated he would reduce his online activity temporarily.

Peta has proposed replacing Skegness's traditional mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a fish mascot and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing that the current mascot symbolizes animal cruelty. The Jolly Fisherman, originally commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway, has become synonymous with Skegness. Dawn Carr from Peta claims the mascot evokes images of cruelty towards fish and suggests a rebranding to position Skegness as a progressive, animal-friendly destination. However, Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, believes the mascot is beloved and does not portray cruelty, indicating that while the council will consider the suggestion, there is unlikely to be strong support for changing the mascot.

Scotland secured a convincing victory over Georgia, despite Georgia initially leading through an early try by Vasil Lobzhanidze. Scotland quickly responded with tries from Tommy Seymour, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg, Hamish Watson, and a penalty try, establishing a commanding lead by halftime. Lobzhanidze scored again for Georgia after a powerful scrum, but Scotland maintained dominance, with Hogg adding another try following a swift counter-attack. Scotland's Greig Laidlaw was instrumental, converting multiple tries and penalties. Despite Georgia's strong scrum causing Scotland some issues, including a yellow card for Moray Low, Scotland finished strongly, winning comfortably. Scotland coach Vern Cotter praised his team's pragmatic approach and effective game management.

Widnes defeated Castleford in a closely contested match, initially leading 14-6 at half-time through tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, with Paddy Flynn scoring for Castleford against his parent club. Widnes extended their lead to 38-12 early in the second half with further tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Castleford rallied late with three quick tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's third try, but Widnes held on for victory. This result ended Widnes' poor run of form, moving them into seventh place, one point behind sixth-placed Castleford, who suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detainee held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002, was released after a US review panel concluded he no longer posed a significant threat. Arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban—charges he denies—he had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Following his release, he returned to Kuwait, where he will spend at least one year in a militant rehabilitation center. His release reduces the number of detainees at Guantanamo to 148. The Kuwaiti government had actively sought the release of its citizens from Guantanamo, and President Obama has repeatedly promised to close the facility.

Thousands attended Anzac Day commemorations in London, including an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade, and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day marks the first major World War One battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces, specifically commemorating the Gallipoli landings. The first London commemoration occurred in 1916, attended by King George V. Since then, the event has become significant for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders, honouring their countrymen and women's sacrifices in all wars. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer highlighted the courage and heroism of Anzac troops. Ceremonies included prayers by schoolchildren, national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK, and participation by veterans, service personnel, and their families. The Gallipoli campaign was a bloody eight-month operation aimed at forcing the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, aged 30, has joined St Mirren from Premiership club Well for a second spell and could debut against Alloa in the Championship on Saturday. Last season, he scored nine goals for Dundee and has mainly appeared as a substitute this term. Clarkson, who previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, has nearly 400 senior club appearances and was capped twice by Scotland in 2008, scoring once. He states he is fully fit and eager to help St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, improve their league position.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Despite initial concerns about the workers' pension scheme, Unite union confirmed that existing pension agreements will be honored and remain unaffected by the takeover. The new owner intends to restore profitability by investing more, reducing costs, and using spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The passage describes a council scrutiny meeting addressing problems with a newly launched chain ferry at Cowes. Council leader Dave Stewart acknowledged the ferry's problematic start, including breakdowns, groundings, suspension due to training issues, and vehicle damage. He announced free crossings until July 2 and ordered an audit review. Local businesses, suffering from lost trade, questioned compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward said was under consideration. Ward described the ferry as a prototype with expected initial issues, noting electrical problems had been fixed, ramp extensions were authorized to prevent vehicle damage, and grounding issues had been resolved.

The passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry. Fishing communities strongly supported Brexit, hoping to regain control over UK waters and improve their industry, which they felt was harmed by the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). However, a House of Lords report warns that fishing, despite its symbolic importance, might become marginalised in broader Brexit negotiations due to its small economic size. The report highlights complexities, including shared fish stocks with EU states, the UK's reliance on EU markets for exports, and the possibility that continued market access may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. It also notes the risk of fragmented fisheries management across the UK's devolved nations post-Brexit. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic, seeing Brexit as an opportunity for improved quotas, sustainable management, and greater economic benefits for coastal communities. The UK government acknowledges these opportunities while emphasizing the importance of sustainable fisheries management and continued market access.

Timothy Geaney admitted to obtaining inappropriate images of young boys between April 2004 and February 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and was required to participate in a special programme for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching register due to conduct deemed fundamentally incompatible with teaching standards. The panel noted the prolonged nature of his offenses, the volume of images, and the lack of remedial action, concluding there was a strong likelihood of recurrence. Geaney, aged 69 at sentencing, was prohibited from reapplying to the teaching register for two years.

On 2 March, a fire occurred at a waste management site on Duncan Street, causing travel delays and reduced train services. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and decided to revoke its environmental permit effective from 7 August, pending any appeal. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had previously raised concerns about potential fire impacts, prompting joint inspections with the EA. Although the site operators, Asset and Land Group, were considered broadly compliant with fire safety laws, the cause of the fire remains undetermined. The company must remove all waste from the site.

Syria has missed a deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, citing security issues after a shipment was attacked by terrorist groups, according to Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad. He rejected US criticism of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, despite reports from activist groups claiming significant civilian casualties. Meanwhile, conflicting reports emerged about rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, with activists claiming rebels had freed detainees, while Syrian state media denied this. The US expressed concern over delays in Syria's chemical weapons removal, noting only 4% of the stockpile had been shipped out so far. Russia urged Syria to complete the transfer by March 1, and Syria reaffirmed its commitment to meeting its obligations.

England defeated Pakistan convincingly at Old Trafford, leveling the Test series with a day to spare. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, achieving their second-largest victory over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match after scoring 254 and an unbeaten 71, taking four catches, and claiming a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance as extraordinary. Pakistan struggled, dismissed for 198 and 234, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq surpassing 50 in the first two Tests. Misbah acknowledged poor shot selection and low confidence, while commentators praised England's disciplined performance. The third Test begins on 3 August at Edgbaston.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, their families, and friends to inform recommendations aimed at care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of highlighting both good practices and the negative impacts of poor care, noting significant variations in care quality across Wales. Her review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that no care provider experts have been included on the advisory panel, suggesting this limits opportunities for partnership and full sector engagement.

Former Aberdeen midfielder Paul Sheerin, aged 39, has been appointed at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin previously served as player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, guiding them to their first national trophy—the Scottish Third Division title—in 2011, although the club was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser stated that manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin following a thorough selection process, and Arbroath chairman John Christison supported Sheerin's decision to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin's playing career included several Scottish clubs, a stint in Sweden with Östersunds, and a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

After Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will temporarily manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with former Derby manager Paul Clement as their preferred choice. Curtis emphasizes the importance of selecting someone capable of avoiding relegation, warning that returning from the Championship would be challenging. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after nearly facing bankruptcy and relegation from the Football League in 2003, had established a reputation for attractive, possession-based football. Curtis believes the club has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements. Despite this, Curtis feels the current squad is capable of staying up and stresses the importance of players understanding the club's history and significance to the local community.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome through competitive and controversial methods, drawing criticism from the scientific community for his unconventional approach and perceived arrogance. After serving in Vietnam, he pursued medical research, becoming a pioneer in genomics by shifting focus from DNA to RNA, greatly speeding up gene sequencing. He founded private research institutions, notably Celera Genomics, which completed the human genome alongside the public project in 2001. Later, he established the J Craig Venter Institute, creating the first synthetic life form, "Synthia," and conducting extensive marine genetic research. Despite controversy, Venter believes synthetic organisms could revolutionize industry and environmental sustainability.

The Sutton Trust report, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, criticizes England's apprenticeship system as low-quality, overly complex, and insufficiently focused on young people. It highlights that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeships are at level three (A-level equivalent), and most apprenticeships since 2010 have been below this level, targeting older workers already employed. Compared to Germany, where apprenticeships are more respected, widely offered, and predominantly aimed at young people, England's system is fragmented, offering 18,000 different qualifications versus Germany's 330. The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, recommending up to 300,000 new starts annually, primarily at level three or higher, lasting at least three years. It also suggests limiting lower-level apprenticeships and improving vocational education quality and career guidance. The Department for Education states it is already reforming apprenticeships to raise standards, while the Association of Colleges agrees with the need for improvement but cautions that some existing level two apprenticeships remain valuable and should be preserved.

Britain's Sarah Storey won a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. At 37, Storey aims for further Paralympic success at the upcoming Rio Games. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, holding 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across swimming and cycling from six Paralympics, and has now secured 21 world titles. Storey began her career as a swimmer, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United have been expelled from the Football Conference due to severe financial difficulties, failing to meet multiple extended deadlines to pay debts totaling approximately £148,000 owed to football creditors. Despite a dramatic final-day victory that initially secured their Conference Premier status, their financial issues led to their expulsion, allowing Chester to be reinstated. The club, recently taken over by businessman Tommy Agombar, had previously rejected an offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club and clear debts. Hereford's financial troubles, worsened by declining attendance since relegation from the Football League in 2012, leave them owing significant sums, including over £70,000 in unpaid taxes.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 senior caps for England after debuting in 2009, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only briefly at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46) and scored his sole international goal against Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner described his decision to retire from international football as one based on common sense, wishing success to the team and staff.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it globally for around 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, notably the first complete Mozart symphonies cycle on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London. He also served as artistic director for festivals, taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities, and was praised for his generosity, intellect, and dedication to historically informed music. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date.

A boy from Northern Ireland had to leave mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping, and his family requested a place for him at a special school. However, all special schools in their area were full, leaving him isolated at home and confused about why he could not attend school like his siblings. Recently, an extra classroom assistant was hired at a local special school, raising hopes he may soon start attending. His mother remains concerned that other families will face similar issues due to overcrowding in special schools. The Education Authority declined to comment on individual cases but stated they are reviewing special school provision to better meet children's needs from 2016 onwards.

Newport Gwent Dragons are facing a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), who intend to use Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue. Newport County football club currently holds a lease at Rodney Parade until 2023, with priority for fixtures if they remain in the Football League. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey stated that both Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their existing agreements, and the WRU has been informed of this. However, the WRU's plan to install an artificial surface conflicts with Football League rules. Newport County, who returned to the Football League in 2013, are currently fighting relegation from League Two, and club representative Foxall emphasized that relegation would be devastating for both fans and the city.

The passage describes the personal experiences of an individual from Sierra Leone who was kidnapped at age 15 by Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during the civil war, forced into violence, drug use, and atrocities. After escaping, he struggled in the capital, was imprisoned, and then rehabilitated through a preacher named Richard Cole and his Lifeline Nehemiah project. Inspired by Cole, he later became involved in fighting the Ebola crisis in 2014, educating over 10,000 people, providing food and supplies to 11,000, and establishing an Ebola treatment clinic despite limited resources. The passage concludes with his reflections on personal transformation, regret for past actions, and his belief in investing in young people to rebuild the nation and the world. The Ebola outbreak resulted in 11,314 deaths overall, including 3,955 in Sierra Leone.

A collection of approximately 80,000 artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs belonging to the Wedgwood Museum faced auction to cover pension debts inherited after Waterford Wedgwood plc collapsed in 2009. A public fundraising campaign launched by the Art Fund successfully reached its target within a month, ensuring the collection remains on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum. This outcome prevented the collection from being dispersed globally and preserved its cultural significance for Staffordshire and Britain.

Reality TV personality Mark Wright is reportedly close to acquiring a 20% stake in Billericay Football Club, potentially becoming a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, recently came under the ownership of multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed willingness to invest £10,000 weekly. The club also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright previously played non-league football and was runner-up on "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt after 12 minutes, but Colchester equalised shortly after through Kurtis Guthrie following a corner. Both teams had chances to win, with Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making key saves. Colchester ended the match with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the disused Fawley power station chimney into a major attraction, making it the tallest south of London's Shard. The chimney, part of a former oil-fired power station that operated from 1971 until its closure in 2013, will become the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development. Plans include a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The 300-acre site was acquired by Fawley Waterside in 2016, and construction could begin in 2018 pending planning approval. Developers emphasize the chimney's iconic status and potential for cost-effective redevelopment compared to similar attractions.

At the Hong Kong championships, Great Britain's Chris Latham secured a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, following Elinor Barker's earlier silver medal in the women's scratch. Latham finished behind Poland's Adrian Teklinski, who took gold, and Germany's Lucass Liss, who earned silver. GB narrowly missed another bronze in the men's team pursuit, losing to Italy. Britain's women's team pursuit squad, featuring Elinor Barker alongside younger riders, finished fifth and did not qualify for a medal race, though Barker remained optimistic about their future potential. Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated early in the women's sprint event but will compete in two more events. Overall, the British team showed mixed results, with some promising performances and areas identified for improvement ahead of future competitions.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes featuring Dame Barbara's character, Peggy Mitchell, who will die from cancer. Kemp, who previously played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, agreed to return to reunite the Mitchell family and honor Barbara, a close friend. Peggy recently returned to inform her son Phil that her cancer had returned, and emotional scenes depicting her death will air in the spring. The reunion of the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil, is expected to create memorable episodes, highlighting their complex family history and relationships.

Sadio Mane scored two quick goals as Liverpool defeated second-placed Tottenham Hotspur at Anfield. Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's poor start and lack of desire, stating it would be difficult to challenge for the Premier League title if Chelsea extended their lead to 12 points. Spurs have struggled away from home, winning only twice since September and just once in their last 17 away matches against top-six teams. Former player Danny Murphy highlighted Spurs' defensive issues, tactical inconsistency, and lack of pace and confidence away from home, emphasizing the need for rapid improvement.

In Nigeria's recent elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory, winning 19 out of 28 governorships, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. This follows the PDP's first-ever presidential election loss last month, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated as president on May 29. The PDP lost key northern states, including Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa, but retained control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and mostly southeastern states. Elections in Taraba remain outstanding, while Imo state's election was inconclusive. The APC's gains have reduced the PDP to a regional party, strong mainly in the southeast and Niger Delta. However, the APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, raising concerns about potential disruptions to oil production and revenue. Although violence marred elections in some areas, overall the elections were more peaceful than previous ones, suggesting a maturing democracy. The PDP's defeat was attributed to voter desire for change, corruption allegations, defections to the APC, and perceived failures in addressing the Islamist insurgency in the northeast.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will introduce an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online content such as videos, band interviews, and ticket purchasing through signs and posters. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan stated that this new feature enhances visitor experience and enables global audiences to engage with the festival remotely.

Ofsted rated several Birmingham schools inadequate, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, Golden Hillock, and Saltley School, following allegations of a hardline Muslim takeover known as the "Trojan Horse" affair. As a result, Park View and Nansen Primary will have their funding agreements terminated, potentially removing Park View Educational Trust from managing them. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock received warnings to address breaches promptly or face similar consequences. Issues identified included inadequate safeguarding against extremism, failure to promote pupils' spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development, and discriminatory practices such as gender segregation and unfair treatment of non-Muslims. A head teacher described feeling isolated and undermined by parents until the Trojan Horse allegations became public. Birmingham City Council plans to install a temporary governing board at Saltley School, while Park View intends to challenge Ofsted's findings legally. Parents have criticized Ofsted's reports as biased and unfair, calling for dialogue with education authorities.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 due to fluid build-up in his brain, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Optometrist Honey Rose is accused of gross negligence manslaughter for allegedly failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution argues that her conduct fell significantly below expected professional standards, claiming Vinnie's death was preventable had she performed her duties properly. Ms Rose denies the charge, and the trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he met online, filming the encounters, and sending explicit material to the victim's sister and father. He denied the charges but was convicted after a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court. The case was referred to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its severity. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was placed on the sex offenders register and assessed as posing a moderate risk of re-offending. The judge emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's condemnation of his actions.

Ireland scored 165-5 in a T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 not out), and captain William Porterfield (39) contributing significantly. Afghanistan successfully chased the target, reaching 171-4 with two overs remaining, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). Ireland faced early trouble losing opener Paul Stirling for a duck, and captain Porterfield felt they fell short of their desired total and bowling execution. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2 wickets, the only bowler to claim multiple wickets. Ireland also suffered a setback with paceman Boyd Rankin missing the T20 series due to a back injury, though he is expected to return for the upcoming ODI series starting on March 15. The teams will meet again for the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona is under investigation regarding Neymar's transfer from Santos, initially reported at £48.6m, but later revealed to have cost the club £106.8m when including additional fees and payments. The club denies wrongdoing but has voluntarily paid an extra €13.55m in taxes to address potential discrepancies and protect its reputation. Former club president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of financial misconduct, which he denies. Investigations continue, and no confirmation has been given on whether the case will be dropped following Barcelona's payment. Neymar has scored seven league goals and three Champions League goals this season.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found murdered on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both aged 21, have been charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty. UK Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to review the investigation and have now completed their work, returning to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns regarding the Thai investigation, particularly about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of suspects. Thai police maintain that DNA evidence links the suspects to the crime.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five qualifiers so far and faces Iceland next, knowing a victory would nearly guarantee qualification for their first major finals. Forward Lisa Evans emphasizes the emotional importance of qualifying after previous near misses in Euro 2013 and the World Cup. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making their upcoming matches crucial. Evans, who recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, highlights the benefits of Scottish players competing abroad, noting it brings valuable experience and diversity to the national team.

Apple has introduced security improvements to its iCloud service following recent celebrity photo leaks, which were reportedly enabled by third-party software exploiting vulnerabilities. The updated security measure involves two-step verification, requiring users logging in from new devices to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or phone number, or use a 14-character recovery key if the trusted device is unavailable. Previously, attackers could bypass two-step verification by downloading backups using Elcomsoft's forensic software. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed Apple's new measures effectively block this method. However, he expressed concerns about the recovery key being easily lost or stolen. Security experts suggest Apple should make two-factor authentication the default setting rather than optional. Apple CEO Tim Cook acknowledged the need to increase user awareness and encourage stronger security practices.

UKIP, which won the election, spent £2,956,737 on its campaign, amounting to 68p per vote. The Conservatives spent slightly more (£2,980,815), equating to 79p per vote. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote), while the Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) and lost 11 of their 12 MEPs. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP spent £267,372. Altogether, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087, with all except Labour increasing their spending compared to the 2009 election.

Centre-back Anderson, aged 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. Anderson previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, and may face his former club on 18 February. Meanwhile, striker Ruairi Keating, aged 21, joins after being recommended by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams, pending international clearance. Keating previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader-type player despite limited appearances, and Keating as young, raw, and eager. The Gulls currently sit four points above relegation, having won just one of their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died shortly after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Veterinary staff confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur even in horses without underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia and overheating, he had never collapsed before and displayed no such symptoms on the day of his death. The horse had notable past victories, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described Many Clouds as the "horse of a lifetime." Despite previous concerns about overheating, authorities concluded that his death was due to a rare haemorrhage unrelated to any significant underlying health condition.

The passage describes emotional farewells from several veteran MSPs who are stepping down ahead of the Scottish parliamentary election on May 5. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during speeches by former First Minister Alex Salmond and Labour MSP Duncan McNeil. Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity rather than division, praised the parliament's growing responsibilities, and humorously acknowledged competition from the UK budget announcement and Cheltenham races. He concluded by highlighting the honor of serving Scotland. Duncan McNeil, who served since 1999, urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also stepped down, humorously noting she would miss interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage describes casting and production details for the live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson will star as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and an unnamed star as Mrs Potts, a role originally voiced by Angela Lansbury. Directed by Bill Condon, filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios, with the film scheduled for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions regarding potential criminal charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, in which 96 football fans died. Last year, new inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed, and evidence involving 23 suspects was referred to the CPS. Of these, 15 suspects relate to the causes of the disaster, while eight involve police conduct afterward. Victims' relatives, who have endured a lengthy struggle for accountability, will be informed privately of the CPS decisions. Margaret Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed hope that this marks the final stage of their long journey, emphasizing the families' determination to achieve accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has recently experienced multiple incidents involving packages being thrown over its walls. A former inmate described the prison as notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident reported witnessing several incidents herself. Although a former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, the Ministry of Justice stated there was no evidence of drone activity at Chelmsford. The Ministry acknowledged the issue, noting staff efforts to prevent contraband, but admitted more action was needed. New laws have been introduced, allowing prison smugglers to face up to two years in jail.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Wright, who failed to stop at a red light, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn, who had been helping pedestrians cross the road, is now receiving residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse in court, stating he was shocked and deeply affected by the incident. The trial is ongoing.

Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir will miss next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies, as her exams are scheduled shortly after the event. The 24-year-old athlete, who recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, expressed disappointment at missing the opportunity to represent Scotland but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. She mentioned the possibility of competing at the World Indoor Championships in March and believes she has potential for two or three more Olympic appearances. Muir recently set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5000m event.

Trevor Deely, aged 22, disappeared in December 2000 after attending a Christmas party. Recent developments include a renewed search involving excavations at a woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, expected to last several weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed the case and enhanced CCTV footage showing Deely speaking with an unidentified man dressed in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. Detectives believe this same man was later seen following Deely on Haddington Road. Gardaí have appealed again for this unidentified individual to come forward.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th after a two-year injury absence, defeated Swiss player Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3. This marked Del Potro's first Grand Slam appearance since 2014 due to multiple wrist surgeries. He expressed joy at returning to tennis after a difficult period. Del Potro will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. In the same half of the draw, Australia's Nick Kyrgios overcame Dustin Brown in a rain-interrupted five-set match and will face Feliciano Lopez, who also won a five-set match against Fabio Fognini. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga secured straightforward victories in their matches.

Tunisia and Morocco both faced challenges regarding their participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia risked expulsion after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea. They later apologized, resolving the dispute. Morocco was initially banned after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban and significantly reduced their fine. Both nations have since reconciled with Caf and will participate in the 2017 qualifiers, with Tunisia aiming for a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

McLaren, historically one of Formula 1's most successful teams with 182 race wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a significant decline.
