Their struggles began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and have continued due to problems with their Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team is now only aiming for modest grid positions and points. McLaren previously enjoyed dominant eras, notably with Honda engines in the late 1980s and Mercedes engines in the late 1990s. However, controversies such as the 2007 espionage scandal and the 2009 "lie-gate" incident have marred their reputation. Ron Dennis, who previously led the team to success, returned after the 2013 slump but has yet to reverse the decline. Dennis remains confident that McLaren will soon return to winning championships, a belief shared by Alonso, who rejoined the team in 2015 hoping for renewed success.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST. Police found evidence that alcohol had been served until 04:49 BST, well beyond permitted licensing hours. Limavady Magistrates Court subsequently ordered the bar closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, faced two charges of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours and was fined £3,000, while James Thomas faced one similar charge and was fined £1,000. The judge criticized the management of the bar, noting O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressing regret at lacking authority to impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and hitting eight three-pointers to surpass his previous record of 272, as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry also had nine assists, while teammate Klay Thompson added 26 points. LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points and Damian Lillard had 20 points for Portland. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78, led by Pau Gasol's 16 points and 15 rebounds. Miami struggled significantly after halftime, scoring only 27 points in the second half, severely hurting their playoff chances.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen visited their training ground at Melwood. Initially believing he was just a competition winner, the players soon realized Van Velzen was actually a skilled free-kick specialist. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube videos showcasing his free-kick abilities, impressed the Liverpool stars with his talent, even pretending at first to be inexperienced. He described the experience as amazing, particularly enjoying the players' reactions to his skills. Van Velzen also surprised Balotelli by referencing the player's famous slogan from a previous match.

Women carrying the BRCA1 gene mutation, such as actress Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by undergoing ovary removal surgery (oophorectomy). A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA mutations found that ovary removal after diagnosis reduced breast cancer death by 62% in BRCA1 carriers, but not in BRCA2 carriers. Overall, ovary removal was associated with a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The protective effect was strongest when surgery occurred within two years of diagnosis, showing a 73% reduction in death. Researchers suggest ovary removal should be considered as part of initial treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers, especially those with early-stage breast cancer. BRCA mutations significantly increase lifetime breast cancer risk (50-80%), and are more common among Ashkenazi Jewish women. Jolie, who underwent both a double mastectomy and ovary removal, publicly supported the procedure, emphasizing it did not diminish her sense of femininity.

On Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina, a married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train traveling from Charlotte to New York City. The accident occurred shortly before 10 am on tracks owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers aboard were injured, though one passenger received medical attention after falling ill during the nearly three-hour delay caused by the incident. The couple, who may have lived in a homeless camp, were pronounced dead at the scene.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member, spent 27 years working undercover for the DEA in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. Toro provided crucial information leading to the prosecution of high-profile figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, Toro was never granted citizenship, was unpaid for his work, and now faces deportation after retiring due to declining health. Toro fears he will be killed if deported to Colombia, and the DEA has refused to assist him after he publicly revealed his situation. He remains in legal limbo, unable to collect social security or secure permanent residency, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

The US internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices involving the '.sucks' domain. Vox Populi has been accused of exploiting celebrities and companies by charging high fees—around $2,499 per year—to protect their reputations by removing or securing '.sucks' domains. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have reportedly paid to remove their names from these domains. Major brands such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have also been targeted. ICANN initially approved the '.sucks' domain but is reconsidering after complaints from industry groups labeling the practice as predatory and coercive. ICANN has referred the matter to US and Canadian regulators to determine legality and may take further action depending on their findings.

A woman was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found wrapped in a blanket inside a bag floating in a Norfolk village pond. DNA analysis from a recent exhumation identified her as the mother. Initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide, the charge was dropped after she explained the baby was stillborn and she had concealed her pregnancy from family and friends. Police confirmed no foul play or third-party involvement. The baby, originally buried unnamed, was reburied with the name Peter, after the local church. A charity provided a new headstone, and police expressed empathy for the mother, acknowledging the emotional complexity of the case.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from Young's moving taxi. The incident occurred five years ago in Bath, Somerset, when Young mistakenly believed Hicks intended to avoid paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank as punishment. Hicks jumped from the vehicle traveling over 20 mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries, epilepsy, and the need for constant care from his mother. The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling Hicks to damages, although the compensation amount will be reduced by 50 percent due to Hicks' decision to jump from the moving vehicle. The final compensation amount, expected to be hundreds of thousands of pounds, is yet to be determined. Both parties have permission to appeal.

Several tornadoes and severe storms were reported Wednesday night in Kansas and Missouri. Tornado sirens sounded near Wichita, Kansas, with one tornado spotted northwest of Goddard, narrowly missing Wichita but threatening nearby communities. Additional tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. In Missouri, a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, and roof damage. Nearby areas experienced large hail and unusual cloud formations. Severe weather is expected to continue Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face off in a middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold, aiming for his fourth consecutive win since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago, believes he must aggressively pressure Machida, who prefers a more elusive, defensive style. Rockhold sees clear weaknesses in Machida's game, particularly on the ground, and plans to dominate by forcing Machida into uncomfortable positions. While Rockhold respects Machida's skills and experience, he is confident in his own abilities and preparation. Machida, coming off a victory against CB Dollaway, also feels confident, believing that if he executes his strategy effectively, he can defeat Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters acknowledge the importance of this bout in determining the next title contender.

An aircraft was filmed landing without deploying its landing gear at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane skidded along the runway on its belly, damaging its propellers. Upon realizing the mistake, the pilot quickly re-engaged the engines and managed to take off again despite the damage. Remarkably, the pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, successfully flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. Georgaklis, who has nearly 50 years of flying experience, was accompanied by his dog. The FAA is investigating the incident, noting that gear-up landings typically result from human error or mechanical failure.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performances this season but pledged to support the midfielder at least until the end of the campaign. Manchester City are reportedly open to offers for Toure as they plan to refresh their ageing squad. Pellegrini acknowledged Toure's underperformance but dismissed suggestions that he needs rest. City goalkeeper Joe Hart admitted the players have let Pellegrini down and insisted the manager retains the team's support. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell against moving to City, citing previous examples of English players who struggled for playing time there.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence for mafia association expired under Italian law. Rancadore, who fled Italy in 1995 and lived in Britain for over 20 years under the alias Marc Skinner, was convicted in absentia in 1999. Although initially ordered to be extradited to Italy, it emerged that his sentence had legally expired in October 2014, as Italian law extinguishes sentences after double the penalty period has passed. Consequently, the European arrest warrant against him is being withdrawn. The case must still be formally concluded by the Italian Supreme Court, but Rancadore's solicitor expects the extradition request to be dropped. The case drew criticism from legal experts due to the time and resources spent on extradition proceedings, compounded by administrative errors by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS). Rancadore will now remain in the UK with his family.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy and trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Sprinter Sacre will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This race will be McCoy's final Grade One ride before retirement, a decision he announced after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body after declining to do so for decades. Marcia's body was discovered 33 days after her disappearance, strangled and sexually assaulted, near her home. Ritter, who initially followed her late husband's advice not to view the photos, now regrets waiting so long and expressed anger and a desire for revenge upon seeing the images. Barrett was convicted in 2009 of second-degree murder after DNA evidence linked him to the crime, receiving a 44-year sentence.

Rory McIlroy, currently ranked world number one, is determined to win the Masters to complete a career grand slam, a feat achieved by only five golfers in history. Reflecting on his 2011 collapse at Augusta, McIlroy describes it as the most important day of his career, teaching him valuable lessons that led to subsequent major victories. Despite having only one top-10 finish at Augusta, he finds it "unthinkable" to end his career without winning at least one Masters title, believing he can succeed multiple times there. McIlroy emphasizes the importance of focusing on his game rather than the pressure and hype surrounding the event, viewing the golf course as a sanctuary from external distractions.

This passage summarizes trending stories from the week, including four rainbows appearing over New York after heavy rain, exotic dancers at funerals in rural China facing a crackdown, Robert Downey Jr.'s tense interview, the viral "#kyliejennerchallenge" for lip plumping, a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past through film, controversy over a prom invitation referencing bombs, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's dramatic transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer, a pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombing his son.

Hundreds of children in England were hospitalized last year due to brain damage caused by exposure to alcohol in the womb, with official figures showing 272 cases of foetal alcohol syndrome. Experts warn the actual number affected could be significantly higher, with WHO research suggesting at least one in 100 UK babies—around 7,500 annually—may suffer learning, behavioural, and physical disabilities from prenatal alcohol exposure. Foetal alcohol syndrome is permanent, under-diagnosed, and can cause severe lifelong disabilities, as illustrated by the case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires constant care. Current government guidelines advise pregnant women to limit alcohol intake, but experts advocate for a complete abstinence recommendation during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a former juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy," has been jailed for six years after attempting to rob a store in County Durham. During the robbery, McKerry wielded an axe and demanded cash, but was tackled by shop owner Sab Dhillon and struck twice with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife, Sam, causing him to drop the weapon. McKerry, who had a lengthy criminal history including numerous arrests and convictions dating back to his youth, was arrested by police shortly after the incident.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Simon Radford (31), Craig Stoner (24), and Darren Smalley (35)—have been charged with gang rape following an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian military barracks near Halifax, Nova Scotia. The alleged assault occurred after the sailors, who were participating in a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament, returned from a game. The victim, a local woman in her early 20s, attended the party with a friend invited by Canadian servicemen. The accused sailors have been granted bail under strict conditions: each must pay over £2,000, surrender their passports, remain in Nova Scotia, reside at the Stadacona naval base, and continue employment with the Royal Navy. They face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, punishable by up to 14 years imprisonment. The investigation is ongoing, and additional charges may follow pending forensic results.

RJ Jackson, a four-year-old boy from Las Vegas, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disease affecting only about 70 people worldwide. The condition causes his skin to appear red, inflamed, scaly, and "scalded," requiring frequent application of creams to ease his symptoms. His mother, Valerie Jackson, has faced accusations of child abuse from strangers who mistake RJ's condition for signs of mistreatment, including an incident where armed police confronted her after a member of the public reported her. RJ and his family regularly endure cruel comments, bullying, and exclusion from public places due to ignorance about his condition. Valerie discovered RJ's diagnosis through an online support group after doctors initially struggled to identify the disease. Despite the challenges, Valerie emphasizes her son's beauty and joyful personality, hoping increased awareness will reduce misunderstanding and prejudice.

Campaigners and feminists have strongly criticized Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" adverts featuring bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield, arguing they promote unrealistic and unhealthy body standards. A Change.org petition demanding their removal gathered over 50,000 signatures, and the Advertising Standards Authority received more than 200 complaints. Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the posters would be removed, but clarified this was due to the end of the paid three-week advertising period, not directly because of complaints. Protein World defended their campaign, claiming the image was unphotoshopped and aimed at promoting fitness and health. The company faced backlash for its aggressive responses on social media, including dismissive comments towards critics. The controversy escalated to threats against Protein World, including a bomb threat under police investigation. Despite the backlash, Protein World described the campaign as "fantastic" and indicated they would not change their advertising approach.

Rail companies have faced criticism for planning fare increases of up to 87% shortly after the general election, despite political leaders promising fare freezes. Prime Minister David Cameron has personally intervened, urging First Great Western (FGW) to reconsider its planned fare hikes on the London-Cotswolds route, which affects his Witney constituency. FGW intends to raise the off-peak return fare from Charlbury to London from £33.30 to £62.40, an 87% increase. Other significant fare increases include routes operated by London Midlands and Virgin Trains, with hikes ranging from 22% to 24.5%. FGW claims the changes align the Cotswolds route with its other services and offers cheaper advance-purchase options. Virgin defended its increases, noting they primarily affect cheaper "Virgin-only" fares and that its overall fare rise is below the industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left permanently blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The incident occurred when Young confronted the attackers who had been throwing stones at his property. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. Young, recently married to Elaine, 54, expressed feeling unsafe and confused about why they were targeted. Police have launched an investigation but currently see no clear motive, suggesting it may have been random vandalism. The couple, who had married just three weeks earlier, now plan to move away due to fear for their safety.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a one-year contract extension following his successful return from injury. Poynton, aged 25, missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident in which his father died. After undergoing ankle surgery, he returned to play during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. He is now committed to Derbyshire until the end of the 2016 season. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, praised Poynton's exceptional character, dedication, and good form since returning, expressing hope that the new contract will boost his confidence.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, has been declared cancer-free after battling neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children annually in the UK. Initially diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, Harley underwent intensive chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy. To help him feel brave during treatment, Harley decorated his protective radiotherapy mask as a Ninja Turtle superhero mask, gaining international attention and receiving gifts from Nickelodeon. His bravery earned him recognition from Cancer Research UK. Harley will continue regular check-ups to monitor his health, and his family is overjoyed and optimistic about his future.

Jack Grealish, a promising 19-year-old Aston Villa player, is currently at the center of an international tug-of-war between England and the Republic of Ireland. Villa manager Tim Sherwood has advised Grealish to prioritize his club career and continue performing well for Aston Villa before making a decision about his international future. Sherwood emphasized that the choice is entirely Grealish's, comparing it to a similar situation he experienced with Nabil Bentaleb at Tottenham. Grealish's father agrees with Sherwood's advice, stating that his son should focus on club football first and that the international decision will follow naturally. Grealish, who has previously represented Ireland at youth level, is expected to make his final decision at the end of the season.

Travelling by private jet is an expensive luxury, with landing fees varying significantly between airports. The highest landing fees are charged at airports that are unexpectedly popular among wealthy travelers, such as Salzburg in Austria and Darwin in Australia. Private jet travel is a growing industry, with millions of flights annually in the US and Europe, and is particularly busy during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix. The most expensive airports for landing fees are predominantly in Japan, with Tokyo's Haneda Airport topping the list at £4,559 ($6,850). Other costly airports include Narita and Kansai in Japan, Toronto Pearson in Canada, Darwin in Australia, Bristol in the UK, Dublin in Ireland, LaGuardia in the US, and Salzburg in Austria. Popular private jet routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to Rome, but landing at these top airports incurs significantly higher fees.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy ate delicately, Cooper quickly consumed the treat in one bite, a habit typical for him. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, ensures Daisy eats first due to Cooper's speed. A video of this event has gained over seven million views, receiving mixed reactions—some viewers found it cute and funny, while others criticized feeding dogs ice cream. Gallegos defended the practice, noting Cooper's excellent health and athleticism, and mentioned her previous dog lived to 19 years old with similar weekly treats. The dogs also enjoy occasional Starbucks "pup-uccinos," which Gallegos clarified contain only whipped cream and no coffee.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year contract after a successful interim period. Locke initially joined as assistant manager last summer and stepped into the interim role in February following Allan Johnston's departure. Since taking charge, he has lost only one of seven matches.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. Kemp applies scented oils, manufactured by Doterra, to Logan's head and neck, believing they help him stay calm and focused. The school claims the oils' smell distracts other students and staff, prompting a complaint from a teacher's aide. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem, but she insists on continuing their use, arguing they positively impact her son. Lake County School District later clarified they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue." The family uses oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, known as the Sandpiper complex, was destroyed by a severe fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze consumed 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. The fire was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings and was visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but could not enter the building. The cause of the fire remains unknown, though authorities are investigating reports it may have started near a parked car. Residents and the building manager lost everything in the incident. The complex, typically used as holiday homes, operates between May and November.

Approaching her 89th birthday, the Queen was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park, accompanied by a groom. Despite encouragement to wear a helmet, she prefers a silk scarf, reportedly due to concerns about her hairstyle. The Queen has been passionate about horses since receiving her first pony, Peggy, at age four, and has ridden throughout her life, although recently reducing her riding due to a knee injury. She breeds several horse and pony breeds, including Fell ponies at Hampton Court and Highland ponies at Balmoral. Fell ponies, an ancient breed from Cumbria, were historically valued by Romans, Vikings, and Normans for their strength and versatility, and remain popular today, including with the Queen herself.

An argument between two Brisbane neighbours over noise levels ended tragically, with 55-year-old Leon Yeaman killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. Yeaman was reportedly making loud noise around 9 pm, disturbing Pama, a shift worker who was sleeping at the time. Pama confronted Yeaman, and during the altercation, punched him once, allegedly while being pushed. Yeaman, described as kind, generous, and a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed loud music, died at the scene. Pama, a married father of three with no prior history of violence, was charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail, ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to police twice weekly. The case returns to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, faces up to 15 years in prison after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old pupil, Damian Vanya, who had ended their relationship to date a classmate. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the attack, instructing the supposed hitman—actually an undercover police officer—to severely injure the boy before she personally joined in to "finish" him. The exchange was secretly filmed, and Simonova was arrested and charged with attempted murder. Damian expressed relief at her arrest, hoping authorities would "throw away the key."

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho has revealed that he prays daily and maintains a strong faith in God, though he never discusses football in his prayers or with his wife. Mourinho emphasizes the importance of separating his professional and personal lives, describing himself as a good family man and friend who tries to support others. He acknowledges making mistakes professionally due to the competitive and emotional nature of football management. Mourinho, who serves as an ambassador against hunger for the World Food Programme, says he and his family understand poverty. He attends church regularly only when in Portugal. Earlier in the season, Mourinho was fined £25,000 for alleging a campaign against Chelsea.

On the April 1 episode of "The Price is Right," former host Bob Barker returned to the show for the first time in eight years. Barker, who hosted the game show for 35 years before retiring in 2007, appeared at age 91 and led the first game segment before handing hosting duties back to current host Drew Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared energetic and comfortable in his role.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested early Friday morning in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house. Baldwin faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Following his arrest, Baldwin's security clearance was revoked and he was placed on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which handles diplomatic activities. His arrest follows recent misconduct allegations involving other Secret Service personnel, including a high-ranking supervisor under investigation by Homeland Security's inspector general, and a separate incident involving two officials accused of entering a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life by approaching a hungry lion within just 10 feet at a safari park to capture close-up photographs. Armed only with his camera, Saeed lay on the ground near his open car door, but the camera's shutter noise alerted the lion, causing it to aggressively jump toward him. Saeed narrowly escaped by quickly retreating into his car. Although he laughed at the time, he later admitted he probably wouldn't attempt such a dangerous stunt again.

New York City police are seeking help identifying a woman found dead nearly a month ago on a Brooklyn street. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and pronounced dead that evening. She had no identification but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg featuring the name "Monique" within a heart topped with a rose. Authorities have released images of the tattoo to aid identification efforts. The cause of death is still pending a medical examiner's report, and police are asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, returning from the UK in 2009, couldn't afford traditional property, so they built a unique home on a 1986 flatbed truck. Over a year and a half, they constructed a cozy, solar-powered, two-bedroom house using wood and steel. Now located on a purchased lot in Nelson, New Zealand, their home features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is nearly self-sufficient, powered mostly by solar panels and supplied with water from a nearby spring. The entire project cost around $25,000, and the couple enjoys living close to nature, surrounded by trees and a brook.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class performed significantly better in early literacy tests than those who either had individual iPads or no iPads at all. Students sharing iPads scored approximately 30 points higher. Blackwell suggests that the collaborative learning facilitated by shared technology, rather than collaboration alone, contributed to these improved outcomes. She recommends schools reconsider how tablets are used, particularly in early education, to maximize their effectiveness. These findings were presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association.

A piglet born without hind legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its two front legs. Nicknamed "super pig," it gained popularity through a heartwarming video showing it balancing and foraging for food despite occasionally wobbling. Owned by farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai city in Sichuan province, China, the piglet has attracted villagers eager to see the unusual animal. It interacts normally with its siblings, who all have four legs. This piglet is not the first two-legged animal to gain fame in China; previously, a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became popular for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when driver Francesco Dracone spun his car while exiting the pit box, striking Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut and was released after treatment. The incident occurred amid challenging track conditions due to prolonged rain. Dracone did not finish the race, ending up in 23rd place.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, just four days after their marriage. CCTV footage captured Severiano violently slamming her head into concrete paving 11 times, punching her repeatedly, and then shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to police that he committed the crime out of jealousy, accusing his wife of attracting attention from other men. After the murder, he attempted to flee in a stolen car but crashed and was arrested. Police found multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in his vehicle. Severiano now faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," has openly discussed her personal struggle with mental illness, revealing she once came close to suicide due to severe anxiety. In a candid interview, Wilson explained that a combination of anxiety, stress, thyroid disease, and isolation from family led her to feel life was no longer worth living. She described feeling alone and unable to see a way forward. Wilson now acknowledges herself as an anxious person and believes anxiety and depression are closely linked, emphasizing the importance of recognizing this connection to better address rising anxiety rates among Australian women. According to Beyond Blue, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and anxiety can often lead to depression.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found the woman using heroin in her bathroom and attacked her after she refused to leave. Prosecutors later dropped the charges, stating Curtin was justified under Oregon law, which allows force against intruders who refuse to leave. Curtin gave birth in January and has since separated from her boyfriend, who previously struggled with heroin addiction. The boyfriend and his ex-girlfriend share a five-year-old child and had previously used drugs together. Curtin now lives with her parents and has moved on from the relationship.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner, who tried to trick her by including broccoli. Gemma reacted with disgust, immediately spitting out the vegetable. The dog lives with two children, and there is hope they won't follow her example and will instead learn to enjoy vegetables. Other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic page. The issue arose because the URL for HSBC's Young Entrepreneur Awards, discontinued in 2011, was allowed to expire and was subsequently taken over by a pornographic site. HSBC removed the hyperlink, clarified it had no association with the external site, and assured the public that its website remains secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus calmly guided firefighters during an 11-minute 911 call after a fire broke out in his family's home in Clinton, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus provided clear instructions to rescuers, comforted his frightened sister, and remained composed throughout the ordeal. Firefighters successfully rescued the siblings by breaking a window and entering the room. Marcus and his sister were hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries, while three other family members escaped on their own and were also hospitalized.

Blue fluorescent algae recently illuminated Australia's east coast, specifically at Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the event, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The glow is produced by a single-celled phytoplankton called noctiluca scintillans, which typically blooms naturally in spring and autumn. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales, this algae is carnivorous, preying on another algae type called diatoms, and emits the luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar event occurred previously at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.

New genetic tests, such as EndoPredict, can help breast cancer patients avoid chemotherapy by identifying genetic markers in tumors to determine the risk of recurrence. After surgery, tumor cells are analyzed to assess whether the cancer has a high or low chance of returning. For some women, the test can accurately predict recurrence risk as low as five percent, comparable to or better than chemotherapy outcomes. Chemotherapy, commonly given after tumor removal, has severe side effects including hair loss, nausea, weight changes, and fatigue, making it daunting for many patients. Currently, these tests are mostly available privately at around £2,500, but specialists advocate for NHS adoption, arguing that costs would be offset by reduced chemotherapy use. Experts emphasize that such tests allow patients to make informed decisions rather than automatically undergoing chemotherapy. A patient example, Becca Cornford, benefited from the EndoPredict test, which showed her recurrence risk was low enough to safely avoid chemotherapy, allowing her to better care for her children.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. Emergency evacuations occurred on 18 other ships. The Ministry of Defence maintains a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before deployment or during leave. Commander Sarah West, the first female captain of a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK amid allegations of a relationship with a crew member, prompting an investigation. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, comprising around 9% of personnel in 2014, and three women became the first female submariners in 2014. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq due to pregnancy between 2006 and 2013, as military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence, raising concerns about potential drone-related terrorism. The incident coincided with a court decision approving the restart of two nuclear reactors, a controversial move opposed by many Japanese citizens following the Fukushima disaster. Authorities noted the drone was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing cesium, though the amount found was not immediately harmful. The discovery prompted government officials to emphasize the need for stricter drone regulations and heightened security measures, especially ahead of events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was abroad at the time of the incident.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province in China, has gained widespread attention for his devoted care of his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. After his father's death, Lu began taking his mother to work daily on his motorbike, securing her with a sash to prevent falls. He fears she might wander off if left alone, as she previously got lost collecting firewood. His employer, a bank, provides a room for her at his workplace. Lu feels a deep sense of duty to care for his mother, reflecting her past devotion to raising him.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans increased significantly between 2005 and 2012, driven largely by rising rates among women. Heavy drinking rose by 17.2%, and binge drinking among women increased at more than seven times the rate among men. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Changing social norms, increased alcohol advertising, weakening alcohol control policies, and relatively cheaper alcohol prices are cited as contributing factors. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. Alcohol-related deaths in the U.S. were approximately 88,600 in 2010, with excessive drinking costing over $220 billion annually.

Doctors are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting women and their babies at risk, according to UN officials. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends caesareans only when medically necessary, ideally between 10% and 15% of births, due to risks such as infections, complications, disability, or death. Currently, just over a quarter of births in England are caesareans, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The WHO's stance contradicts NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans even without medical justification, including for anxiety about childbirth. Caesareans also cost significantly more than natural births and divert resources from other healthcare needs.

Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into an $800,000 summer home in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner's belongings in a yard sale. She faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Homeowner Mark Conklin discovered Filkins inside his home, where she falsely claimed ownership before fleeing. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket. Missing items include furniture, lamps, kitchenware, linens, and a painting. Authorities have requested that anyone who received items return them and offered assistance in seeking restitution. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

Bella Crooke from Melbourne lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend's birthday party. It was handed in to Albury police station, where officers humorously posted selfies, puns, and playful messages on Bella's Facebook page to inform her the phone was safe and ready for collection. Bella, unaware of these posts, later retrieved her phone and found the police had also humorously replied to her friends' texts. The amusing posts quickly gained attention online, and Bella praised the officers' good humor, subsequently adding a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed after being caught in a fight between two adult hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water surface, suffering fatal injuries. Its mother watched helplessly, initially staying with her herd for safety, but later attempting unsuccessfully to rescue her calf. The incident was witnessed by a tour operator who described the event as shocking and tragic.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is listed for £575,000, significantly cheaper than neighboring properties. However, the low price is due to the lease having only three years remaining, equating to around £191,000 per year—similar to local rental rates. The property, located in exclusive Egerton Place, requires extensive renovation but offers 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and communal garden. Extending the lease could increase its value to approximately £6 million, but a 90-year lease extension would cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. Estate agents report high interest due to the rarity of such short-lease properties, but warn potential buyers of the substantial costs involved in lease extension.

A computer outage at Starbucks affected sales registers at approximately 8,000 stores across the US and Canada, prompting baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented stores from accepting credit cards and ringing up sales, though some locations continued accepting cash. Starbucks resolved the issue late Friday night and expected normal operations to resume Saturday. While many customers enjoyed the unexpected giveaway, some Starbucks locations closed early to avoid further losses. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists have been undergoing training and radicalisation activities in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Extremists participate in seemingly ordinary community activities but have ulterior motives. Historical incidents include Abu Hamza sending extremists to train in Powys in 1998, two of the 7/7 bombers visiting North Wales in 2005, and a 2010 plot involving Cardiff-based terrorists planning Mumbai-style attacks. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, an institution reportedly established by Iraqi clerics. Authorities emphasize the importance of community intelligence in combating terrorism.

An Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Western Australia following tropical cyclone Olwyn. This discovery marks the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, DNA profiling confirmed the whale as a juvenile female Omura's whale. The species, first scientifically described in 2003, is typically found in tropical and subtropical waters around Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. Scientists consider this find highly significant, as little is known about Omura's whales. The whale's carcass has been buried, and its skeleton will later be recovered for further scientific study and possibly museum display.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding gender bias in leadership, sparked by a Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, who argued that Hillary Clinton should not be president due to hormonal differences making women irrational. The author counters this argument by highlighting historical examples of male leaders making irrational decisions, noting studies that show women leaders typically take fewer unnecessary risks. The passage emphasizes that the real issue is not biology but deeply ingrained gender bias, which continues to limit women's opportunities despite their educational and professional achievements. It cites evidence of overt and covert bias, such as the disproportionate representation of men on corporate boards and biased perceptions of male versus female professors. The author argues that achieving gender equality benefits everyone economically, socially, and personally, and stresses the importance of confronting and overcoming gender stereotypes to ensure equal opportunities for future generations.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small," portraying Winston Churchill, and appearing as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films, is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques and historical items. The auction, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes over 200 items such as furniture, paintings, swords, rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, rare books dating back to the 17th century, and a specially commissioned diorama of the Battle of Agincourt. Hardy, aged 89, is a military historian and expert on medieval longbows, having studied English under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford. He expressed sadness at downsizing his collection but hopes the items will bring joy to their new owners. Hardy retired from stage acting after a fall but intends to continue television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted by Florida authorities as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. Police became suspicious after Shemansky missed a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was discovered following a well-being check requested by a family member. Authorities confirmed foul play and have recovered the murder weapon but have not disclosed details about the cause of death. Shemansky, who has a history of bipolar disorder, previous violence against law enforcement, and past psychiatric hospitalization, was reportedly under significant stress due to ongoing divorce proceedings. Neighbors suggest his mother prevented him from attending the visit with his son, possibly triggering the incident. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without medication or supplies, and authorities are actively seeking information on his whereabouts.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously lost its bid for the 2019 championships to Doha, Qatar, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of Eugene's capability. IAAF president Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic importance of accessing the U.S. market and the collaboration among public authorities, private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the public. This decision mirrors a similar situation in 2007, when Osaka, Japan, was also awarded the championships without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, into a deadly robbery. Granger befriended Hassan at a London casino, exploiting his generosity and vulnerability. After a date, she left his flat unlocked, allowing her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler to enter, tie up, and brutally kick Hassan to death while searching for his gambling winnings. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," driven by ruthless greed. Granger, who claimed she acted out of love for Jackson, was found guilty of manslaughter but acquitted of murder. The attackers stole £3,000, a TV, and a mobile phone, and were later caught after police examined Granger's phone records.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas has experienced a notable decline in form during the second half of the season, continuing a pattern observed during his previous tenure at Barcelona. Despite an impressive start at Chelsea, where he seemed certain to break Thierry Henry's Premier League assist record, Fabregas' performances have significantly dipped since January. His recent poor form was evident in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland, raising concerns about his durability and fatigue from a demanding season. Although Chelsea remain on course for the Premier League title, manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping Fabregas can regain his early-season form to help secure the championship.

West Ham are close to signing Jamaican youngster Deshane Beckford after he impressed during a two-week trial with their academy. The talented 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United has attracted interest from several European clubs, including offers from Belgium, and is considered one of the Caribbean's most promising talents. Separately, West Ham announced affordable season ticket prices starting at £289 for their move to the 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium in the 2016-17 season, making them the cheapest in the Premier League.

Police have dropped an investigation into a violent assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman and joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, despite substantial evidence including video footage, car registration numbers, and a photograph of the suspect. Lane was attacked by masked protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, resulting in concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling, and memory loss. Wiltshire Police stated the case is currently undetected due to insufficient evidence, angering Lane and hunt supporters who feel let down and believe more could have been done. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings worn by saboteurs to aid future prosecutions.

Adam Gadahn, also known as "Azzam the American," was an American-born spokesperson for al Qaeda, killed in January at age 36 during a U.S. counterterrorism operation. Gadahn, who converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, became al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, appearing in numerous videos threatening attacks and urging violence against American, Western, and Jewish interests. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to terrorism, becoming one of the FBI's most wanted terrorists. Gadahn's final video appeared in September 2014, calling for the overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married to an Afghan woman and reportedly had at least one child.

Chinese parents are passionate about raising child prodigies, and a new basketball star, five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, is gaining fame in China. A viral video shows Mai demonstrating exceptional basketball skills, including scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. Mai began playing basketball at two and a half years old, and his impressive talent has earned him numerous fans across China, prompting amazed reactions and admiration from netizens.

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), a group that campaigned in the 1970s and 80s to legalise child sex, has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25, lobbying MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, seeks statutory regulation of the press as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's involvement is likely to embarrass the group. PIE previously allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), lobbying to lower the age of sexual consent to ten and legalise incest. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals, confirmed his attendance at the rally in a blog post. A Hacked Off spokesman stated the meeting was open to the public.

Bondi's iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as an unusual catwalk for the Ten Pieces fashion presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Ten Pieces, a lifestyle brand led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome, minimalist, androgynous collection of ten unisex clothing items designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for day-to-night wear. Guests enjoyed refreshments and sunny weather, while beachgoers and passers-by stopped to watch the unique event unfold against the backdrop of the ocean.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a relaxing day with his family at a safari park in northern California, where he posed with giraffes, sea lions, and fed a rare white tiger. He was accompanied by his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next boxing match against former light-welterweight champion Chris Algieri, scheduled for May 30, ending speculation about potential fights with Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, and Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis, had his name included on an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His family objected strongly, stating they were not consulted and did not want his name listed alongside Israeli soldiers. Almagor, an Israeli organization representing terror victims, also opposed his inclusion, arguing his death was an individual criminal act rather than terrorism. Following these complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel decided to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial and its website.

A young boy was filmed by his father, YouTube user Lionel Hutz, chasing their family cat around the garden, repeatedly attempting to use the cat's belly as a pillow. Each time the boy rested his head on the cat, the feline quickly moved away, prompting the child to follow and repeat the action. Eventually, the cat had enough and went indoors. A later video showed the pair reconciled, with the boy gently feeding treats to the cat.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past marijuana sales. Kushner, one of several former drug dealers testifying against police officers accused of wrongdoing, revealed that officers stole cash and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Although Kushner had passed a background check when hired in 2010, school officials were unaware of his criminal history, including a 2008 DUI conviction and a 2011 arrest resulting in probation. Kushner maintains his innocence regarding the 2011 charges and expressed regret over his past actions. The defense attorneys for the accused officers argue that the government's case relies on dishonest witnesses.

An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, injured six people and caused a large fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a chemical reportedly linked to cancer and used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill was reported. Five people were hospitalized due to injuries from broken glass. Over 600 firefighters responded, and the fire is now under control. The plant previously experienced an explosion in 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. PX plants have sparked protests in China due to pollution concerns, leading authorities to relocate this plant from the densely populated city of Xiamen to its current, more remote location.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland under-21 international, is known for wearing his socks low and using children's-sized shinpads due to superstition. Despite referees advising him otherwise, he insists he will continue this habit. Grealish recently made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing satisfaction at finally starting despite disappointment with the result. He appreciates his manager's faith and hopes for more starts this season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered global and irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Although no longer in a medically induced coma, the 22-year-old remains unresponsive, unable to react to visitors or familiar voices, and has a tracheostomy. Her grandmother expressed sadness over the possibility of her living indefinitely in this condition, hoping only for a miracle. Despite this, Bobbi Kristina's father, Bobby Brown, recently stated publicly that she was awake and watching him, and his attorney confirmed some improvement, noting she has left ICU and begun a long rehabilitation process. However, the quality of life she will have remains uncertain and may not be clear for years.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final after taking a 2-0 lead against Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, despite struggling with her serve and committing 13 double faults. Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were decisive. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova had beaten Julia Goerges in straight sets. Russia now needs just one more victory from the remaining three matches to advance to the final and compete for their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, already impacted by recent severe storms, are being warned to prepare for further flooding and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate an east coast low, similar to the previous storm, could bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, primarily affecting northern coastal areas and the Hunter region, which was severely impacted previously. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that additional storms will hinder ongoing clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 requests for assistance still pending. Authorities urge residents to prepare their homes and families to minimize further damage.

Nina Moric, a model known for appearing in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied recent Italian media reports claiming she attempted suicide. Moric clarified on Instagram that she was hospitalized after collapsing at home due to low blood pressure, resulting in bruising and injuries. Despite her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso reportedly confirming a suicide attempt, Moric insisted she had no intention of harming herself and was shocked by the claims. She stated she is recovering at home and only needs rest. Italian media previously reported a suicide attempt by Moric in 2009. Moric was formerly married to paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

As Kate and William await their second child, the British public strongly favors traditional names. A recent poll indicates that "Diana," after William's late mother, Princess Diana, is the most popular choice if the baby is a girl, receiving 12% of votes. Other favored girl names include Alice and Charlotte, each with 9%. For a boy, the preferred names are James and Alexander. The majority of respondents (25%) hope for a girl, compared to only 3% wanting a boy. Social media users also expressed enthusiasm for naming the baby Diana. Additionally, the poll showed strong public support (68%) for William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bombing in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killed 17 people and injured 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, during a protest against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves, who spent seven successful years at Barcelona winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, could not agree on a new deal. His agent confirmed that negotiations ended after Alves turned down a three-year extension, which required him to participate in 60% of matches. The agent expressed disappointment that Barcelona waited until April to address Alves' contract renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has encouraged Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has quickly become popular at Boca, believes Pirlo and Totti's playing styles would suit the team perfectly and that Boca fans would enthusiastically welcome them. He specifically highlighted their South-American style of play and their potential popularity at La Bombonera stadium.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, became an internet sensation after experiencing a dramatic double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square during a race at Wincanton. Despite the spectacular nature of the incident, Ferguson sustained only a minor cut on his nose and quickly returned to his regular stable duties and riding. He described the fall as unavoidable and joked about potentially pursuing gymnastics after racing, taking the incident in good humor despite receiving some teasing and gaining popularity online.

James Haskell, captain of the London Wasps rugby team, celebrated the release of the movie "Avengers: Age of Ultron" by posting an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man. The film premiered at Westfield London, featuring stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who began his rugby career with Wasps in 2002, left in 2009 to play internationally in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a key fashion trend for spring/summer 2015. It highlights their versatility, comfort, and appeal as an alternative to skinny jeans, which have dominated fashion for years. Louise Redknapp and Emma suggest pairing wide-leg trousers with high heels and simple tops to maintain flattering proportions, especially for shorter individuals. Denim is identified as the easiest way to adopt this trend, with Gucci, Celine, Stella McCartney, and Topshop showcasing various interpretations. The passage also notes that this style has returned periodically since the 1970s and can be worn regardless of weather conditions.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper," despite objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against it, citing negative portrayals of the Middle East. Initially, the university canceled the screening, but reversed the decision after backlash and a counter-petition. University officials stated that canceling the film was inconsistent with their commitment to freedom of expression and student choice. An alternative screening of the family-friendly film "Paddington" will also be offered. The decision received praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty after allegedly using an aerosol spray and lighter to ignite a flame that singed a quokka on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived the incident with minor injuries. Detectives seized video evidence, and the men, who were living in Cockburn Central, were evicted from the island and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, roughly the size of domestic cats, inhabit islands off Western Australia's coast, notably Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed in New York clubs like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen footage of herself dancing, as her memorabilia had been lost. With help from filmmakers and volunteers, she finally viewed old "soundies" (early music videos) featuring her performances. Barker was delighted by the experience, calling it "just fabulous."

The passage describes the decline of the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain. A recent survey by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that about a third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own cars, with only 12% of men who do wash their cars doing so regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include increased availability of hand car washes, larger vehicles being harder to clean, and busier lifestyles due to Sunday shopping and televised football. Only 5% of respondents have asked their children to wash the car for pocket money. Car washing by owners is most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least common in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Owners of Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to wash their own cars, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least likely. Holidays, such as Easter, see an increase in car washing, often as an excuse to leave the house.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard's significant impact at Liverpool, highlighting Gerrard's support when Skrtel joined the club in 2008. Gerrard, who is set to leave Liverpool for LA Galaxy after this season, aims to conclude his Liverpool career by reaching and winning the FA Cup final against Arsenal. Skrtel described Gerrard as synonymous with Liverpool and still one of the world's best players, acknowledging the difficulty of replacing him. However, Skrtel believes Liverpool has players capable of filling Gerrard's role if supported properly. Both players are returning from recent suspensions and could feature in the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved his first-ever hole-in-one at Augusta National during the Masters' par-3 contest, thrilling the crowd alongside playing partners Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Although Nicklaus' ace was notable, Camilo Villegas overshadowed him by scoring two aces on the same day. Kevin Streelman ultimately won the par-3 contest. Nicklaus, known as the "Golden Bear," previously became the youngest Masters champion in 1963 and won a total of six green jackets. He is also one of only five golfers to complete the career grand slam.

Several storms caused tornado warnings and damage across Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. Tornado sightings were reported near Goddard, Kansas, close to Wichita, and near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. In Missouri, a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, and roof damage. Nearby areas experienced large hail and unusual cloud formations. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. More storms were expected Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he mistakenly used a gun instead of a taser during an arrest. Bates was granted permission by the judge to vacation in the Bahamas, prompting criticism from Harris' family, who viewed it as insensitive. Bates' lawyer stated they look forward to addressing the facts in court. Allegations arose that Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff, with claims supervisors were pressured to forge his records. The sheriff's office denied these allegations, and Bates' lawyer released training documents to support his qualifications. Two deputies involved in Harris' arrest were reassigned due to threats. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the fight, McGregor revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla tattoo. He claims to have greater motivation than Aldo, who is defending his title for the eighth time. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 home supporters, highlighting their tense rivalry.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after publicly skolling a beer at an Australian rules event. Critics, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert, argued Abbott's actions glorified binge drinking, promoted irresponsible drinking culture, and reinforced stereotypes linking masculinity to heavy drinking. Robert emphasized that such displays encourage drinking as a performance rather than social activity. Abbott's actions drew mixed reactions: opposition leader Bill Shorten joked about Abbott's drinking habits, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, highlighting his overall healthy lifestyle. Although previous prime ministers like Bob Hawke had similarly engaged in public drinking, critics noted that attitudes toward binge drinking have shifted, making Abbott's behavior problematic in the current climate.

Indiana is experiencing a significant rise in HIV cases linked to intravenous drug use, primarily involving the painkiller Opana, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County. Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, which has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants. However, the program's future is uncertain, as Pence opposes needle exchanges as anti-drug policy, and funding remains unclear due to federal restrictions. Lawmakers are debating legislation to allow needle exchanges in other counties, but concerns persist about promoting drug use versus harm reduction. Health officials emphasize the importance of needle exchanges in preventing further outbreaks, especially given the correlation between hepatitis C and HIV infections.

An obsessive Arsenal fan created a detailed football knowledge test for his girlfriend, Saskia, to assess her understanding of his favorite club. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), earning an 'A' grade and avoiding being dumped, as humorously threatened by her boyfriend. The test included multiple-choice questions, player positions, and creative responses, such as explaining why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard. Saskia shared the test on Twitter, prompting mixed reactions: some praised her boyfriend as a "legend" and Saskia as "proper girlfriend material," while others criticized him for taking things too far. Overall, the event was seen as humorous and playful, despite some negative comments.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. Toro provided crucial information leading to the prosecution of high-profile figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his extensive service, Toro never received citizenship and now faces deportation after retiring due to declining health. He fears returning to Colombia would result in his death. The DEA has refused to assist him after he publicly revealed his situation, leaving him without legal status, unable to collect social security, and considering going into hiding. Toro maintains he has fully atoned for his past and seeks only the citizenship he was promised.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village in Uttar Pradesh. Her family reportedly urged her to remain silent about the assault. She is now hospitalized in Delhi with severe burns covering 70% of her body. The accused men have been arrested. This incident occurs amid heightened sensitivity and widespread protests in India regarding sexual violence against women, following high-profile cases such as the brutal gang rape and murder of 23-year-old student Jyoti Singh Pandey, which sparked national and international outrage. Recent incidents have also included mob violence against accused rapists, highlighting ongoing tensions and demands for improved protection and justice for women in India.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is preparing for Sunday's derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, as he considers them not yet fit enough despite their own claims of fitness. Van Gaal emphasized the importance of winning this match, as victory could secure third place and help avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture. He acknowledged City's strength and dismissed the idea of revenge for an earlier defeat, stressing the need for controlled aggression. Van Gaal expressed excitement about experiencing his first home derby atmosphere, praising the fans' support.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest at the Emirates Stadium by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match, objecting to rising ticket prices. The protest followed the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal, highlighting fans' frustration at high costs, with tickets starting at £64. Organized by fan groups from both clubs, protesters displayed banners criticizing the league's financial priorities and warned that continued high prices risk alienating future generations of supporters. Further protests were planned after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, doctors determined a liver transplant was necessary. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but the baby's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader—twin sister of Star's mother Jade—offered part of her liver without hesitation. The transplant was successful, and both Star and Shanell have recovered well. Star will require lifelong anti-rejection medication and regular medical tests, but now has the chance to live a normal life thanks to her aunt's donation.

Chelsea footballers Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge, competing in various tasks involving shooting footballs into Audi cars. Hazard and Ake initially dominated, winning the first two rounds, including a close-range boot-shooting challenge and a tennis-style game played over an Audi R8. However, Remy and Willian won the final long-range shooting challenge, despite Willian accidentally breaking a car's wing mirror. The event concluded humorously, with Willian laughing after being allowed to drive one of the Audis.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a fatal highway crash in December 2013, killing a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn child. Prosecutors claimed Dellinger intentionally drove his truck across a median at over 100 mph in a suicide attempt, but Dellinger denied being suicidal during sentencing. His attorneys argued he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose effects, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis symptoms. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault charges related to the fetus' death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. He also faces a wrongful death lawsuit. His wife described him as ethical and modest, expressing devastation and sympathy to the victims' families.

Lacey Spears from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for murdering her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube. Prosecutors argued Spears harmed her son to gain attention, highlighting her extensive social media posts about his medical issues and hospitalizations. Spears showed no emotion during sentencing, prompting outrage from the boy's father, Chris Hill, who expressed anger and wished harm upon her in prison via Facebook. Spears' lawyer maintained her innocence, blaming hospital negligence and planning an appeal. The judge acknowledged Spears' mental illness but described the crime as cruel and unfathomable.

Two new influenza strains, influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket, caused increased deaths in Europe and the US because the previous vaccine did not effectively protect against them. As a result, Australian authorities delayed the arrival of influenza vaccine stocks by one month to include protection against these strains. High-risk groups, including the very young, elderly, and most indigenous Australians, will receive free government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, emphasize the importance of vaccination for everyone, as it also protects against influenza A strain H1N1. The updated vaccine is expected to be effective globally and will be identical to the one used in the next northern hemisphere winter.
